PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all priciples involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan,Mr Dobie,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Maher and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of ones's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropratic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Drummond,Mr Maher and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply than ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby and Mr Carlton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong oppositions to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/ or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with out Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ''Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton and Dr Everingham.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern at the way in which children are now being used in the production of pornography call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:
1. To prevent sexual exploitation of children by way of photography for commercial purposes;
2. To penalise parents/guardians who knowingly allow their children to be used in the production of such pornographic or obscene material depicting children;
3. To make specifically illegal the importation, publication, distribution and sale or of such pornographic child-abuse material in any form whatsoever such as magazines, novels, papers or films;

4. To take immediate police action to confiscate and destroy all child pornography in Australia and urgent appropriate legal action against all those involved or profiting from this sordid exploitation of children.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that your honourable House will protect all children and immediately prohibit pornographic child-abuse materials, publications or films.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows:

That the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance be not deleted or removed. An alternative form of allegiance is presently available to those persons who may object to taking the form of oath containing the reference to God.
That deletion of the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance will deny to persons who desire to make such an oath in the presence of God, the opportunity of exercising that right.

That Australia is recognised as a Christian Nation and as such, it is paramount that a continuing reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance be maintained so that our New Australian Citizens will be aware that Australia professes a Christian Way of Life.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ensure that the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance as it is presently worded is not removed or deleted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aircraft Noise at Launceston, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
Whereas the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has sat in Launceston, Tasmania, and taken evidence on the problem of aircraft noise over that city, and
Whereas that evidence has established that a prima facie case does exist on the matter of encroaching aircraft noise on the lives of people living under the existing takeoff flight paths;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
Request the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to bring down an interim report on the matter of aircraft noise at Launceston, Tasmania as a matter of urgency, as;

(a) The situation is becoming worse and, with the expected introduction of a Boeing 727 on the night freight services, the position will become intolerable for those living under the northerly takeoff flight path.
(b) There will be more jet aircraft flights at night than experienced in the day.
(c) That the present measures planned by the Department of Aviation to alleviate the noise are totally inadequate and fail to recognise the basic causes of the problem.

(d) The increasing noise problem affects the well being of the patients in five major hospitals, the aged in five aged home complexes and children in fourteen major schools and colleges, all under the mandatory flight path as laid down by the Department of Aviation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impracticable.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1% of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other States.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other States. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled, should-
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton , and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken .
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that
(i) no jet aircraft use the 32' 14' crosswind runway;
(ii) the Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That:
1. Certain sexual crimes including rape and murder have been linked by the courts to the viewing of 'pornographic' printed material, films and video tapes.
2. It cannot be guaranteed that these types of material will not be viewed by children.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives should-

Not adopt the 'X' classification for films and video tapes, nor Category 2 for printed material. Further, that tighter restrictions be applied to 'R' rated films and video tapes and Category 1 printed material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs ( Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Soviet Union continues to violate human rights in Latvia. This is clearly demonstrated by the recent case of Janis Rozkalns, a practising Baptist who, on January 6, 1983, had his house forcibly entered into by K.G.B. agents searching for various religious publications. The K.G.B. confiscated 40 Bibles.
Mr Rozkalns was charged with ''anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda'' and now faces a sentence of seven years deprivation of freedom plus five years internal exile.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled condemns the religious and human rights persecutions within the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Humphreys and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Maher.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Indi respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Forrest respectfully showeth that the Australian Citizenship Act contains provision for the Oath of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors, and an Affirmation of Allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors: That the said Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are supported by the overwhelming majority of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure that the present Oath and Affirmation of Allegiance are retained; and would strongly oppose any attempt to remove all reference to God and the Queen from the Oath of Allegiance, and any attempt to remove all reference to the Queen from the Affirmation of Allegiance.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Health Centre, North Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Canberra shows that
Whereas the Platform on which the Government was elected states that Labor will develop comprehensive community health services
and whereas the citizens of North Canberra have been campaigning since July 1974 for the provision of such comprehensive community health services

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament make provision for the building in the financial year 1984-85 of the second stage of the community health centre for North Canberra to include general practitioner services
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Concord Repatriation Hospital
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors in the Division of Lowe respectfully showeth:

We object to the proposal by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to channel traffic to and from Concord Repatriation Hospital via Currawang Street, Concord West. We object to the proposal because the street has been a quiet cul-de-sac for many years and the nature of the area will be changed through traffic movements and parking problems.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that there be no access to Concord Repatriation Hospital from Currawang Street, Concord West.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned electors of the Division of Ballarat, request that the Australian government:
1. Recognise the a-political nature of the International Committee of the Red Cross in its humanitarian work to people regardless of race, nationality, creed, sex or culture.

2. Recognise the ICRC reports that their activities on the main island of East Timor have been suspended owing to the refusal of the Indonesian authorities to grant their delegates access to all villages requiring assistance.

3. Recognise the breach of the internationally accepted Geneva Convention of 1949, which states that the occupying power ''shall agree to relief actions on behalf of the population and facilitate them by all means at its disposal by authorising in particular the relief activities of the Protecting Power, the neutral state, and the ICRC, or any other humanitarian body''. At present the ICRC is confined to visits to the island of Atauro.

4. Approach the Indonesian Government to give assurances which will allow the ICRC to extend its humanitarian work of distribution of food, provision of medical assistance, and visitation of prisons throughout the whole of East Timor .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Donald Cameron proceeding to give notice of a motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I issued a warning yesterday with regard to the content of notices of motion. I invite the honourable member to resume his seat and reword his notice of motion so that it is within the guidelines.
—For the guidance of all of us, Mr Speaker, do you want us to eliminate any preamble and descriptive material?

—The question allows me to reiterate what I have said before. The honourable member will find that clear guidelines are set out in the House of Representatives Practice. The information supplied must be just sufficient for a definitive substantive motion. The practice of introducing argument has crept into the giving of notices of motion which has meant that they have become overly long. It is not intended that such argument should be in such notices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House applauds the Government's determination to pursue a non- discriminatory immigration program and the priority it has accorded (a) family reunions and (b) acceptance of refugees in that program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes with regret the Prime Minister's inability to report fairly on foreign affairs and trade matters;
(2) expresses its concern that the Prime Minister is unable to discern reality from fantasy;
(3) deplores demonstrations of personal aggrandisement which prejudices national goals and objectives, and
(4) condemns the Prime Minister for making false statements in response to the future of the Australian steel and beef industries. (Notice given 2 May 1984).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes-

(a) the Government's decision to allow publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs to go on sale in the Australian Capital Territory under Category 2 of the A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983, and
(b) that the Prime Minister accused the Member for Moreton of being stupid for expressing concern about the decision and denigrated him on 5 April 1984, and

(2) is of the opinion that by his response, the Prime Minister has shown himself to be a promoter of the use of hard drugs and, despite some of his better qualities, he is an unsuitable person to determine the standards of and to lead this nation.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SPORT, RECREATION AND TOURISM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) that this House notes with regret attempts by the Minister responsible for sport to use the authority and influence of his political position to place unreasonable pressure on sports administrators, and
(2) expresses the view that the Minister should concentrate his energies on those matters which are properly within his ministerial responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) notes the assurances by the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, Datuk Musa Hitam, that Malaysian students abroad, whether private or government sponsored, were free to criticise and, in fact, were encouraged to make constructive criticism of their government, and
(2) congratulates the Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia on his support of, and commitment to, free speech and shares his view that free speech is the cornerstone of all human liberty.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following Bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or requests :
Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1984.
Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984.
Debate resumed from 5 April, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Hodgman had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

(1) its shameful and disgraceful action in seeking to remove Her Majesty The Queen from the oath of allegiance and the affirmation of allegiance, against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians, and without having first put such an important amendment to the people of Australia in a referendum;
(2) its deliberate devaluation of the importance of the honour of Australian citizenship, and
(3) its overall failure to consult properly with the people of Australia before bringing into this Parliament such radical republican legislative proposals'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, debate having been adjourned from 5 April and previous debate having taken place on 2 April. A reading of Hansard of that previous debate shows an unusual viciousness on the part of government. Perhaps that is not so unusual; matters of social legislation are characterised by unnecessary vitriolism on the part of Government. Government members have sought to portray members of the Opposition who sincerely hold strong beliefs on immigration matters as being out of touch with the Australian electorate. I suggest that quite the opposite is true. Members of the Opposition more properly represent the traditional values and views of the overwhelmingly majority of the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I examine more closely the specific measures of the legislation I will say something about the multiculturalism of Australian society. Members of the Government are delving into the realms of the ridiculous if they do not think that members of the Opposition support and encourage in every way possible the great multiculturalism of Australian society. We are proud and very supportive of the changes that have taken place in Australian society since the end of the Second World War. We are proud to have members of the ethnic community on our benches and we are proud to mix with and have friends in the ethnic community. Such communities form a large part of our electorates. Certainly in the electorate of Gippsland there are a great many immigrants of every nationality.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they all vote for you, too.

—They do tend to vote for the National Party, as the honourable member for Gwydir interjects, because they know that their views will be properly represented by the Coalition, which is not dominated by self-serving minorities as in the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking more specifically to the provisions of the Bill, we see that the first thing this amendment Bill does is reduce the qualifying period for Australian citizenship from three years to two years. I expressed concern about that reduction in the qualifying period. I understand that we are the only Western country in the world to have a qualifying period of three years. Certainly to reduce it further is of concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—The reason is that the conferring of citizenship is the greatest honour a country can bestow on an immigrant. Therefore it is of the utmost seriousness and a measure of the greatest respect that a country can bestow on an immigrant. That immigrant in turn must demonstrate a commitment to Australia, its heritage, its traditions, its government and its system of justice. Therefore, to reduce the qualifying period to two years strikes me as watering down to some extent, not totally, that sense of commitment. Thus, I express concern, as have other members of the Opposition.
—Some of the migrants in my electorate are opposed to it. They say it is making it too easy for other migrants to come here.
—Oh, come off it!
—Order! The honourable member for Murray and the honourable member of Melbourne should not have an across-the-chamber conversation. The honourable member for Melbourne will cease interjecting.

—I appreciate your intervention, Mr Speaker, but the honourable member for Murray interjected in a very constructive way which contrasted very markedly with the irrelevant interjections of the honourable member for Melbourne.
—I remind the honourable member for Gippsland that under the Standing Orders all interjections are out of order.

—I am indebted to your guidance, Mr Speaker. The second matter worthy of reference in this Bill is that it will amend the requirement that an applicant for citizenship demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the English language. I suppose we could debate for some time what is meant by an adequate knowledge of the English language. Without delving into the technicalities, I suggest that we all have an understanding of what that means. It means, surely, that an immigrant is able to communicate at the day to day level, to travel throughout the country, to obtain lodgings, food and all of those mundane matters. One would not expect an immigrant, under the definition of 'adequate knowledge', to be able to deliver a speech in this exalted chamber, although I suggest that an adequate knowledge of the English language is not always a criteria for some Government members.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly I suggest that if an immigrant is to assimilate properly and be able to communicate properly with others in his or her new country, proper knowledge of the English language is required, otherwise we run the risk-and no Government member has addressed this-of keeping immigrants apart. Surely it is the bipartisan agreement of this chamber that we should not create ghettoes. I do not mean ghettoes in the sense of those in America, where there is great poverty , but the separation of communities and ethnic groups. That is of great concern. If immigrants are not required to have a proper knowledge of the English language, we do run that risk. I ask any Government member who follows me to address himself or herself to that aspect, because nobody has yet done so. Of course, this Government is not concerned about creating a separation of ethnic minorities because of its divisive and discriminatory treatment of land rights, but I will save that argument for another day.

The third matter which is of great concern in this Bill is the treatment of those of British origin. The present Australian Citizenship Act allows the automatic acquisition of Australian Citizenship by British subjects resident in or with close connection with Australia in 1949, when that Act came into force. That provision has been removed because the Bill provides for the repeal of the definition of British subject status from the Australian Citizenship Act at a date to be proclaimed following further examination. That is of concern because in recent days debate has been conducted in the public forum about whether this Government is placing too great an emphasis on immigrants from Asian countries rather than from Europe and, in particular, the United Kingdom.

Yesterday a very worthwhile contribution to that public debate was made in the Sydney Morning Herald, by Mr Jock Collins who is a senior lecturer at Kuring-Gai College of Advanced Education in New South Wales. In that article Mr Collins set out at length the history of post-war immigration in Australia. He reached no conclusions but was able to set out a number of facts for the public, some of which are of concern and some of which would dispel the irrational arguments of those who argue for greater Asian immigration and those who argue for greater European immigration. I will not dwell on that as I do not believe today is the proper time--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Pommie shop stewards?

—The Pommie shop stewards, as the honourable member for Gwydir has said, have created great concern in Australia. They have been very destructive. The English system will not tolerate the Pommie shop stewards, and unfortunately we have had to cope with them. Not surprisingly, they have found their way largely into the Australian Labor Party, and they are responsible for doing great damage to many aspects of Australian life by their prolonged strikes and their disruptive industrial tactics.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth matter which concerns me and my colleagues in the Opposition, and which is probably the crux of this debate, is the deletion from the oath of allegiance of reference to the Queen of Australia. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who is the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, addressed himself extensively to this aspect of the amendment Bill in his speech of Monday, 2 April. Mr Speaker, let me read for you just what this amendment Bill will set up in place of the traditional oath of allegiance. The new pledge of Australian citizenship will take two forms. The first form-the affirmation-is as follows:

I renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
The alternative form of the pledge-the oath-is:

I renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any State other than Australia. I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

Neither form of citizenship pledge has a reference to the Queen of Australia. Yet the Constitution, the cornerstone of our parliamentary democracy, sets out that the Queen is the constitutional monarch. If we are to delete from the citizenship oath reference to the Queen, I suggest that this Government put to the Australian people an amendment to the Constitution. We would welcome such a referendum because we know there is no doubt that the Australian people would reject out of hand the removal of the Queen as our constitutional monarch. It cannot be surprising that the Government seeks to remove references to the Queen ; after all, the Governor-General is her representative in Australia. We know the bitterness and, quite simply, the hatred that so many members of the Government have towards the Governor-General who, in 1975, properly exercised the powers conferred on him by the Constitution.

What mandate does the Government have to delete reference to the Queen from the citizenship oath, given that the citizenship oath is the most important aspect of a migrant's new life in Australia? It is the symbol of that migrant's acceptance of the traditions, the parliamentary democracy and the system of law and justice in Australia. If reference to the Queen is deleted from that oath, that migrant, that new Australian, is not bound in any way to the protection of the institution of the Queen. Deletion of reference to the Queen from the oath of Allegiance is a further attempt by this Government to move down the road of republicanism. What clearer evidence could come before the Australian people than that by stealth this Government, over a period of time, has become committed to republicanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —A republican dictatorship.

—A republican dictatorship, under the leadership of the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). After all, it is a dictatorship. It is interesting that members of the socialist left are in the chamber. They have been reduced to political irrelevance by the Prime Minister's dictatorship. So, Mr Speaker, it is not surprising that for that reason the socialist left supports the Prime Minister in removing reference to the Queen to allow him at another time to assume the responsibilities and office of the head of a republic.
—What will happen to the flag?
—The honourable member for Lyne asks what will happen to the flag.
—Change it.
—Who said that?
—The honourable member for Macarthur interjected that the Government will change the flag.
—It is out now.

—It is out now, as the honourable member for Murray said, but it is no surprise; it is simply a matter of coming out of the closet. If deletion of reference to the Queen in the oath of allegiance is a sure indication of the Government's commitment to a republic, the alteration of the flag is definite proof. There can be no doubt. That would be conclusive. There is every indication that this Government intends changing the flag. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who sits in the House at the moment, has given a very clear indication that that will be the result.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), on behalf of his electorate, recently wrote to the Minister asking for assurances that the flag will not be changed and that the traditions which we so value in Australia and which are represented by our flag will not be overturned in an arbitrary, dictatorial manner. The reply that the honourable member for Murray received was equivocal, hinting that the Government was looking at altering the flag. The Minister is in the House. If I am misrepresenting him, I invite him to dissociate himself from moves to change the flag. If he does not choose to dissociate himself from such moves, he stands condemned and his proper purposes will be abundantly clear.

Representing rural electorates, my National Party colleagues and I are very aware of the need to maintain traditional values based on a Christian ethic. The people of Gippsland, like other people in National Party electorates, have been over the years the salt of Australia. They are sensible people. They do not believe in change for the sake of change. I have put before the House their view that any alteration of the respect and commitment to the constitutional monarch, the Queen of Australia, and to the flag, the symbol of our nationhood, is absolutely abhorrent. Furthermore, at the risk of stating the obvious, let me impress on the members of the Government what the flag represents. It represents our heritage. It represents the sacrifices that so many Australians have made in lives as well as in toil towards building this country into a great nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. There is no reference to the Australian flag in the Bill being debated.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I well understand the sensitivity of members of the Government in regard to the flag. The suggestion that it be changed is causing more and more disquiet throughout the community. I realise that Government members will attempt to gag such debate, as last night they gagged debate on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2), to prevent anybody from trying to raise such matters. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis) has a particular sensitivity. It was he who interjected no more than five minutes ago that he and members of the Government were committed to altering the flag.
—It was not me.

—The honourable member for Macarthur denies it now. This shows the duplicity of members of the Government on matters such as this. It shows the duplicity of the Prime Minister and of the Special Minister of State. When will the Australian people get a clear and unequivocal statement as to the Government 's intentions?

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I reaffirm my commitment to the multiculturalism of Australia. On a personal note, citizenship ceremonies are amongst the most enjoyable electorate functions I have to attend. They often take place throughout Gippsland and I enjoy those occasions because every person taking the oath portrays a commitment to Australia. We are very proud of that commitment. Certainly, from my discussions with them, they do not want to see a weakening of that commitment. When they take the oath of citizenship they want it to mean something. They do not want it to be based on some false premise. They do not want it to be watered down in any way; they want it to be a clear statement of their commitment to the Australian values, traditions and way of life. This legislation and this Government seriously hamper and weaken that commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would imagine that there would be no need for debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. However, there has been extensive debate over a lengthy period. The sentiments expressed in the Bill are supported by the overwhelming majority of Australians. Certain members of the Opposition, especially those from the more backward parts, have somehow tried to portray this Bill as anti-Australian. Some have even gone so far as to portray the Bill as a socialist ploy to turn Australia into a republic. What utter rubbish!
—What about the flag?

—I will come to the flag. I will deal with the flag later in my speech . Part of my electorate has a large ethnic population. These people welcome the Bill as do the majority of Australians. Unfortunately, those who shout loudest will always find a few people who believe what they say. Our opponents have seized on one clause of the Bill. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) mentioned this. It is always a pleasure to follow him in debate because he usually speaks such utter rubbish that it makes one's own speech, no matter how bad, sound so good. That clause relates to the proposed changes to the oath of allegiance. That is only a minor part of a wide-ranging package of amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act. Among groups in my electorate that have seized on parts of the Bill are, sadly, the Country Women's Association and parts of the Returned Services League.
—Oh, the old bogy men.

—Yes. I assure members of the CWA for whom I have the greatest respect that reference to God will not be taken out of the oath of allegiance. Even the CWA must admit that many people have questioned the appropriateness of the current oath of allegiance.

SPEECH.PARA: Another group that has been rather concerned is the Bowral Senior Citizens Association which, in the period of a month, wrote to me four times on the topic . Each letter received a reply from me pointing out that references to God would remain in the oath for those who so wished but those who did not wish to swear allegiance to God could make an affirmation. The group finally wrote to me saying that it was disgusted. I can only guess why. This Government is not forcing its particular brand of religious belief on the whole population. That is what the Opposition wants us to do. Members of the Opposition talk about democracy. They are trying to force one form of narrow religious belief on the whole of Australia. The days of the Inquisition are over. Opposition members should not try to force their narrow political and religious views on the whole of Australia. I finally suggested to these people that there were more important concerns facing Australia today. From their comments in the local newspaper I do not think they accepted my argument. However, they have not been able to convince me that this is the most important issue facing contemporary Australia. Nor could they convince the unemployed or those pensioners facing hardship that this is the most important issue facing contemporary Australia. The views of the Opposition on this matter show how bankrupt its policies are. It is talking this matter up and trying to make out that it is the most important issue facing Australia.

I turn now to the opposition by the RSL. This is part of a campaign being waged by the RSL in New South Wales about the flag. I raised a point of order during the honourable member for Gippsland's speech-it was overruled-that nowhere in this Bill is the flag mentioned. This is not a Bill about the flag. The flag has not been mentioned anywhere in the Bill. I know that there is debate in the community about the flag. However, this legislation has nothing to do with that. I do not know whether we will have a new flag. I do not particularly care; I am not worried. I do not think it is an important issue. If we decide to have a new flag there will be extensive debate in the community about it, and rightly so. However, I do not think it is the most important issue facing Australia. There are far more important issues.

I sent copies of the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) concerning the Bill to every RSL sub-branch in my electorate. Unfortunately, some deliberately distorted it. Recently I was invited to address a meeting of the south-east region of the RSL sub-branches. At that meeting I outlined again the Government's thinking on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. Even before the meeting, two sub-branches gave to the media details of motions that were to be moved at the meeting. The information in those motions was wrong, and I said so at the meeting. Later I was shocked to read a statement by the Port Kembla RSL Sub-Branch Secretary, one Mr Charles Rose, that the Government's move to alter the oath of allegiance and eliminate references to ' God and Queen' was pandering to people who had come from undemocratic and underdeveloped countries. He went on to make the outrageous claim that if one is against law and order one does not swear allegiance to the Queen. What utter rubbish!

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I get a little tired of the RSL and others, including the honourable member for Denison, who is at the table and is laughing, and the honourable member for Gippsland, who has now left the chamber, trying to impose their narrow definition of loyalty on everyone. Diversity of views is part of the democratic process. The right to live in a democratic society is one of the things, we are told, that members of the RSL fought for. The amendments contained in the Bill follow extensive national consultations during 1982. In relation to the existing oath, the report on those consultations stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The strongly held and predominant view emerging from the consultations was that swearing allegiance to a sovereign, and especially to a named sovereign resident elsewhere, was inappropriate in Australia at its present stage of history.
I share that view. The report continued:
This view was shared by persons from a variety of backgrounds, including holders of imperial awards and persons who maintained that they were not republicans.

One does not have to be a republican to believe the oath should be changed. Despite the advantages of Australian citizenship, over one million people in Australia who are residentially eligible to become citizens have not applied for citizenship. Many such people have made it clear that their reluctance to become citizens results from their unwillingness to swear the oath in its present form. I know that from personal experience. The honourable member for Gippsland talked about some of the migrants, the new settlers, in his electorate; I think I have more in mine. People in my electorate have told me that they will not take out Australian citizenship and swear the oath in its present form. The pledge of allegiance now proposed for new citizens captures the key elements of becoming an Australian citizen. As is now the case, new citizens will be able to choose between a religious and a secular form of pledge to their new nation. The wording of the proposed pledge states:
I renounce any current citizenship, and all allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge-
or 'swear by Almighty God'-
that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

The Government believes this pledge of allegiance is distinctly Australian in character, expressing a clear commitment to Australia, its laws and Constitution , and avoiding what is for many people a confusing requirement to swear allegiance to a sovereign resident elsewhere. While there are legitimate differences of view on the monarchy, they should not be invoked in an Australian citizenship ceremony. The proposals bring everyone together, allowing all of them to make a full commitment of allegiance to Australia.

The argument put by the honourable member for Denison so long ago, on Monday, 2 April, about why people come to Australia is absolute rubbish. One wonders whether he has any contact at all with the communities for which he purports to speak. Why is the honourable member for Denison always prophesying the end of the Hawke socialist Government? One thing of which we can all be sure is that the honourable member for Denison will keep making this prophecy. The other thing that is for sure is that it will not come to pass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Want to bet?
—We will see after the election, will we not?
—When is the election?

—You will be told in good time. In case those opposite think that I am anti-British, nothing could be further from the truth. I must admit that I would not go as far as my colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) when he spoke, and the sentiments he expressed, but I differ from many in the Opposition ; I lived in the United Kingdom for 11 years. I have two university degrees, both from British universities. Few in this House have greater respect or affection for Britain than I have. But, above all, I am Australian, despite my 11 years in the United Kingdom. I want to cast off the colonial cringe that those on the Opposition benches revel in so much.

SPEECH.PARA: Do those opposite really think that this is the most important issue facing Australia today? As I said before, of course it is not. I actually beg those opposite to get out of the 1880s and move in to the 1980s. I ask them to show a little bit of national pride and stop talking this rubbish that they talk in his House. They should be Australian, think Australian and support this Bill. I conclude by paying tribute to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I have the great privilege in this House of representing the people of the Illawarra region, this great ethnic centre, as indeed does the Minister represent his great ethnic centre. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis). I did not realise that he had been to the United Kingdom and obtained two degrees from universities over there. Perhaps that explains his problems. I recall that a year or two ago the honourable member for Macarthur led a mob into Parliament House. He was great in front of the mob which bashed down the front door of Parliament House--
—You are always accusing me of that. It is not true, you know. I was in the mob; I didn't lead them though. I was part of them, but not leader.

—He was very strong in the mob. But this is an important debate. It has been an emotional debate at times, but that is not such a bad thing. But it is important because it goes to the very heart of what this country is all about. The Government seeks to change the nature of citizenship in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) made an excellent speech, as he always does. He made the point that we should recognise the importance of multiculturalism in this country. I have some doubts about that concept although I think we are very fortunate to have in Australia people from all parts of the world. It is great that we have people from all over Europe, from the Indian sub-continent and from Asia. These people coming to Australia have given us a vitality which has enriched the Australian community. But it is important to recognise that we have to understand that people have their different cultures. They have different heritages and backgrounds and they should be able to practise those things within Australia. That is great. But we are one country and there has to be this unity. There should be some diversity, certainly. It would be a terrible place if we all did the same thing. But also there must be a strength and a unity. We must be one nation. It would be a tragedy for this country if we became divided up into a whole lot of quite separate ethnic communities. Let us recognise the heritages and the cultures of these people, and the culture of our Aboriginal people also. Let them practise those cultures and even develop them within Australia, but also let us be one nation together.
The honourable member for Macarthur said that there are people in his electorate who have come to Australia but who will not have a bar of this idea of swearing allegiance to the Queen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—Yes, the honourable member did. He used words to that effect. He said that they would not swear allegiance to the Queen. That is what he intended to say. Why did these people come to Australia? Many people have come here because they thought there would be a better way of life in Australia and a better future for their kids.
—Why did your forebears come to Tasmania?

—They came as free agents. They wanted to come to Australia, like anyone else, to better their lives. People do not come here for a worse existence. They come here because we have a very good standard of living and very high standards of education, health and welfare. These are the sorts of things people have come to Australia for. But when people come to Australia they also have to recognise something of our heritage and history, and the Queen is part of that history. I think we can get carried away with the idea of the monarchy. Let us recognise that we have a constitutional monarchy but the Queen, Her Majesty, does not make the decisions. I think the arrangements are very sound. They have worked very well so far. What is wrong with Australia? Why do honourable members opposite want to change these fundamental things and break down the structures and institutions that have made this country so great? Why do they want to change them as they obviously do? The honourable member for Macarthur did not say that he did not want to change the flag. He avoided that issue.
—The honourable member for Gippsland raised the matter of the flag.

—The honourable member for Macarthur raised it too, and I will reply to him. Members of the Australian Labor Party all around Australia are saying: 'Let us change the flag. Let us have a new flag by 1988.' They have not got the guts to say so in the Parliament. They are using sneaky methods to achieve their aims . The Government pretends to be a government of moderation. It has endeavoured to create an image of moderation but behind this moderation, if one looks into the depths of the Government, one sees that there is a very radical element. Some members of that radical element are in the House at the moment. This issue has dragged them in. They are trying to change a number of things. No one could suggest that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not an avowed republican. He is on the record as saying that he is an avowed republican. A significant number of members on the Government benches are avowed republicans.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Macarthur said that God has not been taken out of the oath. But what has happened to the oath? The word 'oath' has been removed. If the honourable member wants to know what the word 'oath' is all about, he has two university degrees from England and he ought to look up the dictionary, read it carefully and see what the word means. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) does not have the decency-I do not know where he is; he is hiding somewhere-to be in this House. What is he up to? He is following the same line as Al Grassby. He initiated all this in 1973. The same sorts of things were attempted in 1973 and they were knocked out. The word 'oath' has been replaced. I ask honourable members opposite seriously why they have replaced the word 'oath' with the word 'pledge'. What is a pledge? What is the difference between a pledge and an oath? I suggested that the honourable member for Macarthur look at that issue carefully and then he would understand why we are concerned about these moves. There is no doubt that we are moving down the prickly path towards republicanism. The people opposite may want to put this to the test. I note that the Minister has had the decency to come into the chamber at last. I would like him to say whether he is a republican. Does he want to change the flag? He is the man behind this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the honourable member speak through the Chair and not directly to the Minister.

—Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I put those questions to the Minister at the table. Is he a republican? Does he want to change the flag? Is he against the Queen? He is the leader of the left-wing element in the ALP. He is the great leader of the radicals. He is the man behind this Bill. That makes us very suspicious of what is contained in the Bill. The national anthem has been changed. That is very relevant to this Bill. There was no reference to the people of Australia. There was a referendum a few years ago. People were asked what national song they preferred. Three choices were given. I think the choice should have been Waltzing Matilda but the people chose Advance Australia Fair and I accept that decision. They were asked to choose a national song. Is that correct?
—Tune.

—A national tune. I thank the honourable member. He has corrected me. Recently, without any reference to the people, in a very arbitrary way, this Government said that the national anthem will now be Advance Australia Fair. The name of the Crown Solicitor has been changed to the Australian Solicitor. Photographs of the Queen are now being replaced in public buildings around Australia. There is a continuous attack upon Her Majesty, the Monarch of Australia, the Queen of Australia. I do not refer to her as the Queen of England . She is the Queen of Australia. Why is this happening? This is an insidious move down the track towards republicanism and it is about time the people of Australia woke up to what this Government is really all about. We have seen all these radical moves. I will not get on to sex discrimination.
—I would not if I were you, under this Bill.

—I said that I will not. I accept your ruling, Madam Deputy Speaker. We are going down the track toward republicanism. I think the people of Australia should be most concerned about these moves. I ask again: What is wrong with our present institutional arrangements? What is wrong with the Queen? Why are honourable members opposite against the Queen? Has not our system worked very well so far? What are the hangups of honourable members opposite? The Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) said a short time ago: 'Look at President Reagan.' Do honourable members opposite want an American system? Do the left-wingers want a American system with a president? I think this is the aim. There is some evidence of this. The aim is to have by 1988 a new flag, a republic and a president of the Australian Republic. No doubt, the man who has that ambition is Bob Hawke, the present Prime Minister. I think it is arguable that he is now the President of Australia but I will not develop that argument at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the oaths that we have had to this point. I refer to an excellent speech by the shadow spokesman for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). He referred to the existing oath of allegiance. It was brought in by Whitlam and the Labor Government in 1973. It is in the following terms:

I, . . . renouncing all other allegiance, swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.
What could be more Australian than that? It is dinky-di Australian talk. That is a very appropriate oath of allegiance. Of course, a person can make an affirmation in the following terms:

I, . . . renouncing all other allegiance, solemnly and sincerely promise and declare that I will be faithful, and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors, according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

These amendments were brought in by the Hon. E. G. Whitlam, Prime Minister of Australia. I believe those words remain most appropriate. However, as I said before, the Government wants to change this arrangement by requiring people to make a pledge. A pledge might be all right for someone who wants to take himself off drink or something like that, but why is a form of pledge appropriate in this instance? An insidious anti-God approach has been adopted in this legislation. The man behind the legislation, the creator of the legislation with his colleague, Mr Grassby, is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who is at the table. He is the leader of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. We should be suspicious of this legislation because the Minister comes from the left wing of the Labor Party.

I shall put something to the Minister at the table and I want a sincere answer. The Minister made an affirmation when he became a member of this Parliament. Who knows whether he will be a member of the next parliament. When he affirmed his obligations as a Minister he affirmed that he would bear allegiance to the Queen and that he would serve her faithfully. I wonder, as a matter of conscience, whether the Minister would be honest enough to say that he did not give a damn about that affirmation, that he has no allegiance to the Queen and that he has no allegiance--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has lasted longer than you did as a Minister.
—He has not yet. A week is a long time in politics. I was a Minister for three years.
—Order! I invite the honourable member to ignore interjections.

—I am sorry, Madam Deputy Speaker, but I could not refrain from answering that interjection. What do we mean when we make an affirmation or swear an oath? Is it meaningless? Is there some importance in an affirmation? If there is importance in the affirmation and if the Minister meant what he said-I very much doubt it-why does he breach the solemn affirmation he gave and attack the Queen in every way he can? Why does he try to get rid of her from this country and make Australia a republic? That is what he wants to do; that is what it is all about. Perhaps he should come clean and admit now that that is what he wants to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is also concerned with citizenship. How important is citizenship? It is very important for a person who wants to become a citizen of Australia. Such a person is declaring his desire to be part of Australia, to live in Australia and to become a true citizen. He wishes to indicate his true allegiance to the country and what it stands for. Citizenship conveys a sense of belonging. Of course, citizenship carries heavy responsibilities as well. I am disappointed when people who come to Australia and who want the best things that Australia can offer in terms of material gain are not prepared to become citizens of this country. Freedom has been mentioned in this debate and this is a great thing. We are probably freer than any other country in the world. United States of America surveys indicate just how free we are as a nation. People come from strife torn parts of the world to enjoy our freedom, our material wealth and our standard of living. They come to enjoy the good life that we have in Australia. However, according to the honourable member for Macarthur, some of them say: 'But I do not want to be part of this thing called the constitutional monarchy', which has made Australia great. People over a short time have worked to change these fundamental things. These people have had an influence on the Minister.

I think it is tragic that we have downgraded the value of citizenship by reducing the residential period of three years in the previous eight years to two years in the previous five years. A person can reside in Australia for only two years and then become eligible for full citizenship of Australia. In fact, he can be here for two of the past three years. He could be here for two years, fly to some other country and be absent for 12 months and, under this piece of legislation if passed by this House, become an Australian citizen. He will be required to live here for only two years of the previous three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—'Hear, hear' we hear from the left wingers. People can flit into Australia, be here for a short time, nick off again and become full Australian citizens. I think they should have to do more than that. If we look round the world we will see that in many countries people have to be resident for five years, eight years and 10 years. I believe that in some countries they have to be resident for as many as 12 years. But in Australia the period is only two years. I think that this requirement tends to undermine the true value of Australian citizenship. The explanation given by the Minister in his second reading speech is that we are living in a mobile world, that we have to understand that people travel around the world regularly and they should not have to stay here long to be able to qualify for Australian citizenship.
—You have got them thinking, Ray.

—I hope that I have got them thinking. We are all Australians and we should fight for what we believe is right. I believe that we are fighting for good things. I am not an Anglophile like the honourable member for Macarthur, who went to live in England for about 12 years. I have lived in Australia all my life. I did not abandon Australia and try to get a better life in England, as the honourable member for Macarthur did. I can understand where he got his union training. He got it from the Pommie left wing unionists, or was it in Moscow? People should be required to stay here for a reasonable time before they can become full Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a sly way to republicanism. This is what the legislation is all about. It is a step by step move along the path towards republicanism. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) clawed his way to power. He kicked poor old Bill Hayden in the teeth and knocked him down. He crawled over him to satisfy his own ambitions and his real ambition is to become the President of the republic of Australia by 1988. This legislation is designed to help him along the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the Minister wish to make a personal explanation?

—I do indeed. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom), during his remarks, implied that by way of interjection I advocated establishing a situation which would have President Reagan effectively President of this country. What I did do in the course of my remarks was ask honourable gentlemen opposite what they had against President Reagan rather than the situation to which the honourable member alluded. I, of course, have sworn an oath of allegiance to the Queen as Queen of Australia. I was able to swear that oath of allegiance because Gough Whitlam made her Queen of Australia. Prior to that point she was not Queen of Australia. For 71 years persistent periods of Tory government never got around to doing that, though the Tories loyally wish to defend it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to address my remarks to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). I also want to thank the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) for reminding us of the changes that the Whitlam Government made to the status of the Queen in this country. The honourable member for Braddon has asked this House why the Government wants to change the legislation. I wonder whether the honourable member ever reflects on the fact that this country in terms of settlement is less than 200 years old and that this Parliament is less than 100 years old. Because of that we will be changing many things. We are in the middle of constant change. If this country did not change we would not be looking at bringing in people from overseas and we would not be learning and advancing so that this country could change for the better. Of course we are going to be involved in change. This Parliament should be involved in legislative change. There would not be much point in having a parliament if we did not change the legislation, introduce new legislation and rescind other legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address my remarks to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1983 I would like to read briefly from the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West). In that speech he said:

The Government is committed to ensuring that the Act reflects the national identity of all Australians; that it does not discriminate between persons on the basis of their sex, marital status and present or previous nationality; that it provides for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions to deny or deprive persons of citizenship under the Act; and that it is thoroughly Australian in character. The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to those commitments.

I suggest also that the purpose of this Bill is to give effect to these changes. As the honourable member for Braddon should be aware, the Australian Citizenship Act as it exists today did not exist prior to 26 January 1949. In fact, citizenship has changed in status from 1788. We have had a variety of citizens of this nation. In the State of the honourable member for Braddon, as in mine, we have had a different history of settlement. We had free citizens and we had convict citizens. They were not citizens then, but they eventually became citizens. People have come from over 250 nations and settled in this country. The nature of this country changes every five to 10 years. I suggest to honourable members who ask why we want to change this Act that we want to change it to make it fairer and more just and to reflect the current thinking in this country.

Before I address myself to some of the changes in the Bill itself, I comment briefly on some of the statements made by previous speakers, not necessarily during the debate today. As has already been mentioned by some of my colleagues, this debate has now been going on for a month and we have addressed ourselves to it at various times in this chamber. I make some comments about some of the things that have been said here because I think many of us should reflect on some of these remarks and be rather ashamed of them. I might add that such remarks come from the other side of the chamber. We in the Government have spent the greater part of this debate trying to spell out in the clearest possible way what the Citizenship Amendment Bill entails. We have done this because we believe that the Bill is important both to the Parliament and to the people of Australia. One would have thought that the Opposition also would have concentrated on clarifying the various aspects of the Bill which have been discussed in the community. Looking back over the debate, however, I have found that the opposite has been the case.

We have just heard the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), say that Australia will become a banana republic because of this Bill. The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) agreed with him and added that the Government is motivated by resentment of Britain and all things British. I suggest that that is utter nonsense. If the honourable member for Wide Bay thinks that Australia's acknowledgement of its British heritage depends on whether migrants swear an oath of allegiance to the British monarch, I suggest that he is demonstrating a complete lack of understanding about what it means to recognise a cultural, social, economic and political link.

Unfortunately, the honourable member for Wide Bay did not confine himself to giving the House his rather quaint version of Irish history and Anglo-Australian associations. He also gave us his definition of multiculturalism and his views on racial equality. I was truly appalled to hear a member of this House associate himself so unashamedly with such a blatantly racist position. In relation to people discharging the duties of Australian citizenship, the honourable member said that some people lacked the capacity to educate themselves directly on Australian issues. To illustrate his point he chose the Aboriginals, the Australians who have been here for generations, for thousands of years. He said:

They became dependent on others who must make good the inadequacy and, therefore, they are not volunteering an expression of view that is a result of their own reasoning and their understanding. They became simply an echo for the opinions and ambitions of others.
He goes on to make his point absolutely specific:

A particular grouping of Aborigines, with all understanding, have been totally incapable of coming to an honest and objective conclusion about where their best interests lie in regard to voting. They have been totally dependent on best friends or advisers who, in many instances, have had no particular interest in the Aborigines' welfare but certainly have had a keen interest in the result of a ballot. So we create a citizen, and leave him lamentably ill-equipped to cope with the responsibilities he faces as a citizen.

My colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) was moved following that speech to remark on the disgraceful performance by the honourable member for Wide Bay. He hoped that Al Grassby never reads the Hansard report of this debate . I add to that that I hope that no one of Aboriginal descent ever sees the way the Aborigines were referred to in this debate. The offensive attitude displayed in this House by the honourable member for Wide Bay is a blot on this House. I suggest that it reflects some of the minority views at the moment being expressed in the community in an endeavour to whip up an issue. Many politically motivated people in the community who look at this Government today cannot find any other issue than one such as racism on which to attempt to stir up some form of sympathy for their position in the political system.

The honourable member for Wide Bay dared to talk about not undermining the status of Australian citizenship by accepting second and third class citizens. It is not very hard to understand what the honourable member means by a first class citizen. One of his colleagues, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) talked about traditions which had made Australia great. We know some of the traditions of old-style conservatism in Australia, the old divisive ethnocentric traditions that were tearing Australia apart before the people of Australia woke up and threw out the party which even now cannot get over the fact that it was not born to rule. What kind of attitude does the honourable member for Moreton have towards migrants in general? He said:
Many people play it quietly until they get Australian citizenship and then resort to what may be bad habits.
What on earth, I ask, could he mean by that? Many people? Bad habits? This really is the language of bigoted paranoia.

I comment very briefly on the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in which he refers to the 'overwhelming majority of Australians'. I suggest that this is another demonstration of the terrible difficulty the Opposition seems to be having in counting. In my view a small number of people either have failed to acquaint themselves with the actual terms of the Bill before rushing in here yelling about abolishing the Queen-we have heard that again today-or their capacity to understand what it means to acknowledge a rich and diverse heritage is so limited that they are content to base their criticisms on the distorted, alarmist reports which circulate in certain quarters every time a change of any kind is proposed. Let us face it, some people, for their own reasons, cannot admit that Australia is a free and independent multicultural society. To turn this small number into an overwhelming majority is, I suppose, worked out according to some mathematical logic that keeps the Opposition from recognising how little support there is in the community for its outdated attitudes.

I would now like briefly to address myself to some of the proposed changes. This Bill reflects the Government's four basic principles relating to the provision of Australian citizenship. All of us have spent many evenings in our electorates at citizenship ceremonies. We recognise the importance of these ceremonies and the fact that they are held in high esteem by people in the community who are either performing ceremonies for the Minister or who are there to become citizens of this great country. Firstly, the Bill ensures that the Australian Citizenship Act reflects the common national identity of all Australians. Secondly, it removes from the Act discrimination between persons on the basis of sex, marital status and national origin. Thirdly, it provides for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of the Minister to deny or deprive persons of citizenship under the Act. Fourthly, it amends the Act so that it is thoroughly Australian in character.
