In applying these principles to drafting the proposed amendments it became necessary to include measures to eliminate various anomalies, reduce subjectivity in criteria for citizenship, clarify and simplify administrative requirements, and remove redundant provisions. I once again remind the honourable member for Braddon that that is why we are changing the Act.

I now briefly address myself to a rather contentious issue, which seems to generate a lot of antagonism across the chamber, and I refer to the nature of the pledge. During national consultations-initiated, I might add, by the previous Government in 1982-a number of points emerged about what people wanted the pledge to express. I remind the House that there was strong support for a pledge which is distinctly Australian in character, which expresses full commitment to Australia, its laws and Constitution, and which avoids the requirement to swear allegiance to a sovereign resident elsewhere. It may come as some surprise to the Opposition to know that the report of the consultations made it clear that these views were expressed by people from a variety of backgrounds, including holders of imperial awards and people who thought Australia should retain its links with Great Britain. The Bill proposes two forms of pledge. One pledge contains a reference to Almighty God, in recognition of the fact that many people want to swear an oath before God when giving allegiance to Australia as they become a citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—Is the honourable member for Braddon asking which god or which pledge? I suppose it depends on which country these people come from. A Buddhist who came from China might take that up with me and say that he or she does not necessarily believe in a god. A Moslem may come here and wish to take the oath and swear to his or her god and a Hindu to his or her gods. One pledge contains a reference, as I have already said, to Almighty God, in recognition of the fact that many people want to swear an oath before God when giving the allegiance to Australia as they become citizens. Both pledges incorporate the same three basic elements. The first is the renunciation of former allegiance, the second is a commitment to observe the laws of Australia, and the third is a declaration of new allegiance to Australia. I am sure many of my colleagues in this chamber have been to citizenship ceremonies and have seen the numbers of people who affirm at those ceremonies. I suggest that my electorate is very similar to many others in terms of mix of people and their religious or other beliefs, and I find that there are quite substantial numbers of people who do affirm. So I do not see that there will be any problem. There are a number of people in this community who do affirm.
—Three out of ten.

—That is a substantial number, I would suggest. A number of people have made representations objecting to the possible deletion of references to God from the oath of allegiance. Their feelings have been taken into account in drafting the two proposed forms of the pledge of Australian citizenship. Likewise, some people have expressed their concern about the removal of reference to the Queen from the oath of allegiance but, just as the new forms of pledge will allow people to express their full commitment to Australia, whatever their religious beliefs, so neither form differentiates between Australians on the basis of their attitudes to the monarchy. By this change I suggest we have removed the possibility of discrimination in that respect. As the Government has stressed throughout this debate, a citizenship ceremony is not the appropriate forum for a discussion about the relative merits of republicanism and the monarchy.

SPEECH.PARA: I also comment on the change relating to the responsible parent. This Bill removes the present discrimination between men and women by giving equal rights to both parents. Under the present legislation the father is the responsible parent. The mother is the responsible parent only if the father is dead, or the mother has custody, or the child is born out of wedlock. The Bill removes any distinctions between the mother and the father and between children born in or out of wedlock. Instead it defines 'responsible parent' in terms of having guardianship or custody of the child, whether jointly or otherwise. I acknowledge that the Opposition is also pleased with that amendment.

The Bill amends the present requirement that applicants for citizenship have an adequate knowledge of English. The Government believes that, rather than bringing people down because of their lack of English, we should be encouraging them to improve their English. With the new requirement of a basic knowledge, applicants will still have to understand enough English to be able to go through the citizenship ceremony, unless they are over 50 years of age. Even members of the Opposition admit that this latest amendment is a humane proposal.

I congratulate the Minister for his commitment to these changes. Since I have been in this place he has indicated to us, both here and in committee and party meetings that he is totally committed to changing the Act and introducing this Bill, and I commend him for that. I wish not only to congratulate him but also the Government for the changes. I have to say that I have been horrified and at times disgusted by some of the racist comments from the other side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time after time this Government claims that it is a government of reform. It claims it is healing the divisiveness within our community. What humbug and hypocrisy that is. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) opened his speech on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill by saying that the Bill is 'thoroughly Australian in character'. Obviously the Minister has a different understanding of what is Australian. Perhaps it is from a socialist left factional perspective that the Minister believes it is Australian to pillage the rightful role of the Queen of Australia . Perhaps from his myopic Labor view it is considered Australian to downgrade the Queen, God, our language and our democratic system based on the Westminster principles.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a well planned move towards dragooning Australians into republicanism. Members on the opposite side may scoff, but let us not forget the comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's world today program as recently as 26 January 1984. He said:
I believe that this--
that is republicanism--
is something that ought to and will happen.

The Prime Minister has merely converted the immature 'little Australian' nationalism of earlier decades into an artificial ocker nationalism of the 1980s . I can happily and confidently tell this House that the people do not want a republic and will not accommodate the Prime Minister's ambition to be President. The people do not want the changes proposed in this Bill to the oath of allegiance, as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has resolutely told this House time and again. I know this from the reaction within my electorate and the gallup polls, and the hilarity which has greeted the offer of a portrait of the Prime Minister to Commonwealth departments and units of the defence forces.

Australia has a proud history as a constitutional monarchy. It joins the ranks of many other such countries, all of which have stable governments and are democracies that are an example to new emerging nations. Let me remind the House that the real significance of a monarch is in the power the monarchy denies to others and not so much in the limited power the monarch has. It is a safeguard that has worked well throughout our history. The Queen of Australia is recognised by all residents in this country. It is malicious to suggest that new settlers are confused by the role the Queen plays. Even if one accepted an argument that initially some new settlers are unsure of the role of the Queen of Australia then surely they should become aware of that role before they seek Australian citizenship.

I remind this House that citizenship should be seen as a privilege and an honour, and not be demeaned to the level of a driving licence. Citizenship places certain rights on the individual but also demands certain duties in return. I will come to that later. Yet the Minister proposes in this Bill to do away with any reference to the Queen. I note that he did not have the courage to eliminate God. Is that because in the gallup polls God still outrates the Prime Minister? If I recollect correctly, the Prime Minister is well behind God in the gallup polls.

This Bill proposes to abolish the oath and replace it with a 'pledge'. What does the Minister mean by a pledge? To whom is this pledge made? Mr Deputy Speaker, let me read the proposed 'pledge'. It says:

I renounce any current citizenship and allegiance to any state other than Australia. I pledge that I faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

This is foreign to Australians. Perhaps the Minister has been watching too many American television shows. As I said earlier, the Minister has purposely eliminated any reference to God. I agree that a new citizen will be able to specially request the so-called pledge with reference to God, but again I ask why this change is necessary. There has always been a provision for those people who wish to make an affirmation. To do so, why is it now necessary, by legislation, to place the onus on the new citizen to have to make a request for an oath to God? I remind the Minister that again he is out of touch with the community. In the last census an overwhelming percentage of the population identified themselves with a religious denomination believing in a god, Christian or otherwise. Why has the Government decided to ignore the majority? Why is there such a manical desire to abolish, to tear down, the values that are dear to so many Australians? What will be next to go-the national flag?
This obsessional desire to water down the basis of our heritage is continued by the proposed changes in English language requirements. Again there is no logic in the Bill. The Minister says:
Knowledge of English is essential to full participation in Australia's social, cultural and political life . . .

I agree with what the Minister says. But then the Minister continues and says that the Government does not wish to deny citizenship to those with limited English. Then, a few words later, the Minister says:
. . . applicants for citizenship must have only a basic knowledge of English.

What does the Minister mean by his words 'limited English', 'basic English' and 'knowledge of English'? It is my understanding that the English language requirement has been conversational ability. Does the Minister propose to lower the standard already set by the previous Government? If that is the intention of this Government, the Opposition is totally opposed to such moves.

I said earlier that citizenship not only provides certain privileges but also demands certain responsibilities from a citizen. One of the responsibilities is jury service. It is the obligation of every Australian citizen to serve on a jury when required to do so. If we lower the language criteria we are making a mockery of the jury system-but perhaps this Government plans to abolish that institution of our lifestyle, too. How can citizens who have a very limited knowledge of the English language fulfil this duty? Does the Minister propose to establish two classes of citizens-English speaking and non-English speaking? Let me also refer to the question of exercising one's constitutional rights of voting. A lowering of the English language requirements will contribute little to encouraging the casting of a valid and thought out vote.

I cannot fathom the purpose of this move. It is especially difficult to understand when we find that the number of applicants meeting current standards is increasing. I cannot understand, when 1.2 million residents meet citizenship requirements and do not wish citizenship, why a lowering of requirements is needed to attract these people. They have made their choice not to seek citizenship. Why should we either try to buy their interest by lowering standards or entice them in some other way? Again the Minister aims to demean the status of citizenship as an integral part of our heritage.

I now turn to a very serious matter that will emanate as a result of this Bill. The Minister, in his headlong rush to attract more people, proposes to reduce the residence eligibility period from three years to two years. He says one reason is 'increased international mobility'. For once the Minister is right but has he considered the security aspects emanating from the increased mobility? Australia, like most other countries, faces the ever-increasing dangers of terrorism and drug trafficking. In such a climate security checks are most important. One need only talk to members of the forces protecting this country to realise how difficult this increasing mobility makes establishing proper and accurate security checks. One need only read the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking to realise the importance of passports and citizenship to the international drug trader. Yet in the face of all that the Minister proposes to relax the continuous residence requirement from the 12 months immediately preceding the application to 12 months residence in the previous two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aggregate.

—Correct. Again the Minister has exhibited his desperation to attract new citizens to Australia at any cost. I again emphasise that citizenship is not a right that can be automatically acquired. It is a privilege and an honour and I know from my own experiences at citizenship ceremonies and in dealing with ethnic groups that our new citizens see Australian citizenship in that light.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill does nothing to enhance citizenship. This Bill has not been thought out clearly and fully and, more importantly, it is being used as a veil over this Government's intentions to force Australia to become a republic. I sincerely hope that in that institution of considerable Australian history and heritage, the Australian Senate, wiser counsel prevails and appropriate action is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I go back to a couple of comments made by previous speakers. The content of the debate so far on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill has been a judicious mixture of analysis of the existing provisions of the Australian Citizenship Act and also a lot of hyperbole. That is to be expected, having regard to the history of inactivity of those on the other side of the House. We have heard a lot about the new national anthem and proposals about a new flag for Australia, but we have heard very little from the other side about what the Bill comprises.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to a couple of comments relating to the new national anthem that are deserving of some further attention. A poll recently taken in Queensland indicated that some 84 per cent of those polled actually supported Advance Australia Fair as the new national anthem. In the next few months that may be cause for some reflection on the part of the Queensland Premier who, I think, assumes that there is widespread support for the old anthem. I certainly do not think that is the case. The poll tends to confirm that is indicative of the lack of touch of the coalition parties not only on this issue but also on a whole range of other issues. I think they ought to give some consideration to leaving behind views that are firmly entrenched in years gone by and have a review of what they are about.

The coalition parties apply the same sort of argument to the issue of the Australian flag. Let me say that I am on record as indicating my view that it is premature to think about changing the flag. Nevertheless, a flag is simply a material representation, if you like, of what Australia is all about. If at some stage in the future the Australian people take the view that the flag in its existing style no longer reflects adequately what they believe Australia is all about, no doubt at some stage in the future the flag will be changed, as flags have been changed in many countries during their history. I reiterate that my view is that it is premature to go down that road at this time, but certainly the public debate engendered on this subject is to be encouraged.

The Australian Citizenship Act did not exist prior to 1949. Many speakers, in the comments they have made here today, have assumed that there has been some long history of people having a fixed attitude to the requirements of Australian citizenship. That is simply incorrect. Australian citizenship was allowed to British subjects and also to Australian residents but we also had another ugly category of 'aliens'. It seems to me that the perception of that category has really continued as an implicit part of what some members of the Opposition parties have put to us today. The attitude to those aliens-we call them ethnic Australians or Australians of ethnic origin-seems to be something that is implicit in a whole range of policy areas and I think the history of the attitude of the coalition parties which are now in Opposition is such that it really cannot be held up in this House as being one of care for ethnic Australians. The subject of the treatment of Aboriginals was raised here earlier by my colleague from Tasmania the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). I hope he has dissociated himself from the current activities of the Tasmanian Government with respect to the burial of Aboriginal remains.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not up with the latest.
—Nevertheless, your Government put a position and I did not hear you dissociate yourself from it.
—Things have changed.
—Things have changed, but that reflects no credit upon you or your colleagues from Tasmania.
—You would be surprised. You should deal with the facts.
—You raised the issue. We also have the shameful treatment--
—Order! I ask the honourable member to direct his comments through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In Queensland we also had the shameful treatment of Senator Bonner. I refer to the dumping of the only Aboriginal representative in the Federal Parliament. Again, the honourable member opposite raised the issue. I could go on, but I shall not. I will return to the contents of the Citizenship Act. In this debate the honourable member for Braddon also talked about people raising the flag. My only comment is that the honourable member for Braddon has raised the flag-the flag of surrender. He is mindful of what will happen to a party which is absolutely out of touch with the aspirations of the Australian electorate and he has now announced his resignation.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark, because the honourable member for Braddon, one of the finest members that this House has ever had, is resigning from Parliament for family reasons. I ask the honourable member to withdraw that statement because if he does not he will face a concerted attack from here on.
—Order! The honourable member will not debate that point.
—The Labor Government has taken a range of initiatives to encourage --
—Are you going to withdraw?

—With respect to the Deputy Speaker, I have not been asked to withdraw. I shall but the point was worthy of being made. The Labor Government has taken a whole range of initiatives which I think will go some considerable way towards encouraging the 1.2 million people currently residing in Australia who have lived here for more than the existing three-year period required under the current Act and who have yet to take out citizenship to do so. This range of initiatives will help such people to see themselves as part of the Australian community and will go a considerable way towards encouraging them to take out Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: The theme of the Government's involvement in these areas is to break the common nexus between ethnicity and disadvantage. It is a common theme but it had not really been addressed by governments in the post-war period until perhaps the beginning of the 1970s. Certainly, in the short months since March 1983, this Government has taken a number of initiatives to assist ethnic Australians. These initiatives have had a significant impact on the views of people as to whether they ought to participate more fully in our democratic process, and it is a common theme. I represent the electorate of Maribyrnong. It is an electorate which comprises very large numbers of people of ethnic background. A common theme that I have heard in discussions with my constituents is a view that things are happening. It may be that because my seat is part of the western region of Melbourne, an area that hitherto has been relatively neglected by a number of governments, my constituents have a greater perception of government involvement in areas that assist them directly. Through that perception they may come to the conclusion that they want to participate because they are being given a fair go. They are being treated as Australians are on other sides of Melbourne.

Let me give the House a few examples of areas of government involvement which I know have encouraged people to come to my office and inquire about taking out Australian citizenship. For example, in the western region of Melbourne the adult migration education program has had a major impact on people's perception of their standing in our community. They believe that progam is giving them a fair go and it is encouraging them to take out Australian citizenship. Expenditure for this program has increased by 14 per cent in the last year and there are provisions for a significant increase in the number of permanent teachers in that area of education. Another example of the Government's initiatives is the development of a new materials and syllabus centre to increase the effectiveness of English language teaching through better professional support. This goes to the very issues raised by the honourable member for Braddon in regard to the basic English requirements. Funds have been allocated to expand and improve occupational English classes for migrants in the work place. Again, this is a significant step towards addressing the very issues raised by my colleague.

Priority will be given to needy schools under the Commonwealth education programs. These schools, of course, contain a disproportionately large number of ethnic children and such schools are substantially represented in electorates such as mine. The participation and equity program is designed to improve the number of children completing full secondary education either in school or in the area of technical and further education. I refer also to the review by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs of post arrival programs. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts is conducting an inquiry into a national language policy. Of course, we await with some interest the results of that inquiry.

Another Labor Government initiative is the develpment of a National Advisory and Co-ordinating Committee on Multicultural Education to advise the Government on the cultural resources available and the changes needed to the education system so that it better reflects the ethnic composition of the Australian community and provides for equality. The Sex Discrimination Act, adverted to by a number of previous speakers, will provide redress for migrant women who suffer discrimination in employment, housing and access to services, or who suffer from sexual harassment in the work place. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill of course, also encompasses anti-discrimination provisions and is an added incentive for the ethnic communities to participate by taking out citizenship.

A migrant women's desk has been established in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. That is, hitherto, an area which has been relatively neglected by that Department. Provision has been made for substantial funding for child care facilities in association with English language classes to help ensure that migrant women are able to attend those classes. It is, of course, of the utmost stupidity to provide resources that people cannot utilise because of their own particular circumstances. Funding has been provided for the women's emergency services program to employ ethnic workers in women's refuges. This provision, while not affecting a wide range of people, has had a significant impact in my area. Migrant women, because of their cultural backgrounds, are often in a more vulnerable position than Australian women. Initiatives like this go a long way towards encouraging migrant women to see themselves as full members of the Australian community.

Migrant women are now represented in the Government's new arrangements for consultation with women's organisations and interest groups. That area, again, has been relatively neglected in the past. I see my colleague, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) nodding his head in agreement. I thank him for that. An immigration policy was introduced in 1973 that does not discriminate between nationality, race or creed. Of course, that was an initiative of the Whitlam Government. The thrust of that policy I must say, in all fairness, was essentially maintained in terms of the current Bill. Of course, we took into account the policy review which was initiated by the now Opposition parties, if my memory serves me correctly, in about June 1983. That review was a significant acknowledgement by the now Opposition that there needed to be change in the context of the Australian Citizenship Act. Of course, we ensured that our own policy commitments have been reflected in the Act in its final form. No one would expect us to do otherwise.

I shall not go through, ad infinitum, initiatives that the Government has taken in respect of ethnic communities. I believe, as I have already indicated, that those initiatives are an integral part of encouraging ethnic individuals or people with ethnic backgrounds to take the step to become Australian citizens. As has been previously indicated, that step should be accorded the utmost respect by anyone taking it because of its important and sensitive nature. However, there are a number of things that I would like to comment on that have only been touched on in passing. The qualifying period for citizenship has now been reduced from three years to two years. I think that is a fundamentally important decision. I have always felt that a real step towards becoming an Australian citizen is the decision to come to Australia and to make Australia one's home. I think that a period of two years, if the applicants accord with the other eligibility requirements, should suffice. However, a particularly important provision of the Bill is the section that allows for appeals on a number of grounds to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. In the past there has always been a sneaking suspicion in some immigration cases that political clout is a more important criterion than merit for people seeking a change in their citizenship status either by applying for Australian citizenship or to matters such as deportation or deprivation of Australian citizenship. I think the Government has taken an important step in that regard. It reflects well on the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) that, in future, those sorts of decisions will be placed before a proper judicial tribunal and will not be subject to the executive whim of a Minister who may or may not be influenced by criteria other than those of the merits of the case.

I have already adverted to the initiatives taken by this Government to improve knowledge of the English language by all new Australians of ethnic backgrounds. Recently a detailed study was conducted in the western region of Melbourne. It showed that a lack of knowledge of English was a significant impediment to young Australians of ethnic backgrounds getting employment even though they had been born in Australia. So, for goodness sake, how we could demand that people, for example, over the age of 50 who have only been here for five years should have a knowledge of English that exceeds that of young Australian born people in their mid-20s is beyond me. I think it is an unjustified demand and, in terms of the number of Australians who have not taken out citizenship, certainly a demand that demonstrably, has not been able to be met by a whole range of people who would consider it a very high honour to take out Australian citizenship.

The Bill amends the requirement that an applicant for citizenship should demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the English language. Of course, that excites some passion in people who take that provision at face value and who do not go on to read the other qualifications. For goodness sake, I think that if there was a harsh enough judge had the Queensland Premier arrived from New Zealand today rather than some years ago he would not pass that test. A knowledge of the English language is essential to full participation in the Australian social, cultural and political life. However, the Government does not wish to deny citizenship to those with limited English who have lived in Australia for some time and who would take pride in becoming Australian citizens .

The Bill proposes that applicants for citizenship must have only a basic knowledge of English. Applicants over 50 years of age will be exempt from the new requirement of a knowledge of basic English recognising the difficulty that many older people have in learning a new language. Everywhere I go in my electorate I talk to older members of the various ethnic communities. They are no less a people than other Australians. In my view they have equal rights. Indeed, many of them, in my subjective view, would make better citizens of this country than many of those who were born with that right. For example, only recently I spoke to the Chief Commissioner of the Victoria Police, Mr Miller. We were talking about the ethnic group which had invited us to a Returned Services League function, of all things. The RSL sub-branch comprised solely Italian returned soldiers. In talking about that community we recalled a number of interesting statistics. The Italian community has the highest rate of home ownership in Australia. It has one of the lowest rates of criminality of any group in Australia and because members of that group happen to be over 50 and have a lack of understanding of English I do not think we should preclude them from becoming Australian citizens. I am mindful that my time is running out. I thank the House for its indulgence and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When introducing the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill into the House, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is the outcome of the most extensive review of the Citizenship Act since it was passed by Parliament in 1948 under the Chifley Labor Government.

There is no doubt that this is a most extensive review and change to the Australian Citizenship Act. That is beyond question. However, I question the reasons why there has to be such an extensive change to the Citizenship Act. There is no question that any legislation of this Parliament or any other parliament needs to be constantly reviewed to ensure that it is still appropriate to the Australian community. But why are these extensive changes being made at this time? During their contributions to this debate, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) suggested that this Bill is part of a much wider plan by the present Government to turn Australia into a republic. I suggest that the honourable member for Braddon and the honourable member for Gippsland were quite correct in their observations. When we debate the Bill I believe we need to look beyond its parameters to find the direction in which this Government is taking Australia. I believe the Bill represents one part of a much more extensive master plan to break down the very social fabric of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—My colleague the honourable member for La Trobe, who is a member of the socialist left in Victoria, suggests that that is nonsense. Perhaps I will inform him of a few other facts as I go along in my contribution. There is no doubt that Australia has an Anglo-Saxon background. That is our heritage and our history. That is the very origin of this country and its social fabric. What this Government is about is a very purposeful attempt to break down the Anglo- Saxon origins, traditions and history that have surrounded and built this country into what it is today. I do not believe the Government alone is the perpetrator of this master plan. I believe it is the innocent fool, if I can put it that way, which is being led by others of a more sinister nature. For the benefit of the Minister and the House I will quote from a book entitled Red Over Black, written by an Aboriginal named Geoff McDonald. Perhaps I should inform the House of Mr McDonald's background. For 20 years he was a member of the Communist Party of Australia. He was trained by the Communist Party at its special training camp in Minto New South Wales to be a communist activator within particular organisations in this country. After 20 years in the Communist Party Mr McDonald realised the error of his ways and decided that, for the sake of Australia, he should expose what was happening within the Communist Party and how its activists were operating in various organisations. I quote from Mr McDonald's book:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the history of this century has demonstrated time and time again how Communists have been sucesssful in adopting Lenin's famous teaching of exploiting those whom he described as ''useful idiots''. During my own days in the Communist movement I learned how relatively easy it is for Communists to exploit the idealism and misguided views of non-Communists. Many politicians are , unfortunately, just as easy to mislead as others. The steady global Communist advance over the past sixty years has been achieved primarily by Communists exploiting gullible and mis-informed people.

Mr McDonald makes it perfectly clear that the Communist Party considers that there are 'useful idiots' in this community. He also makes the point that members of parliament are just as easily exploited, just as much useful idiots, as people who might be involved in various organisations in the community within either the academic world or other spheres of influence. I believe those communist activists are treating the Parliament and members of the Australian Labor Party as 'useful idiots' in bringing this Bill into the House, and also in some of the other actions that are being taken by the Government, to undermine the social fabric of Australia. There is no question that the best way to undermine the economy and the social fabric of Australia is to distort our history and origins and the things we hold dear which we can pass on to successive generations. Mr McDonald earlier in his book stated:
. . . the issue is largely one of the need for a society to be homogeneous if it is to be stable.

If one accepts that theory then obviously, by distorting the homogeneous structure of our society, one has the very basis of making a society unstable. I believe that in part, that is what the Bill is all about. It is not an attempt to bring nationalism to Australia. It is an attempt by communist activists to undermine and distort the social fabric of Australia. They are using the Government and members of the Labor Party as useful idiots in achieving that objective.

Part of the Bill's function is to change the oath of allegiance, to take the word 'God' out of the oath of allegiance. Who in this place would suggest that Australia is not a Christian country? Who would suggest that? My friends on the other side of the chamber are notable by their silence. Who would suggest that Australia is not a Christian country? Who would deny people who are Christians the right to make their oath in the name of God? That is what this Government is doing. It is taking away the right of people who come to this country to pursue their Christian belief by swearing an oath to God. At the moment the Act provides that people of various religious backgrounds can make an oath in the name of God or an affirmation, if that is their wish. But by taking the word ' God' out of the oath of allegiance we are giving those people a choice of making an affirmation or an affirmation. There is no choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The honourable member is misleading the House insofar as he is indicating that the Bill does not provide for swearing to God. I refer to the second alternative: 'I swear by Almighty God that I will faithfully uphold . . .'. The honourable member is misleading the House.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Maribyrnong is debating the issue.

—I go further in outlining what the Government is trying to do in changing the social fabric of Australia, and these matters were referred to by my colleagues in their contributions. I impress on the House that we need to look at the Bill in the context of what is taking place by action of the Government. For instance, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) used his autocratic decision-making powers to tell Australia that it had a new national anthem. Even Mr Whitlam, in his halcyon days, did not attempt to do that. At least he had the courtesy to Australia to conduct a referendum. But not the present Prime Minister. He did not even show that courtesy to the people of Australia. He simply informed them, by way of a Press release, that suddenly we had a new national anthem. I would have thought that, if the symbols of Australia are to be changed, at least the Australian people should have some say in how those symbols are to be changed or whether they should be changed. That was not the case with the present Prime Minister. He decided that he knew better than the people of Australia and told us that we had a new national anthem.

SPEECH.PARA: We understand also that plans are afoot to change the style of the Australian flag. I ask why the Government should be considering changing the Australian flag. It is the flag under which this country was brought together in 1901. It is the flag that has held this country together since that time. Yet these people want to change the flag and the symbols that have held this country together. I believe there is a purposeful attempt to break down and distort the very social fabric that has held this country together since its formation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want the hammer and sickle.

—I believe my colleague the honourable member for Denison is right; they want the hammer and sickle. On the first sitting day of this Parliament we were reminded by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) that we on this side of the chamber do not have the numbers to do anything. Government members believe that, because they have the numbers, they have the right to change Australia. But why did they not take this to the people as part of their manifesto and see if they could get a mandate to change Australia? Why did they not tell people before the last election that they wanted to change the flag? Why did they not tell people that they wanted to change the oath of allegiance? Why did they not tell people that they wanted to open the doors of Australia for a flood of Asian immigration ? No, they did not mention any of these things. But now it is being exposed that this is what they are on about. This is what the Government is doing and all we on this side of the House can do is to try to expose its actions to the people of Australia to allow them to make a judgment whenever the Government dares to go to the polls on the next occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that what we are witnessing at the moment is a sinister program to undermine completely the social fabric of Australia, to change the very nature of this country, to move away from our Anglo-Saxon background, to remove any history that has held this country together and, in part, to turn it into a country that will be nothing resembling the country we have known in the past. This will be terribly disruptive. I believe it is part of the communist plan to help to bring Marxism into this country. Unless the people of Australia are alerted to what this Government is about, it could very well be successful. I do not claim that I have the numbers over here to stop the Government but what we have got are voices to warn people of what the Government is about.

This is not just a Bill to change the Citizenship Act. It is far more sinister than taking God out of the oath of allegiance It is a program to break down Australia. I can assure Government members that, while they might consider themselves to be useful idiots who can be used by communists, there is not one honourable member on this side of the House who is a useful idiot. We will not allow ourselves to be used by communists in the way those people have been used. Nor will we allow this sort of thing to be done that will undermine Australia. We will not allow the Government to get away with it without our at least forewarning the people of what the Government is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was amazed to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) who has just sat down. I cannot help feeling that somebody else must have written his speech for him because it is quite out of character for him to charge that the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1983, which is before the House, has resulted from the work of communists and people working against a Christian society. These comments represent communist bashing of the worst kind. It was a most uncharacteristic outburst of nonsense and we can see from the comments he has made who the idiots are in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As an English migrant who has been resident in Australia for 23 years, it gives me a particular pleasure, and indeed a pride, to be a member of a Labor Federal Government which is introducing mush needed amendments to the 1948 Citizenship Act. The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1983 reflects the multicultural nature of today's Australian society and has my overwhelming support. In February 1961 when my wife Joyce and I, with our three children, Stephen, Ivan and Janet, emigrated from England to Australia we had the good fortune to be supported by the assisted migrant program. For the total sum of #20 or $40 we were able to travel from London to Melbourne on the Fair Sky of the Sitmar Line- -

TALK.START.PARA: —We got good value. You are a great member.

—I thank the honourable member. This ship was manned mainly by Italian sailors, who were particularly kind to the hundreds of young British children aboard, and was captained by an Argentinian. I think it was a good bargain and obviously the electors of La Trobe, having put me in this place to represent them on two occasions so far, believe that the $40 was cheap at the price. In fact there are a number of distinguished members on this side of the House who ware also born overseas and who have made some very valuable contributions in debates in this House. Judging from some of the ribald comments from members on the opposite side of the House when I first joined the Parliament in October 1980, they had other ideas.
—They didn't like your English accent.

—I will say something about that in a moment. I notice that there have been comments in the media about whether the term 'Pom' is offensive. I understand that the acronym 'Pom' stands for Prisoner of Mother England and in that sense it certainly is not offensive because many of those early migrants from England were convicts because they had rebelled against a system of harsh and exploitative oppression. Of course, it really depends on the tone of the voice whether being called a 'Pom' is offensive or friendly.

SPEECH.PARA: There was no doubt of the intention of members of the Opposition when they jeered at my accent. They also jeered at my honourable friends and colleagues the honourable members for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). The intention of honourable members opposite was to mock us because we had distinct overseas accents. Even the honourable member for Burke ( Dr Theophanous) was mocked, not because he had a foreign accent but because he had a Greek name. This latent and sometimes blatant racism is a hallmark of some members of the Opposition and that is why they are maliciously and irresponsibly attacking the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) on the implementation of what previously has been seen as a bipartisan immigration policy.

I was most surprised to read in the newspapers and listen on the radio to the comments of Professor Geoffrey Blainey on Asian immigration. I was surprised to find that a man who was a one-time colleague of mine at the University of Melbourne, and whom I know to be a man of humane disposition, cannot see that his remarks are inflaming the latent racism of a minority of ignorant and insecure Australians. Professor Blainey has stated quite correctly that in 1983, 40 per cent of our migrant places were filled by Asians. However, what he fails to say is that the present immigration policy is based on humanitarian principles of which genuine refugee status and family reunion are essential ingredients. As the Minister has explained, one of the main reasons for the high percentage of migrants from Asia in 1983 was that other migrant groups were not taking advantage of the family reunion program.

Another reason which I will come to later arises from the large influx of refugees from Vietnam and Kampuchea, many of whom came to Australia as economic refugees and were given easy admittance to Australia by the previous Government. In a period of eight years the Fraser Government was responsible for some 78,000 Indo-Chinese refugees settling in Australia. The greater majority of the refugees were from Vietnam, with about one-fifth from Kampuchea and Laos.

To say the least, I am appalled at the standard of debate which has been raging in the media about the so-called Asianisation of Australia. Surely we are not going back to the dark days of 1901 when Australians were told by a writer in the Bulletin that the Anglo-Saxon must be preserved in his pure state if he was to retain his position as the best and most intellectual on earth. Apart from anything else, it is ridiculous and ignorant to lump all Asian nationalities together in a campaign which advodates a return to what amounts to a white Australia policy with discrimination against family reunion and refugee status for prospective migrants from our neighbour Asian countries. Sri Lankans, Thais, Malaysians, Vietnamese, Indonesians, Filipinos and Chinese, to name a few of the Asian nationalities involved, are as diverse in colour, culture and racial characteristics as it is possible for the human race to be.

It seems that what the critics of our immigration policy are saying is that, because in the last half of 1983, 40 per cent of total sponsorships under the family reunion program was from Asia, we should discriminate against such applicants. In practical terms this means that one has to say to perhaps a Sri Lankan, who is probably a Tamil and whose family is suffering the racial violence that is going on in that country at this very time: 'No, I am sorry, your brother cannot migrate to Australia because there are too many of your people taking advantage of our migration program'. Is that what the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Denison ( Mr Hodgman), who is at the table, wants us to say? If any honourable members of this House have had to sit and listen to these applicants and the human anguish which such a restriction would cause, they would change their minds. If some of the critics could actually become involved and could hear the kinds of human problems that are encountered by these people and the reasons they want their family here, they would change their minds.

As a result of the necessity for refugees to flee their country of birth because of religious and political persecution it is essential that we maintain our refugee program. The Fraser Government's refugee program had many defects which are not present in the programs of the present Government. One particular defect was its failure to screen properly the Vietnamese boat people, many of whom landed illegally on Australia's northern shores. A small proportion of these people were thugs and extortionists who had learned their trade in the back streets of Saigon. In contrast to the humanitarian policies of the present Government, honourable members opposite would choose to allow the entry of these criminal types.

The majority of Vietnamese are law-abiding people but I experienced at first hand the menacing behaviour at the hands of these thugs when I attended an anniversary commemoration of the ending of the Vietnam war. I was also involved in helping an Australian, a German migrant, who almost lost his life in the Eastbridge ex-migrant hostel as a result of a machete attack by three men of Vietnamese origin. Local police have been unsuccessful in preferring charges because although one of the assailants was known, the many Vietnamese who witnessed the attack were too frightened to give evidence to the police. The Opposition stands condemned for allowing such people to enter Australia. However , let me make it clear that I consider that media reports which attempt to brand all refugees as latent terrorists are, in my view, slanderous and irresponsible. I want to highlight the fact that the present attitude of the Opposition, which when in government allowed people with criminal backgrounds to enter Australia, is hypocritical in the extreme.

I turn now to Schedule 1 of the new Bill, the pledge of Australian citizenship, which replaces the pledge contained in Schedule 2 of the principal Act. Opposition members, particularly the honourable member for Denison, have been almost hysterical in their condemnation of the proposed change. In the earlier debate some four weeks ago the honourable memer for Moreton accused the honourable member for Lowe of being a humbug and he also made other slanderous comments which he was forced to withdraw. Why did the honourable member for Moreton become so excited? It was because the honourabe member for Lowe referred to the fact that United Kingdom nationals resented, for a variety of reasons, making an oath of allegiance to the Queen. In fact, the honourable member for Lowe was correct. I was one of those United Kingdom nationals who considered it meaningless, as a national of the United Kingdom and an ex-member of the Royal Air Force, to take such an oath. In due course I and my wife both took advantage of the opportunities given by the Whitlam Labor Government to United Kingdom nationals to take up Austraian citizenship without formality in 1974. I can also well understand the resistance of nationals from other royalist countries or from republics to swear allegiance to an English Queen. It is time members opposite realised that we are now close to the twenty-first century and not still in the artistocratic era of the nineteenth century. Similar to their Herbert Spencerian philosophy their ideas on royalty, so obsequiously expressed by the honourable member for Denison, are 150 years out of date.

Another important amendment is proposed new section 13 which has been substituted for the old section in the principal Act which, amongst other things , reduces the minimum period of residence from three years to two years before a certificate of citizenship can be granted. I applaud this amendment as there is no doubt that two years is quite long enough to establish a relationship with Australia which is deserving of citizenship status. In my own case I experienced a graphic realisation that I had adopted Australia as my permanent home when the 1961 Australia versus England test match was being played. As a Pom I was constantly ribbed when the Australians were winning but when I had to admit to myself that secretly I wanted the Australian team to win I realised that I had well and truly adopted Australia as my country. This was despite the fact that around that time when I was out shopping a shop assistant on the Myer store ground floor sent me up to the horticultural section on the top floor after I had asked where I could buy some light bulbs. Of course, I should have referred to globes.

I was also involved in another embarrassing incident in the Collins Street accountant's office where I worked when one of the female members of staff who had been talking to a male colleague about a difficult pregnancy ended the conversation by asking whether she could use his Durex. My amazement at the frankness of the conversation was allayed a little later when I found that the term was not the name of a contraceptive in Australia. Of course, one has to remember that this happened 23 years ago and no doubt such conversations are quite commonplace these days.

There is no doubt that a knowledge of the English language is not always the advantage that it appears to be when one newly arrives from England. Even now I sometimes find myself at a loss to understand some 'strine'. I was very glad to note that the proposed new section 13 provides that the English language requirements are to be reduced from an adequate knowledge of English to a basic knowledge. A basic knowledge means that the applicants for citizenship will be required to use only simple English to respond to simple English questions and when taking the pledge.

I was also pleased to notice that persons over 50 years of age will be exempted from the English language requirement. A recent visit to Latin America convinced me how difficult it is to absorb a new language when one is over 50 years of age . About the only Spanish word I managed to remember without any difficulty was cerveza and I have to admit that the beer compared favourably with Australian beer. The point is that it is difficult enough for older people to adjust to a new way of life without having to struggle with a new language. But a lack of knowledge of English does not mean that a migrant does not appreciate the need for good government or have the desire to cast a vote to achieve that government . The greater majority of migrants voted for the Hawke Labor Government. This basic democratic right should not be denied to our older migrants because they lack a knowledge of the English language.
It is interesting to recall how we have progressed in the past 83 years. The Barton Government of 1901 prohibited the entry into Australia of:
any person who, when asked to do so by an officer, fails to write out and sign in the presence of the officer a passage of fifty words in length in the English language by the officer.

In this way the Government was able to ensure that any undesirable migrant be excluded. The Attorney-General of that time, Alfred Deakin, made it clear during the second reading of the Immigration Restriction Bill on 12 September 1901 exactly who those undesirable people were. He said that Australians wanted to be one people and remain one people without the mixture of races. Other races could not blend with Australians; there must be one race, a united race, which could intermix, intermarry and associate without degradation on either side. He saw no evil in white Australians declaring themselves superior to the many uneducated races of Asia and untutored savages. In those days, unfortunately, the Labor Party was equally as prejudiced against coloured people, if not more so, than the conservatives. Unfortunately, the media debate which has been whipped up by Professor Blainey carries shades of that second reading debate in our first Federal Parliament. I trust that the conservatives on the other side of the House will declare themselves opposed to the strident calls of racist groups in Australia who are calling for discrimination against migrants from Asia and not emulate their predecessors of 83 years ago.

It is, of course, interesting to note that in the debate of so many years ago honourable members had some problems in defining those Asiatic people they wished to exclude. Thus, both Government and Opposition members were at great pains to make it clear that the language test was not intended to cause offence to the Japanese. The Hon. F. E. McLean, the member for Lang, a member of the Liberal association and the last speaker in the debate, gave a good indication of the essence of that early debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were a bit embarrassed by the Anglo-Japanese treaty.
—That is quite correct. I noted that when I read the debate. I ask honourable members to listen to this. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe there would have been no danger either in the direction of Imperial veto or of any considerable delay had the Government adopted the more courageous course of introducing a Bill which would have excluded the Asiatic races without the roundabout educational test which is now provided.
Is this the sort of thing that the honourable member for Denison wants to see added to the Bill? Mr McLean went on to say:

At the same time I sincerely hope that the administration of this Bill will be effective. I credit the Government with the sincere desire to carry out the intentions of the people of Australia and to exclude coloured aliens from our midst.

That is what the Hon. F. E. McLean had to say on 9 October 1901. As I said before, I trust honourable members on the other side of the House are not supporting those views of a society which was rooted in the nineteenth century. I notice that all honourable members opposite are very quiet now.

Before I conclude my remarks in support of the Bill I would like to say a few words about the citizenship ceremony itself. Over the past 3 1/2 years since I have been the member for La Trobe I have attended a large number of citizenship ceremonies conducted by the Shire of Sherbrooke, the City of Knox and the Shire of Lilydale, the three municipalities which are situated in my electorate. Unfortunately, in recent months the ceremonies have been held on days when I am required to be present in the Parliament. I have, accordingly, written to the municipalities concerned requesting that the ceremonies be scheduled for the weeks when I am not in Canberra as I believe it is most important for Federal members to be present on such an important occasion as the conferring of Australian citizenship. I take this opportunity to express my regret that the Federal Government has not provided funding to support local government in its hosting of these ceremonies. I consider it is most inequitable for local government to have to provide the necessary finance for what is primarily a Federal responsibility. Municipalities are required to pay for the overtime for council officers who are needed to provide services in support of the ceremony and to pay for the refreshments which help to make the occasion friendly and hospitable. Many of the ceremonies I have attended are imaginative and colourful and are a credit to local government. However, if funding were provided by the Federal Government, citizenship ceremonies could be made even more memorable as one of the most important events in the life of Australian migrants.

I have also been most impressed with the fact that one of the officials of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in my area, Mr George Mohrene, has been prepared to give of his free time to officiate at citizenship ceremonies in the City of Knox and the Shire of Lilydale. I trust that the Minister will look into the funding matter as the amount of necessary finance would not be large and would serve to improve the quality and character of citizenship ceremonies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for Franklin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Five generations of inbreeding produced this.

—I am trying to be nice about the subject of this debate, but when one hears the honourable member for Casey remark that all Tasmanians are descendants of convicts, that their forebears went to Tasmania in chains and that Tasmanians are all inbred one feels that it is apt to count to 10. I know that sometimes the honourable member only says these things in jest. But really, Tasmanians can be upset when they hear that sort of thing. I do not want to get onto that subject at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I have firm views about the subject of this debate. I have been most interested in the parts of the debate that I have heard. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), represents the electorate neighbouring mine in Hobart, and I never seem to have any problems with this subject. To be quite truthful, I do not like using the word 'ethnic' and I do not like using the word 'Anglo-Saxon'. I do not even like talking about the Asians any more because I think we are all Australians. Both sides of this House will never agree philosophically on certain aspects. But I think we should start to think and talk about everyone in Australia being the same. Is not one of the Commandments: 'Love thy neighbour'? But a lot of the people in Australia are very confused at the moment. We are all not the same and do not treat people the same. We all say nasty things about people and so on. That attitude seems to have intruded into this debate. We seem to think that we can be better, we can run people down, we can hide under a shroud of hypocrisy, we can say things to hurt other people and then back off when it suits us. I do not think that that is the making of a very good Australia. I think it is the making of a bad Australia.

If we treat everybody in Australia the same, if we treat all Australians the same, the people who come to this country will understand what it is all about and want to mesh into our way of life. They have very little difficulty in doing this. But there are a heck of a lot of people in Australia at the moment who are trying to say that we are all different. They are saying: 'We believe in that and you should believe in this'.

We are all starting to create a real problem for ourselves. Before we know where we are, there is going to be real hatred. I think we should try to stop this hatred from developing. We have talked about change in this debate. We all want change and changes are occurring every day. Some of us, as we get older, do not like the sorts of changes that are occurring. Sometimes changes can be for the better and sometimes they can be for the worse. Unfortunately, members of the Australian Labor Party-

TALK.START.PARA: —Socialists.

—All right, the socialists are an unusual group. I found during the campaign about South West Tasmania that they love to take up causes. One can see it in their eyes. They start flashing left, right and centre about causes. All of a sudden they are involved in an argument about which they know very little. Before we knew where we were we had changes in Tasmania that we did not want. To be truthful, I get confused about what happens in the Labor Party. I think that we should do what it does a bit more because if we did we would get more publicity. The Labor Party has the Left, the Right, the Centre and the up and down the middle group, whatever that faction is called. There are factions of the Labor Party everywhere. Members of the Labor Party seem to jump on a bandwagon and confuse the rest of Australia. When we start to say that we love Australia as it is, that there have been problems over the years but we have developed our country in the way we want it, we find all of a sudden one group of honourable members opposite jumping up and saying: 'We do not like the flag'. When asked what is wrong with the flag they say: 'We do not like it. We want a change because somebody said we should change the flag'. Then honourable members opposite start talking about wanting to change the oath of allegiance. They want to take this out and take that out. When one asks who wants to do this they say: 'That is what the feeling is out in the community'. I never get that feeling. Does the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) get that feeling?
—No.

—They bring up sex discrimination. They talk about the poor Asians. they talk about this and that. Two-thirds of the Asians of the world live in absolute poverty. So we are being a hypocritical nation if we are saying that we will not help them when they need help. That does not mean that we do not want the British people to come to Australia. We, the politicians, and not the people of Australia are dividing this country because we do not have the guts when it really counts to support these people.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a funny place. We talk about importing-I use that word advisedly- 90,000 people to Australia for the purpose of making this country a better place . We abort about 90,000 babies in Australia, then we start talking about what we should be doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. I hesitate to do so but I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House will agree with me that the honourable member is straying just a little too far beyond the Standing Orders. I do not think he has even read the Bill because he has made no reference to anything whatsoever that is in the Bill since he started his speech over five minutes ago.
—That is quite untrue. I have studied the Bill very carefully.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Franklin to confine his remarks to the Bill.

—All right, I will step into the Bill a bit. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) will be the subject of what I am going to say. He is a person who represents a particular group that seems to want that point of view suppressed. To take this a step further, it is proposed that a person who wishes to qualify for citizenship will be required to spend two years in Australia. If migrants want to join in the freedom of Australia and to be part of Australia they should be forced after three years to become Australian citizens. If they want the freedom of Australia they should be forced to become Australian citizens. There should be no mucking around at all. If they do not want that freedom they should go back to where they came from.
—I am supposed to be authoritarian, am I?
—I am telling you my point of view. I am telling you what I think is wrong with your Bill and what is wrong with Australia at the moment. Whether you like it or not I am still going to tell you.
—Order! Would the honourable member address his remarks through the Chair and cease taking notice of the interjections.
—I cannot help it.
—That is your problem, but that is the Chair's ruling.
—We talk about changes. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Steedman ) has developed a change; he wears a leather jacket into the House. We might not like it, but we have to tolerate that change.
—We have the numbers.

—Exactly. The Bill will go through because you have the numbers. I understand that; that is the reason I am saying what I am saying. We have a right to disagree with what you are trying to do. We have a perfect right to disagree and that is what I am doing. Immigration, whether you like it or not, will be a very important part of the next election campaign because many people are starting to talk and to understand that you want changes to suit some minority groups. That is the trouble with your Party. You always jump on a bandwagon for minority groups. That is all I am trying to say. You might think it is right but there are a lot of other people who do not think it is. If you are going to start--

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. I have given an instruction to the honourable member for Franklin to address his remarks through the Chair. If he refuses to take any notice of the Chair the Chair will have to take action. I call the honourable member for Franklin.

—I will be finished in just a couple of seconds. The point I was trying to make is that the Government wants the changes and gets a bit uptight when we say we do not agree with those changes. We do not agree with the change to the oath of allegiance or with the thoughts about Australia becoming a republic. Many people disagree that Australia should become a republic and that is the reason that we are attacking the Government on this Bill. I do not agree with some of my colleagues who have said that there is an insidious group behind all this. I do not go to those extremes, but I do not like the way the Government is changing the face of Australia, an Australia that we have all worked so hard to make and which many migrants have come to Australia to make. I think the Minister is trying to change Australia by starting to develop--
—He will not admit it.

—No, he will not admit it, but we know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants changes. We think this Bill represents just one part of those changes. That is why we are opposing it. We believe that Australia is changing in the wrong way with changes to everything that we thought was good-the flag, the oath of allegiance and the national anthem. We think it would be far better to change some other things, but the Government seems to be concentrating on trying to make Australia a republic.
—Unemployment.

—The honourable member for Braddon mentions unemployment as an area for change. I have never called anyone a dole bludger in my life, but as a Liberal politician, I am accused, not personally, of having done so. The point I make is that that is the sort of thing that has developed in the minds of people and is causing divisions in Australia today. The Government should concentrate more on those things than on these changes that will affect Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment to the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill moved by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I join with my colleagues in opposing many, but not all, of the changes proposed in this Bill. This is a Bill about citizenship and fundamentally my objection to it is that it cheapens Australian citizenship. It makes it quicker, after a two-year residence rule instead of three, to become a citizen. It makes it easier as far as the English language requirement is concerned to become a citizen. It also makes it drabber to become one by the new pledge of allegiance. Quickness, easiness and drabness are not in my view desirable characteristics for Australian citizenship. It may be cut-price citizenship, no-frills citizenship, the cheapest citizenship in the world, but not what we traditionally think of as Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian citizenship has never been very hard to get for those seriously interested in it. Our requirements have been generous and not particularly strict, especially when compared with almost all other countries in the world. The requirements should be generous in a country built on migration from all parts of the world

But is the three-year rule so onerous, so oppressive, that it should be cut by one year? No other comparable country bestows citizenship after two years. Can anyone seriously believe that a person has a feeling for, or a real loyalty to, a country after two years of living in it? The honourable member who last spoke on the Government side, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), said that he thought it was sufficient time. In effect, he said the quicker the better. I cannot see why if the honourable member is happy to reduce it to two years he does not reduce it to one year or one week for that matter. I do not believe that two years is an adequate test. If we really value Australian citizenship perhaps we should discuss lengthening the three-year rule rather than shortening it. I am not advocating that, but shortening it seems to me to smack of wanting to enrol people as citizens or as voters willy-nilly without giving due weight to what is a desirable period of residence before someone can seriously assume the privileges and the duties of Australian citizenship.

Similarly, why dilute the requirement for an adequate knowledge of English to simply a basic knowledge of it? I put to one side the special case of elderly people and willingly go along with the Bill in relation to them. But citizenship surely requires more than a basic knowledge of the common tongue. A basic knowledge is, I suppose, enough to buy food, to find one's way to work and home again; it is enough English to survive. But citizenship is participation in the full life of the country, in its old and deeply established institutions, its political life, and its administration of justice. Even before the new basic English test has been introduced, we have all heard of jury cases where a citizen juror could not understand the evidence yet was trying to pass judgment. Is justice well administered when a juror has only basic English? Surely not! As politicans we have all come across cases of citizen voters who cannot read English well enough to understand the ballot paper instructions or the how-to- vote card and who rely on interpreters. This is surely not what we mean by citizenship, unless we have a contemptuous view of citizens as mere ballot fodder.
As for the proposed new pledges, they have about them as much solemnity as a landlord and tenant lease or a bill of sale. The 1973 oath says:

I, . . . renouncing all other allegiance, swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

The affirmation substitutes for 'swear by Almighty God', 'solemnly and sincerely promise and declare'. This oath and this affirmation have some resonance about them. The language is appropriate to a solemn and moving occasion as should be the adoption of Australian citizenship. It places our constitutional monarchy and its associated institutions at the centre of the matter. Now it is proposed that the applicant pledge:

I . . . renounce any current citizenship and all allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

There is an alternative form of pledge corresponding to the old affirmation. These pledges have as much solemnity as a hire-purchase agreement. I think, incidentally, reference to the Constitution is gratuitous, even devious. I suppose it allows the Government to say that it has deleted explicit reference to the constitutional monarchy but that it is still there really because such reference is in the Constitution. There is an American suggestion about it too. We know that American citizenship is a very serious matter, but the American association here is misleading. The American constitution with its famous amendments, the Bill of Rights and the Supreme Court judgments is a very different thing from our comparatively bread and butter Constitution. Pledging allegiance to one is quite a different matter from swearing allegiance to the other. The legal basis of our freedoms is expressed in different ways.

A migrant interested in citizenship who on reading the pledge of allegiance looks up the Australian Constitution to find out what it is all about is in for a shock as he reads about everything from lighthouses and fisheries to section 92 and section 96. An ordinary citizen, unlike a High Court judge, does not swear to uphold the Australian Constitution in the way an American might swear to uphold the principles of the American Constitution. If this is really meant as a way of implicitly working in the monarchy, it would be better to do it openly as in the 1973 oath and affirmation.
Some measures in this Bill have my support. For example, the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the Minister's decision is a worthwhile measure. There are others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. the debate is inter- rupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The Chair will be resumed at 2 p.m.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the report in this morning's Age newspaper that the idea of a censorship hotline being established between his Press office and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation was discussed at a meeting between the Prime Minister and the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Geoffrey Whitehead. I ask: Who raised the idea of such an obnoxious censorship hotline in those talks? How could the Prime Minister even consider by way of discussion an idea clearly directed at censorship of the Press and the management of news and comment on the national broadcasting network? In view of his previous attacks on the ABC and other media , will the Prime Minister give an assurance to the public that he is not proposing to manage news broadcasts on the ABC and thereby threaten the independence of that body?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here comes another ferocious attack from the Opposition.
—He is up to 37 per cent. It has gone to his head.

—Yes, it has gone to his head. One always has to get the facts straight , as distinct from the fiction which is put out by the people opposite. The facts are very simple. On Friday of last week, at the request of Mr Whitehead, the General Manager of the ABC, I, together with my Minister for Communications, had a discussion with him. At that discussion Mr Whitehead was good enough to set out in very extended form the future plans-financial, administrative and conceptual-as far as the ABC was concerned. We found them very useful. In the context of that discussion the question was raised of certain criticisms that I had expressed, and I outlined to the General Manager some of the points of view I had.

ANSWER.PARA: This fiction the Leader of the Opposition is raising about some form of censorship is an absolute nonsense. There has been no arrangement, nor would there be any, for the form of hotline that has been talked about. No such arrangement has been made or contemplated, nor will it be made. The situation is quite clear on the record. This Government in its 12 months in office has done more to assist the ABC and its independence than was done in the seven years of the previous Government.
