We remain totally committed to the independence of the ABC and we will do all we can to improve its capacity to deliver a very worthwhile service to the Australian community, without fear or favour from this Government and, if it was relevant, I would add 'or this Opposition'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House what progress the Government has made in meeting its target of creating 500,000 new jobs in its first three years of government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say that the Government has made outstanding progress. Since the National Economic Summit Conference last April we have created 210,000 new jobs- that is in 12 months. I know that everyone on this side of the House understands that that is 12 months, but I just explain that those 210,000 new jobs were found in 12 months. That is over 40 per cent of the job target for three years, so we are obviously very well ahead of target. It is very useful in these circumstances to look at the contributions that have been made in this area by the people opposite.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Would the Prime Minister clearly indicate whether he is talking about jobs for six months or permanent jobs?
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—The achievements of this Government make a mockery of some of the assertions that have been made by people opposite, and I remind the House of some of the things they have said. The Opposition Leader, that well- known economic genius on the other side of the House, said on 25 November last year:

ANSWER.PARA: The emptiness of that promise-
that is the promise to create half a million new jobs in three years-
is now starkly revealed.

On 8 September last year the Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to that promise of 500,000 new jobs as an empty promise on the scrap heap. The only thing that is on the scrap heap in politics today is the credibility of the Opposition. Mr Speaker, I remind you and the House that on 20 September last year the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had this to say:
Government policies will help to worsen unemployment, which will rise significantly during the current financial year.

What in fact has happened is this: Unemployment, instead of rising significantly , as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said then and as the Opposition hoped would happen, has fallen from 10.4 per cent last September to 9.3 per cent in March. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, expressing the hopes of the Opposition, said on 8 September last year:
The latest job losses put at risk the Government's Budget objective of increasing employment by about 1.5 per cent over 1983-84.

The facts are these: A 1.5 per cent increase in employment would be about 90,000 jobs, but between June of last year and the present time we have created 186,000 new jobs, which is more than double the Budget target of 90,000. That is the caper of these people opposite. They do not want to look at the facts or recognise that the people of Australia have benefited from the policies of this Government. They preach doom and gloom and they knowingly sow untruths around this country. The Opposition said that we would not do it, and we have more than doubled the target. What sticks in the craw of these people on the other side of the House, these self-styled economic managers, is that it is a Federal Labor Government which is providing, for the first time, competent and effective economic management.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania?

—Well, I have news about Tasmania for the honourable member that he will not like. The first thing I say about Tasmania is this: The honourable member is one of the few people on the other side of this House to show any sense, because he is getting out before the deluge.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I ask the Prime Minister to withdraw that remark. I do not know whether that is a reflection on me or my colleague, but my colleague is getting out for family reasons.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—The magnificent achievement of this Government, of creating over 200, 000 jobs in its first year, stands in stark contrast with the performance of the Opposition parties in their last year in government. In that last year they did not create one job. They destroyed 186,000 jobs in their last year in office. Unemployment increased by a quarter of a million. This divided and leaderless Opposition cannot face up to the fact that it could not provide the effective economic management which is being overwhelmingly provided by this Government.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In discussions with Prime Minister Nakasone and others during the Prime Minister's visit to Japan, did the Prime Minister receive an assurance that Australia would maintain its share of the Japanese beef market if it remained a competitive and reliable supplier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I want to take the opportunity of putting the Opposition's approach to the Japanese beef market in the appropriate perspective so that even its own members may be able to understand the unbelievable hypocrisy which they are showing in this matter. The fundamental objective of this Government's negotiations with the Japanese authorities has been to maximise Australia's access to the Japanese beef market. That has been our public position; it has been our negotiating stance and all that we have said and done publicly and privately has reflected that concern. That position has been put by me, by Mr Bowen, by Mr Hayden and by Mr Kerin. That position will be maintained by Mr Kerin when further ministerial talks are held in Tokyo on 14 May. It is important to understand that what this Government is doing in negotiations with the Japanese is well understood by the Australian cattle industry, with whom the Government has been in regular contact on this matter. As distinct from this responsible attitude taken by the Government, the Opposition has made every effort to weaken and undermine Australia's negotiating stance and to work against the national interests of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I want the Australian public to understand just what was the the achievement of the Opposition parties when they were in government because the problems of this country in regard to the Japanese beef market date back to the Strauss-Ushiba agreement of 1978. That agreement was signed on 13 January 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has to have the notes or he will get the dates wrong.

—I do not have the dates wrong; it was 13 January 1978. Under the Strauss-Ushiba agreement Japanese imports of high quality beef were increased by 10,000 tonnes on a global basis, beginning in the Japanese financial year 1978. That increased their quota of 6,800 tonnes by another 10,000 tonnes. It is important to understand that the types of high quality beef specified effectively precluded Australian competition with United States suppliers. That has been disastrous for Australia ever since. What happened in those circumstances when this agreement was negotiated between Strauss of the United States and Ushiba of Japan? What was the attitude of the then Government? Not only did it meekly accept what was negotiated between the United States and Japan but also it applauded it. A Press release of the then National Party Minister for Trade and Resources, dated 14 January-the following day-said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . welcomed indications of a settlement of a number of outstanding trade issues between the United States and Japan.
Furthermore, this National Party Minister in charge of trade said in this Press release:

. . . since the Strauss visit was concerned with ways of easing Japan's considerable balance of trade surplus, particularly with the USA, the communique should emphasise hotel quality beef mainly provided by the USA.

As a result of those negotiations of 1978 and the subsequent 1979 agreement by which the United States received an increase for its beef exports of a further 14,000 tonnes, which were applauded by the then Government and in particular by the National Party, Australian tonnages shipped to Japan fell absolutely from 100,400 tonnes in 1979 to 92,900 tonnes in 1980 and down to 90,200 tonnes in 1982. That was a result of the negotiations between the United States and Japan which were applauded by the people on the other side of the House.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It seems that Question Time is being interrupted by an incessant barrage of sound. I would not dignify it by using the term ' interjections'. I ask honourable members to observe the Standing Orders of the House.

—As a result of those negotiations, applauded by honourable members on the other side of the House, Australia's share of the market declined from 78 per cent in 1978 to 67 per cent. That was an extraordinary attitude to be adopted by the then Government. I come to the key section of the communique.
—Even Mick Young is worried. Sit him down, Mick!
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will cease interjecting.
—Even Mick's losing confidence now.
—I warn the honourable member for Hume.
—I come to the key section of the communique which was released by Mr Nakasone and me. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Japanese side confirms that it has no intention of dealing with the trade problems with third countries at the expense of Australia.

I therefore reiterate that what we are doing is negotiating for an outcome which will markedly improve the access of Australian beef producers to the Japanese market and which will be satisfactory to the Australian beef industry. We are doing that in all our public and private stances and in all our negotiating. We are doing the best we can for the Australian beef industry and its interests are not being helped by the undermining attitudes of the Opposition in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware of a decision by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to phase out its television operations in Townsville and Rockhampton with the introduction of the new satellite in 1986? In view of the fact that this most unpopular decision involves not only Townsville and Rockhampton but also the entire regions of northern and central Queensland, will the Minister as a matter of urgency, firstly, table in this Parliament the full report or reports on which this decision was made and, secondly, table in this Parliament the names of individuals or organisations, if any, consulted in northern and central Queensland before it was announced? Thirdly, will he give an undertaking to ask the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to reverse its decision?

—I appreciate the honourable member's concern to learn of the ABC's decision with respect to regional television programming at Rockhampton and Townsville. It is an indication of the concern on the part of the honourable member for Herbert not only on this issue but also on all other matters affecting his electorate. I must point out that the decision was made by the ABC Board in the context of its statutory responsibilities. I understand that a report and a recommendation were put to the Board, but these papers are, of course, internal ABC documents. I have been advised that the decision indicated by the honourable member for Herbert was taken in the context of national planning of television. I am further advised that there was no consultation, although the ABC staff organisations and unions were informed before the decision was taken. I am prepared to give an undertaking to seek from the ABC Board the full reasons behind the decision and its implications and to bring to the Board's attention the expressions of concern which have been brought to my notice. In conclusion, I wish to emphasise that the decision is one for the Board of the ABC. That decision taken by the Board was received by me on 26 April.
—Give them some more money.

—That is a fairly stupid interjection. I hope someone will ask a question on that matter, and I will deal with it. There is no provision in the ABC legislation which requires the ABC to seek my approval for such a decision. Finally, I wish once again to emphasise that because of the independence of the ABC Board, this was a decision taken by the Board and not by the Government.

—I refer the Prime Minister to reports that the Vietnamese occupying army in Cambodia commenced its dry season offensive in the middle of April by launching a series of attacks against Khmers near the borders of Cambodia and Thailand. Has the Prime Minister noted that the offensive has dislodged some 75, 000 to 80,000 Cambodians from their camps, many of whom have had to flee to Thailand, and inflicted considerable suffering on civilian inhabitants of the border camps? I note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is now talking to the Prime Minister. I hope that honourable members will note that. This happened yesterday. A question on foreign policy to the Prime Minister had to be handed over to the Foreign Minister. I know the Prime Minister does not have six pages of notes, but I hope he will be able to respond nevertheless.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will get on with his question.

—Does the Prime Minister agree that this is a major offensive and not 'a routine military operation to punish criminals', as described by Vietnam's Foreign Minister? Will the Prime Minister dissociate himself from the remarks reportedly made by his Foreign Minister recently in Tokyo that these actions by the Vietnamese forces were 'not unreasonable'?

—Let me make it quite clear on behalf of the Government that we are disturbed by any actions in the area which are likely to disturb further the situation in that country and in respect of which, as distinct from the noises made by the Opposition, my Foreign Minister has been actively dedicating himself , in discussions with countries in the region, to trying constructively to bring about a more harmonious situation. We have done that consistently from the time that we have been in government. I must say that the efforts which have been made by the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, have met with universal approbation because they have not been concerned with cliches and platitudes but have been concerned with trying to talk constructively with all the countries in the region. Neither the Foreign Minister nor I welcome any offensive action in that area. Mr Hayden will be going to the region in a matter of two or three weeks, where he will inform himself directly through discussions with people in a position to know of the precise nature of the operation, and I am certain that he will say then, and when he comes back, what we have consistently said as a government-that we do not welcome any offensive action by any groups in this area. But we will not attempt to use the situation of great tragedy for thousands of people in Indo-China as an occasion for trying to score political points. We will use our influence constructively to try to bring about a peaceful resolution of what unfortunately has been a tragic situation.

—Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Honourable Michiyuki Isurugi, MP, Minister of State for Science and Technology in the Government of Japan. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the implications of yesterday's excellent consumer price index result for wage movements this year and for the prospects of income tax cuts in the August Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As suggested by the honourable member in his question, it was indeed an outstanding CPI result for the March quarter. The Acting Treasurer made it quite clear in his official statements yesterday that the outstanding result in the March quarter did in part reflect the impact of Medicare. Even if we exclude the impact of Medicare, it should be understood that the rise in the CPI on an annual basis-the annual increase-was the lowest for over a decade. The simple fact is that this Government has reduced the underlying inflation rate in this country from the 11 per cent that it inherited to about 7 1/2 per cent a year.

ANSWER.PARA: Looking to the future in terms of the question that was put to me by the honourable member about the impact of the consumer price index on wage movements , there is still a further impact of the Medicare changes to be reflected in the next quarter. We understand this will be approximately 0.8 per cent. So in the June quarter we are looking at a small increase in the CPI. Quite clearly, the combined result of the March quarter and the June quarter CPI will be minimal. We will probably be looking at no more than about one per cent at the outside. What that means, and I am sure that this was in the mind of the honourable member when he asked the question, is that Australia is looking at a period of 12 months of virtually no wage movement as a result of the operation of the indexation system being related to these movements to which I have referred.

It is quite clear that with Australia now looking forward to about 12 months in which wage rises will be minimal, that will provide a very helpful breathing space for business. It will help profits to recover further, it will help new investment plans to go ahead and it will help the creation of even more jobs. Very importantly, and I know this is a matter of interest to the honourable member for Burke with his interest in manufacturing industry, it will mean that in 1984 real unit labour costs, which are a very important element in these considerations, will go back to what they were in the late 1960s and 1970s after having been way out of line in the period intervening. I hope that both sides of the House will welcome the statement made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions yesterday which made it clear that, in line with the accord, the ACTU will not seek compensation for Medicare induced reductions in the CPI. We, on this side of the House, applaud Mr Dolan and the ACTU for the responsible attitude which it has adopted. We will accept our obligation, as a Government, to proceed with income tax cuts in the Budget so that, again in line with the accord, we can ensure that wage restraint continues in this country.

It is quite clear when one looks at these facts and takes them into account- that is, the wage restraint that has been achieved, the very significant reduction in the inflation rate which has been associated with it, the very high rates of economic growth that have been achieved generally, particularly in the housing industry, and the significant reduction in non-seasonal interest rates in the period that this Government has been in office-with the significant growth in employment to which I have already referred, one will see that, under this Government, there has been a remarkable turnaround in the Australian economy. I suggest that Opposition members put that on the menu when they go to Thredbo. It will give them something to think about and contrast with their own dismal past performance and the hopelessly irrelevant so-called policies that they have for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon, the Hon. William French Smith, the United States Attorney-General. On behalf of the House I extend to him a very warm welcome.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister and follows the answer that he gave to my earlier question in which he refused to dissociate himself from remarks made by his Minister for Foreign Affairs that it was not unreasonable for Vietnamese forces in Cambodia to attack Khmers.
—Your foreign policy--

—The honourable member may not be interested in the destruction of human life in our part of the world, but we are. In view of the fact that the Prime Minister has refused to dissociate himself from the remarks by his Foreign Minister that it was not unreasonable for Vietnamese forces in Cambodia to attack Khmers, including civilians, will the Prime Minister similarly categorise as not unreasonable the recent Soviet attack on the Mujahedeen in Afghanistan? If not, will he advise the House of his different perception of the two?

—I would have thought that, if there was any group in this country that had absolutely no mandate to talk about the destruction of life in the Indo- China area, it would be the people sitting on the opposite side of this House who stand condemned for their total misreading of the political realities of that region in the 1960s and 1970s and who, more than any members of any other government in the history of this country, identified Australians with the destruction of life in that region. If there is one group of people which has not got clean hands on this issue, it is the Opposition in general and the Leader of the Opposition in particular. It took the Australian Labor Party coming into government to end the destruction, not only of Indo-Chinese lives, but also of Australian lives in that area.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I ask your advice, please. In view of the Prime Minister's vitriolic remarks would it be wise to ask our American allies to leave?

—Order! The Chair is prepared to accept that honourable members often raise points of order that are not accurately points of order. I think the honourable member for Bass realises that he took it too far. I warn him against a repetition of that action.

—I make only this observation in respect of that unworthy interjection by the honourable member for Bass: The relationship between Australia and the United States has never been in better shape than it has been under this Government. Of course, the Government and I condemn without equivocation the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in the first place and the attacks that the Soviet Union is now making upon so-called 'rebel forces' in that country.
—What do you think they are?
—I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—I support them. I am saying that they are referred to as rebels by the Soviet Union. I am saying that that is not a proper way of describing them. If the honourable member had the beginning of a whit of sense, he would understand that.
—But you--
—Order!
—I know he is slow-minded. We have to put things slowly to get through to people like him.
—If he attacks me--
—Order! I have warned the honourable member for Denison. I have allowed him considerable latitude.

—We condemn the original invasion and we condemn the actions of the Soviet authorities in that area now. There is no question about that condemnation. It was made from the beginning and we continue to make it.

—Is the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of the numerous reports of buried radioactive materials throughout the Maralinga area? Could such radioactive materials be a serious health hazard to Aboriginals returning to the area? Will the Minister be taking any steps to ascertain from the United Kingdom Government the locations of those radioactive dumps? Further, will the Minister press the Australian Government to have the United Kingdom Government identify those radioactive dumps and to accept its responsibility to have them cleared and cleaned up?

—This matter had been the subject of public comment by my colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy who stated on 30 April that, as far as the Government is concerned, there were no secret atomic tests in Australia in the 1960s. I am also informed that the Government has no information concerning Aboriginals dying as a result of any tests. However, I share with the honourable member his concern about what really was tantamount to a death-bed statement that some four Aboriginals were found dead in that area. I have had conversations with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in South Australia. The South Australian Government is pressing the British Government for the supply of as much information as possible. Currently an inquiry is being conducted by the South Australian Government into the effect of atomic weapons testing on the health of the Aboriginal population. I have provided some $50,000 towards the cost of that inquiry. Today I discussed with the South Australian Minister for Health, Dr Cornwall, the possibility of extending the terms of that inquiry. I assured him, as I assured the South Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that from the point of view of my ministry we regard these matters very seriously. The South Australian Government will have my fullest co-operation in trying to get an early resolution of these matters.
—Will the Minister table the document from which he was reading?
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?
—No.
—I direct my question to the Special Minister of State.
—Things have changed.

—Order! The honourable member for Warringah repeatedly casts aspersions on the Chair in a sotto voce manner. I have not taken action before, but I ask him to be very careful or I will take action. I call the honourable member for Boothby.
—I ask--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

—I took particular exception because a remark was made by the honourable member for Moreton that the question regarding documents on public affairs was put in a different manner on previous occasions, which is inaccurate . The honourable member for Warringah said that things have changed. I call the honourable member for Boothby.
—Mr Speaker, for the third time I will try to ask my question.
—You will be trying for longer than that.

—I hope that the Special Minister of State will not take as long as the Prime Minister does to give a non-answer to the House. I direct my question to the Special Minister of State. I ask: Have any departments or government instrumentalities commissioned opinion polls since March 1983? If so, did that polling include questions of a political nature such as a reference to a political party, a political identity or a party policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that honourable members on both sides of the House will be pleased to know that I am not in charge of every department.
—Did your Department?

—No. For the information of the honourable member for Boothby, we did try to get some semblance of sanity in the amount of money which government invests in advertising and market research. As members of the Opposition know, when they left office they were spending something like $24m a year on advertising and market research, and on many special programs such as the 1982 Budget, for which I think it was left to the honourable member for Balaclava to carry the can. He had to go out and suggest that the best way to present that Budget was to spend a couple of million dollars on television and radio advertising. I might add that that occurred during the Flinders by-election.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, where departments do have claims for carrying out research, which in most cases we insist upon before any money is spent on advertising, so that the money is spent in the professional way in which other people using advertising and market research would use it, their request goes through a committee, which originally consisted of myself, the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. A ministerial order has been altered, and the Australian Government advertising has now been shifted to the public information section of my Department. It is basically dealt with by the Minister for Finance and myself. We have agreed to a number of polls, which have been carried out prior to any money being spent on advertising. I have not seen all the questionnaires that have been prepared further to the briefings given by the specific departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they include any political questions?

—I do not know but I will find out for the honourable member. I would not have thought so. If anything is available the honourable member can look at it. I know how wise he is. He has been following the fortunes of John Cornwall in South Australia, so one could have anticipated the question the honourable member for Boothby asked.
—Are you willing to table the questionnaires?
—I will look at what material has been prepared. I am not a great one for secrecy.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should have notes! In addition to the matters I have raised in answer to the honourable member for Boothby, I add that many departments do not like the idea of becoming part of a system whereby they have to seek approval. The Department of Defence, the Department of the Treasury and others are very reluctant to become part of that system. In the areas where we do have responsibility to give approval I will find out what questionnaires have been approved for the carrying out of research and give the honourable member a detailed answer.

—I ask the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether his attention has been drawn to reports that some union officials have stated their intention to campaign for a catch-up of real wage reductions which occurred during the wages pause. Is the Government concerned about the prospects of such a campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statements that have been made by some union officials, particularly Mr Clancy of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and Mr Carmichael of the Amalgamated Metals, Foundry and Shipwrights Union. Both of these gentlemen have expressed the view that there is a need to catch up for the real wage reductions during the period of the wage pause and that there is a need for some campaign to that effect. The question asked whether the Government was concerned about these statements. We would be if they were to result in a campaign for wage claims outside the indexation system. Such a campaign would be contrary to Government policy. It would be contrary to the policy of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It would be contrary to the wage fixation principles of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and it would most certainly be contrary to what is needed to maintain our extraordinarily high rate of economic and employment growth-the highest rate of growth in the Western industrialised world.

ANSWER.PARA: I say emphatically that, for several reasons, I do not expect that such a wages campaign outside indexation will eventuate. Firstly, the prospect of a small national wage rise in October has been well known since the prices and incomes accord was finalised early last year between the then ALP Opposition and the ACTU. It has been known since that time and repeated on many occasions that that would be the case. Mr Dolan's statements yesterday and this morning confirm that it remains the ACTU's position that it accepts that outcome. Secondly, the ACTU has stated many times that catch-up considerations can be pursued in the context of taxation relief rather than by way of wages. That concept is built into the accord. It has been reiterated again by Mr Dolan on behalf of the ACTU since yesterday's consumer price index figures came out. Thirdly, as Mr Carmichael has indicated, it is not his union's position to go outside the accord in pursuing a catch-up and that is the ACTU's position. When the ACTU wages committee meets on Friday week I am quite sure that that position will be confirmed once again on behalf of the whole trade union movement. Fourthly, as the Prime Minister said yesterday in Question Time and again today, the Government will be doing all in its power to give significant tax cuts in the forthcoming Budget. The Government will be discussing the scope for tax cuts with the ACTU in the near future.

There is every reason to believe that the wages policy of the accord and of the Commission will be maintained and that the wages outcome for the rest of this year will be a very small national wage rise in October which, along with some increases coming through the anomalies aspect of the wage fixation principles, should still result in an overall wage increase in the course of this calendar year of around 5 per cent. It may be slightly more; it may be less. The level of real labour unit costs, as the Prime Minister indicated previously, will be back to the level of a decade ago, for the first time in a decade, by the end of this year. Such an outcome is conducive to a continued decline in our rate of inflation and a continued improvement in our level of international competitiveness and very conducive to the creation of an environment which is highly conducive to an increase in private investment.

In short, I say to the honourable member for Macquarie that there is no need to be alarmed by the statements which got much prominence in this morning's Press, or, in the case of the Opposition, to be overjoyed by those statements. The fact is that those concerns being expressed by those trade union officials are capable of being resolved without damaging the accord, the wage fixation system or the economy of this country.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
