TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek to make a personal explanation.
—The right honourable member may proceed.

—According to the media this morning and a telephone report I have had, the Premier of New South Wales has suggested that it was I who designated the various areas of New South Wales which the Commonwealth Government, in accordance with its constitutional powers, will consider for defence purposes. The areas were not designated by me. They were designated for preliminary investigation-I stress preliminary investigation-as a result of consultations between my predecessor, the Minister assisting my predecessor and the Premier. They were then investigated within the context of determining the requirements of the Department of Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason there was no release of the Press statement was that I did not accept that they should proceed beyond that preliminary investigation until a number of matters had been concluded, including whether there should be a coincidence of the artillery range with the other facilities required for the purposes of the Department of Defence. I did not accept that the areas, in particular the Bathurst-Orange and the Barraba-Bundarra-Uralla regions should be proceeded with if it would mean that large areas of productive agricultural land would need to be acquired compulsorily.

The Premier is totally wrong in his assertion that I had designated those large areas of agricultural land. I restress the fact that the appointment of consultants to proceed with an environmental impact study was a direct result of decisions by the present Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and the Premier. It was not a decision by the previous Government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's attempts to mislead the Australian people on the real state of the Australian economy in order to serve its goal of an early election.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last two days this Parliament and the Australian public have been treated to the best examples yet of the extent and the degree to which the present Australian Government is prepared to live politically in the short term at a medium and longer term cost to the economic management of Australia. It is worth recalling that a certain political figure in Australia had this to say on 15 February 1983 during the last Federal election campaign: 'Under my government parliaments will run their full time'. They were the words of the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), then the Leader of the Opposition, making it perfectly clear that under governments which he led parliaments would run their full time. Everybody knows how very quickly that particular commitment was thrown by the Prime Minister on to the scrap-heap. Everybody knows that less than a year after that statement was made the Prime Minister was blithely announcing that as far as he was concerned he thought it appropriate that there be an election in Australia some time between December 1984 and March 1985. So in less than a year that particular commitment of the Prime Minister, given unambiguously and unequivocally, was thrown on to the scrap-heap.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the state of the Australian economy; if one looks at the economic policies of this Government; if one looks at the way in which this Government has manipulated the consumer price index, one is reminded again and again of how short term this particular Government's horizons are. It may be clever politics to claim all of the credit for the improvements which have occurred in the Australian economy over the last year. It may be clever politics for the Prime Minister to come in here, as he did at Question Time, and say that the reduction in the rate of inflation, even if one leaves out the Medicare fiddle, was still a very creditable performance and to lay all the credit for that on the Government's own economic policies. That may be clever politics. It may fool a lot of the people at present but the Prime Minister knows as well as does everybody on this side of the House that the two factors over the last year which have made the greatest contribution to a reduction in the underlying rate of inflation have been the wages pause of the last Government and the natural effects of a recession on prices and costs in the Australian community.

The truth is that the prices and incomes accord so far has made no contribution at all to the reduction in either the CPI or the underlying rate of inflation that we have experienced in Australia. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in defending the prices and incomes accord to the trade union movement, has argued that if it had not been for the accord, wage increases over the last year would not have been as high as in fact they have been. So far from the policies of the Government, far from the prices and incomes accord being the main reason that Australia's rate of inflation has experienced a welcome reduction, that particular element has not played a major part at all. I repeat: It may be clever politics of the Prime Minister to claim that everything that has happened over the last year-including, on occasions when he gets totally expansive, the breaking of the drought-has been due to the policies of the Government. But because those claims are untrue, although it makes perhaps smart political sense in the very short term, in the medium and longer term the Government will rue many of the statements that have been made by the Prime Minister and by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the last year.

The Prime Minister waxed very eloquent today about the question of employment and unemployment. It is very interesting to look at the speeches of the Prime Minister over the last year and see how little he has spoken about unemployment. One remembers when he was the Opposition spokesman on employment matters in this House. One remembers that every day he was talking about the capacity of a Labor government to reduce unemployment in Australia. Every day the then spokesman on industrial relations was saying that if the policies of the Australian Labor Party were allowed to take effect, they would bring about a sharp reduction in unemployment. The fact is that over the last year, and notwithstanding what the Prime Minister has said, there has been a reduction of only 33,000 in the total number of unemployed in Australia, despite what the Prime Minister and his colleagues so euphorically refer to as Australia's greatest ever economic recovery.

This Government is pushing the issue of unemployment further down the agenda of action so far as its policies are concerned. Its only weapon in fighting unemployment is to pump more and more money into public sector job creation schemes. When a report winds up on the desk of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations pinpointing the problems of youth unemployment and the contribution made to it by high youth wages, what does he do? He pigeonholes the report. He does not even supply copies of it to the Premiers of this country at the Premiers Conference because it does not fit his ideology for dealing with the question of unemployment. Again and again we find that the Government is living for the short term and maximising the political advantage of the fortuitous turnaround in conditions resulting from the breaking of the drought and the wages pause. It is taking all the short term political gains at a very considerable medium and longer term economic cost to Australia.

If honourable members really want to find a mature, sober and pragmatic judgment on what the investors of this country think about the medium and longer term economic prospects in Australia let me draw their attention to the latest set of forecasts of private sector investment which have been produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Let me remind them in doing this that only 20 minutes ago the Prime Minister of this country said in this House that the March quarter consumer price index increase, even if we leave the Medicare fiddle out of it, is the lowest for almost a decade. I remind him that under his Government private sector investment in the next financial year is forecast by the Bureau of Statistics to be the lowest in Australia for over 10 years. If one looks at those figures one finds a very gloomy and dismal pattern of private sector investment. I remind the Acting Treasurer (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, and the Prime Minister that the Government cannot go on forever creating jobs through the public sector. Sooner or later, if we are to have a lasting economic recovery in Australia and if we are to do other than live completely for the short term the Government will have to bring about a private sector revival.

I ask the Minister at the table and the Government why it is, if their economic policies are so wonderful and are bringing about the economic recovery they speak of and if they are presiding over this wonderful economic miracle in Australia, that the investors of Australia so lack confidence in the medium and longer term economic future of Australia. Why is investment in the mining industry in a parlous condition? Why have the mining industry, the National Farmers Federation, the merchant banks and the building societies all gone to the Government in recent days and said that the outlook for private sector investment is very gloomy? Why are they not bedazzled by what the Prime Minister treated us to at Question Time today? Why are they not enchanted by the latest CPI result? Why are they not absolutely persuaded by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations that his wages policy is the answer to all our problems ? There is a crisis of confidence in the medium and longer term economic future of Australia by its investors. These forecasts demonstrate that more than any other statistic that can be produced on either side of the House.

Again, we have an example of the Government living for the short term. A report in the Hobart Mercury at the weekend states that the Prime Minister has instructed all his Ministers to push aside any difficult or unpopular decisions until after the end of the year. Of course, the Prime Minister wants to create the optimum political situation for the entirely unecessary premature election that he will have at the end of the year. I was very interested to see the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations wriggle a bit at Question Time today when he was taxed with what Mr Clancy of the Building Workers Industrial Union had said on radio this morning. He said that the left wing unions would start a campaign, beginning next October, to bring about catch-up in respect of the wages that they lost during the wages pause. The Minister in answer to a question on that subject said: 'Do not worry about that, listeners. We will give a tax cut that will buy them out of any opposition'. The only problem with that answer is that the tax cut will come in August and Mr Clancy will start his campaign in October. What will the Government do if the campaign starts in defiance of its wishes? Will it cancel the tax cut it gave in August if the campaign starts in October? The Minister knows quite well that his capacity to control Mr Clancy is no greater than the capacity of many other people in the Australian Council of Trade Unions to control that gentleman.

What this Government has done on every political and economic issue over the last 12 months is maximise its short term political advantage to the medium and longer term cost of Australia. It has put off a decision on the assets test but it has not removed the threat of an assets test over the head of every pensioner in Australia. It has not introduced the legislation to give effect to its lump sum superannuation proposals but it has not removed the threat to the non- taxability of lump sum superannuation payments. It has promised a reform of the Australian taxation system but it has not said that it will not introduce a capital gains tax and the Prime Minister continues to allow senior Ministers to canvass publicly and argue for a capital gains tax. Again and again the Government puts off the difficult decisions, hoping the electorate will not be reminded of them and hoping that they will not be in the mind of the electorate when we go to the polls at the end of the year. It knows all along that if it is successful those difficult, unpalatable decisions will be back on the table, back on the Government's agenda for implementation.

I will wager that this Government will go to the election at the end of this year without any policy in the area of taxation. In reply to our questions on where the Government's taxation policy is the Prime Minister says: 'We are having a bit of a discussion with the Economic Planning Advisory Council about it. We will talk to EPAC about it. We will talk to everybody and we will produce a fair and equitable taxation system'. That will not be a tax policy or an answer to people who want to know whether we will have a broad-based indirect tax, a capital gains tax or a wealth tax. That will be no answer to the older people of Australia who want to know exactly what will happen with the assets test. Does the Prime Minister know that the elderly in this nation are living in fear of the assets test he has talked about? Does he realise what uncertainty is being created for that section of our community because of his short term political tactics? It would be far fairer to those people to say now what he will do and to tell them exactly what will happen with their pensions rather than adopt the shameful and politically inspired device of empanelling a group of citizens to give a report to the Government. The Government ought to come clean and say exactly what it will do about the assets test. It ought to come clean about all the other things but, as in all its other economic decisions, the Government is living entirely for the short term.

The Government has claimed credit for every good thing that has happened with the economy over the last year. It has failed to recognise that the two major contributions to the improvement over the last year have been totally beyond its control or encouragement-the breaking of the drought and the beneficial effects of the wages pause. Neither of those things had anything to do with the prices and incomes accord. In no way did the prices and incomes accord contribute to either of those developments. They have contributed, more than anything else, to the improvement over the last 11 months. The Government knows that it must get to the polls before a realisation reaches the Australian community of the problems that it will have in 1985.

In 1985 the Australian community will be forced to pay the price of so many decisions having been deferred in 1984. In 1985 the lack of private sector investment could have a very drastic effect on unemployment levels. In 1985 the level of unemployment will be no lower than it was in March 1983. By 1985, according to the Government's own forecast, the underlying rate of inflation will be going up again. The Government cannot have another Medicare fiddle in 1985 any more than it can break the drought again in 1985 and the Government will face that problem also. In 1985 the full effects of the worst investment strike that this country has had for over 10 years will be brought home to the Australian community. In the manufacturing industry employment levels are lower than they were in March 1983. The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) knows better than anybody else in this House that those grim realities will be brought home to the Australian people. It is no wonder that this Government and this Prime Minister are quite irresponsibly and totally living for the short term political advantage and nothing else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an appallingly weak matter of public importance this is! The Liberal and National parties failed this country miserably in the seven years of their stewardship. They have egg all over their faces. All the noise of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Opposition, does not make up for good argument. Now that the alternative policies of the Hawke Labor Government are working this discredited Liberal- National Party Opposition is retreating into the sort of diatribe we have just suffered in listening to the speech of the shadow Treasurer over the last quarter of an hour. Members of the Opposition are jealous of the fact that this country is on the road to recovery. Let me go briefly through some statistics, which I will later refer to in detail. Gross domestic product is expected to increase by 6 per cent in the 1983-84 financial year. We expected in the Budget only a 3 per cent increase. That was a heck of a lot better than the present Opposition achieved during its seven years of failure in its stewardship of the management of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The employment figures from September 1983 to mid-1984 have improved incredibly . Let me go over those figures. In September 1983 unemployment peaked at 10.4 per cent, whereas in mid-1984 we are now down to an unemployment rate of 9.3 per cent. But that is not nearly as good as the figures for the growth of employment itself. From April 1983 to March 1984 we had an increase in the number of jobs of 210,500. Manufacturing production was up 4 per cent in the December quarter of 1983 compared with the March quarter of 1983. In the three months to February 1984 motor vehicle registrations were up 6.4 per cent on those for the previous quarter. We also find that interest rates are generally down on those of last year.

Having suffered a few years in which we had an adverse balance of trade, we find that in the nine months to March 1984 there was a balance of trade in our favour of $356m compared with an adverse balance of trade of $944m in the nine months to March 1983. No wonder the Opposition is ashamed of its discredited economic policies. No wonder members of the Opposition come in with the sort of speech that we had to listen to in this House today, trying to make up for the fact that the alternative economic policies are working. They are jealous of the fact that we were able to bring this country together at the National Economic Summit Conference and that we have been able to create more consensus and to get people to work together to a greater degree than we had during the last seven years.

We had a period of confrontation under the Fraser Government. All the people now on the front bench of the Opposition are part of the discredited team which gave rise to that period of confrontation. Members of the Opposition are jealous of the fact that we have been successful in funding the deficit-successful to the extent that interest rates have declined over the year of that high deficit. We have been successful in reducing the effect of the deficit. Government spending has provided a stimulus to the economy. As I mentioned, 210,500 jobs have been created. Honourable members opposite are jealous of the fact that nearly all the statistics that one looks at show that this economy of ours has improved over the period in which this Government has been in office.

Let me go over the speech, if we can give it that title, of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He commenced by talking about being misled in relation to the term of this Parliament. He overlooks completely that it was the Fraser Government, of which he was a leading member, which decided to go to the polls early and left us with a situation in which we have to have a Senate election before May 1985, causing an early Federal election. He overlooks that completely and suggests that we are going to the polls early. He went on to speak about the so-called manipulation of the consumer price index. That, I would say to him quite unashamedly, is an affront to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which has a job to do and which does that job independently. The Government took a conscious decision, following an election promise, to alter the health insurance charges. Of course the CPI has shown the effect of those health insurance alterations. But the Government does not claim credit just for the adjusted figures contained in the announcement yesterday in relation to the CPI. It claims credit in respect of the unadjusted figures for health insurance. I will also come back to that point later.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition then referred to the prices and incomes accord. Is he, in preaching doom and gloom, as he has today, seeking to break down that accord? Is he so lacking in feeling for this country and desire for it to have further economic recovery built onto that for the first year of our Government that he wants, by his preaching, to bring down that accord? Let him come clean and tell this House and the nation whether he wants that to happen. He is not making any constructive contribution whatsoever to the good government of this country in these difficult times which have been created mainly by the Fraser Government. He is merely taking cheap political points in the way I am now illustrating.

There is only one area in which his claims might be able to be substantiated and that is when it comes to breaking the drought. I plead guilty on occasions, in order to try to bring a little lightness into the affairs of this nation, to giving the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) credit for breaking the drought. If that is misleading the nation, that is the only claim to credibility of the matter of public importance before the House.

When it comes to misleading the House, I shall point out how the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in his speech misled this House in relation to the employment figures. He is suggesting that there has been a reduction of only 33,000 in unemployment over the last 12 months and that responsibility for that should be driven home to this Government. That is an absolute piece of arrant nonsense. There is no way that the incoming Government could have been responsible for the unemployment levels of this country until about April of this year. The figures that I have given are credible and show that the growth in employment in this country from April 1983 until the present day has been of the order of 210,500. That is the figure that ought to be focused on. That is the only figure that would have given that part of his speech in this Parliament any credibility whatsoever.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition even wants to knock the community employment program. I wonder whether he has ever taken the trouble to look at some of the CEP programs in his own electorate and seen the joy that has been given to young kids, particularly disabled kids, who have been out of work for at least six months and others for many years because at last they have been given a chance to show their mettle. The sort of speech that he made today is typical of the attitude of those conservatives with whom he sits inasmuch as they would want to deny these young kids the benefit that they received from the CEP.

I want to quote the sort of knocking words that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition used in his speech. He talked about an investment strike. Everything that this Government has done has been designed to build up the climate for investment to take place. In view of the legacy we were left, there was no way there could immediately be an investment climate. But now the growth in employment, the growth in confidence that has come out of the National Economic Summit Conference, the reduction in interest rates and the sorts of statistics that I have already outlined to this House relating to growth-gross domestic product is up 10 per cent on the minus 2 per cent applicable at this time last year-the growth in manufacturing production over the last few months, the growth in motor vehicle registrations, and the balance of trade turnaround are all necessary background factors to the increase in private sector investment which we can confidently expect.

The honourable member for Bennelong even had the gall to mention that building societies were complaining about the present situation. No Minister in this Parliament has had a more continuous relationship with the building societies than I have. There is no group in the private sector in this nation which is more supportive of the housing policies we have instituted and of the way we have funded the Budget to enable them to lend money. This resolution of the Opposition is a sham. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition ought to be absolutely ashamed of himself for bringing it to this Parliament. I will focus on why he, in particular, should be ashamed of himself. It is absolute hypocrisy for this discredited former Treasurer to claim that the Government is misleading the people when his own record is such that in February last year he deliberately misled the Australian people in order to save his Prime Minister's neck. For the purpose of an election he misled the people. He told us that the deficit figure in prospect was $6 billion. We all know that the real deficit inherited by this Government was $9.6 billion; that deficit made all the more difficult the task that we took over. It made our achievements all the more remarkable.

When the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer the inflation rate was 11.5 per cent; that was the figure for the last quarter for which he was responsible. Only a year later the underlying inflation rate is down to 7.6 per cent. Without any alterations or adjustments relating to health insurance the relevant figure for the last year is 7.6 per cent. When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer the unemployment figure was 695,300, or 10 per cent. It is now down to 9.3 per cent. I just had the privilege of representing this country at meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The dominant view was that international recovery will strengthen and spread in 1984 . Instead of the doom and gloom we are hearing from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition these are the real facts that are known to people who have some idea of what is going on in the world. The real growth in industrial countries is 3.5 per cent compared with 2.25 per cent last year. The GDP forecast is for a rise of 5 per cent in the United States and 4 per cent in Japan. There is no evidence whatsoever that following from those sorts of results in the rest of the world a real increase in private investment in this country will not take place. The only things that could make that result go wrong are the doom and gloom attitudes which are being spread by this Opposition at present.

The good news for Australia is that there has been a strong economic pick-up in the first half of 1983-84. That should be translated into private sector investment. Our economic policy is now totally devoted to making sure that the recovery is not just temporary, but sustained. In summary, since the Hawke Labor Government came to office we have achieved much production and employment and proft figures are up. The rate of inflation and real unit labour costs are down and the economic situation is better than it has been for many years. Even blind Freddie can see that things have improved even if genial John fails to do so. There are so many positive factors. Strong private consumption expenditure ran well ahead of inflation over the last three months. As I said before, but it bears repeating, there is a lowering of interest rates at present. The pick-up in profits provides a very good starting point indeed for the recovery in investment. The growth normally strong in the first year of recovery in 1983-84 has been stronger than is usual and certainly stronger than was expected a year ago. I end as I commenced by saying that this is an appalling matter of public importance to bring to this House. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition ought to be ashamed of himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word appalling is the appropriate word for the contribution of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford). This Government has spent all of its time since the election campaign and the National Economic Summit Conference, squandering the good fortune which has come this country's way in the last 12 months. I refer to the wage pause, the breaking of the drought and the minor recovery in the world economy. It has squandered the opportunities and continued to try to talk up the economy and to accuse us in the process of talking it down. We have a responsibility to the Australian people to ensure that the facts are known.

SPEECH.PARA: The inescapable facts to come from the Minister's contribution are these: First , there is no need for an early election-the Government could put to the people a referendum for a simultaneous election if it wished and go its full term, something the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has no intention of doing; the second inescapable point is that unemployment is not falling; the third is that there is an investment strike. For all the Government says about having created an environment in which investment can take place it has not created that climate; no one has confidence.

I put some more facts before the Parliament to illustrate why that is so. Although jobs are certainly being created that was also so at various stages of the Fraser Government's term of office. The then Opposition said then that unemployment was not falling. The Opposition is now saying precisely the same: Unemployment is not falling. What is happening is that the creation of jobs is keeping up with the natural growth in the work force but, in fact, in its period of office the Government has reduced unemployment by only 0.7 per cent. At the same time Australian businesses had to absorb a compounded wages increase of 8.6 per cent. As well, there has been a dramatic increase in the on-costs in relation to the employment of people.

Yesterday's consumer price index figures really show that the CPI is a most inadequate way of measuring inflation. It is misleading to say, as the Government has said, that our inflation is now under the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. In fact, the Prime Minister at least admitted today that it is running at something like 7.5 per cent which is, of course, well above the OECD average of 5.8 per cent. Thus we are still uncompetitive on world markets. Despite what the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) have said today, 17 or 18 unions, led by the Building Workers Industrial Union, are determined to get some catch-up in addition to whatever tax cuts are granted in August. Mr Clancy has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are doing your best to help them, aren't you!
—The Government has an obligation to make it clear to the people whom it wants to invest that there is going to be certainty, that the Accord is going to stick.
—What on earth was the Prime Minister doing in Question Time other than that?
—He and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations were skating over statements such as that of Mr Clancy who said:

SPEECH.PARA: We want tax cuts which were promised in the Accord-
we have been told today they will be delivered-
and we want a restoration of the real value of wages which was also promised in the Accord.

We were told today that the Government hopes the Australian Council of Trade Unions wages committee will get things in order; we were not told that the Government will support employers in resisting the demands that Mr Clancy and the other 17 union leaders want to make outside the arbitration system in breach of their undertakings to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and in breach of the Accord. Government members cannot talk, as the Prime Minister has done, of reducing real labour unit costs when in fact we know that the on-costs are rising so dramatically. The Labor Government in Victoria recently produced what it called an economic blueprint. It was called 'Victoria. The Next Step', and it showed that labour on-costs, as a share of total hourly labour costs, have risen from 22 per cent in 1974 to 34 per cent in 1983. Of course, payroll tax has been increasing at a rate five times that of job creation in the past three years. This Government is sanctioning breaches of the accord while pretending that it is in place. It actually says that it is creating the climate for investment. It says it is funding its deficit, but it is funding it in such a way that it is deterring investment.

Look at what is happening on the industrial relations scene. First of all, there has been a protracted dispute at Broken Hill. It is no closer to settlement than it was a month ago. What has the Government said and what has it done with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to try to bring that to a close ? It has cut production down to 3 per cent. There are 2,700 miners currently out of work, and North Broken Hill Ltd has blamed its quarterly loss of $3.38m largely on the industrial disputes. Port Pirie is likely to have its smelter closed by Friday if that dispute is not settled. That means more loss of jobs and more damage to the economy. We have had a national two-week go slow by waterside workers. Yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) indicated that he was unaware of that go slow, yet it is having a very damaging effect on our trade. Twenty-one ships, with cargoes worth an estimated $200m are tied up around the country. This is an extra claim in breach of the accord, in breach of undertakings that the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia made to the Arbitration Commission when it accepted the wage indexation package.

In Tasmania seven west coast mines are reported to have closed down over a wages issue. Other local industries dependent on the work and on the consumption of the miners are also being disrupted. There are 2,000 meat workers on strike throughout Victoria. A campaign of picketing and vandalism has delayed the loading of 120,000 sheep at Portland. Again, this is threatening Australia's $ 200m a year live sheep export trade. Mr Curran, the famous Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in Victoria, has said that the campaign is aimed at making live sheep exports unprofitable. What will that do to the rural industries which are dependent on those exports?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it have to do with the Government and with misleading?
—It has everything to do with the accord because they are in breach of the accord.
—But what has it got to do with our misleading the Australian people?

—The Government is misleading the Australian people by trying to tell the public and the investors of this country that the accord is working. It is not working, and the Government is not doing anything to use its relationship with the ACTU in the accord to get those strikes lifted and the breaches of the accord rectified. So much for the self-regulation and the peer group pressure that the Government and the ACTU believe they can exercise. We have had the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association threatening industrial action over a 13 per cent pay claim by public servants. The Government does not appear to have dampened that in any respect, although it is the employer.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we have the infamous Parliament House project, about which more will be said later. What is important is that we recognise now that even in respect of this so-called superannuation claim for the new Parliament House and elsewhere in the country, the big companies are already being forced to pay $10 or $11 over the award. They are paying in breach of undertakings the building unions made to the Arbitration Commission in accordance with the accord. The unions are now being told that perhaps the Commission will not pass on the 4.1 per cent increase because they are in breach. Mr MacDonald, the Building Workers Industrial Union leader, is saying openly that the workers will take industrial action to get the 4.1 per cent increase if the Commission refuses to grant the rise automatically. He is also saying the is is enevitable that the so-called superannuation claim will flow on, and of course it is.

We have seen what has happened with long service leave, which has been granted by State Acts of Parliament. It was meant to be confined to the building industry, but now anyone working on a building site, even if he is simply installing windows, gets long service leave. Of course when he goes back to the factories whence he came, he then has different conditions from other people. It is then a simple matter for the provision to flow through to everybody else. So every maintenance fitter and every electrician on a building site get what the building workers get in superannuation, long service leave or whatever. They go back to their factories and when they are working with their peers they get the same, under the pressures that exist within our structure for comparative wage justice.

This is all in breach of the accord. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has received a report for the week ending 13 April. Eighty-five industrial disputes were major enough to be notified to his Department. Twenty- one of those are in breach of the accord and in breach of the no extra claims undertaking signed by the unions. That is how much the written undertakings mean to the trade union movement and that is how much the accord means. It is a phoney. That is where the public is being mislead. The accord is not working. Even if it were, wage indexation is not wage restraint. The Government has not used its goodwill, it has not used the National Economic Summit Conference to get across the message that wage restraint means that wages can be increased only in line with productivity improvement. An increase in price does not indicate a capacity to pay wages, especially when so much of the price increase is due to government charges, federal and State, which themselves are in breach of the spirit of the Summit communique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can there be a greater example of the panic which has seized the discredited Opposition forces than this matter of public importance? At a time when the economy has shown distinct and positive signs of recovery we have attempts by the Opposition deliberately to reduce confidence in business and in the community by creating false alarms. In this matter of public importance the Government is accused of misleading the Australian people in relation to the state of the economy. That was a cheap remark, unworthy of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) . (Quorum formed) Madam Deputy Speaker, I do not know what the Opposition is afraid of that it has to call a quorum to cut my time. I point out again that this Government has been more open, more consultative and more ready to accept advice on the economy and on industrial matters than any government since the war. I know that this is true because I have been involved in many discussions with industry and trade union leaders in which the Government has been very frank about both the achievements and the problems which remain.

SPEECH.PARA: It is completely dishonest for the Opposition to claim that we have in any way tried to mislead the people in relation to the monumental problems we have been facing. The question that arises is this: Who created the monumental problems? In one year 250,000 people became unemployed. This is the record of the people opposite. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition had the cheek to mention the manufacturing industry, in which 100,000 jobs were lost over two years under his stewardship. This is the sort of thing that has been happening. He says: 'Well, manufacturing employment has not gone up as much as it ought to have gone up and investment has been slower than it ought to have been'. In regard to both of those matters the fact is, as he knows, that it takes a long time to create confidence and to turn the situation around from the discredited policies of the previous Government.

The fact is that any honest person must accept that the Government's record in relation to economic recovery is remarkable. Of course there were certain external factors, such as the drought, but the Opposition has refused to give credence to the stimulatory policy of the Government, to the change in economic policy. One would think, from listening to the former Treasurer, that there has been no change in economic policy and that all that happened was that the drought broke and his discredited wages pause came into effect. The fact of the matter is that the Government has put down a completely different philosophy and policy in relation to the economy from that which existed before, and that policy is working.

Has the Opposition learned any lessons from this? Not at all. I see that the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) has left the House. Indeed he might , because he is about the only one left in the Opposition who has any reasonable position left. The rest of them have moved to the extreme right. We have a situation where even the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) had to say publicly that it was time for the Liberal Party to look again because it has moved so far to the right that it has fallen off the precipice. That is the situation, and who has led members of the Opposition into it? This gentlemen here, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who is the real power in the Liberal Party at present. He has led them to adopt even more extreme and more discredited policies than the ones which have failed in the past. We ask for a reconsideration by the Deputy Leader. He is not a foolish man. We ask him to do something which socialists are used to doing, that is, to partake in self- criticism. How about a little self-criticism from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition? How about his looking at the suffering which his regime created and asking himself why this happened and whether there is some alternative, instead of giving us this ridiculous Liberal Party policy on the economy document which was described by several editorials as absurd. One said it is an amazing document. Indeed, it is amazing.

Madam Deputy Speaker, can you imagine what a solution it would be for the industry problems of this country to sell off the Australian Industry Development Corporation? This is the Opposition's solution to the problems of manufacturing industry. I particularly ask how the policy got through the National Party of Australia, which has obviously lost its way because at least on one point, in regard to giving some support to the manufacturing industry, the National Party did have some basis for a policy. The fact of the matter is that the AIDC was established by Sir John McEwen in order to help plug gaps in industry where private sector investment was down.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly down at the moment.

—I will come to that point. The honourable member says that private sector investment in manufacturing is down, so his solution is to get rid of the AIDC so there cannot be any public sector investment, either. That is the kind of solution to the problems of the manufacturing industry that he puts up. If that were to happen, does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition think business confidence would be re-established? The AIDC plays a very positive role in joint ventures with private enterprise and because of that it gives to private enterprise more confidence to invest. The honourable member for Bennelong talks about getting investment confidence back on the rails but he does not have a clue about how to do that. That is his problem. He seems to think that, no matter what the impirical evidence and no matter what the suffering in this country, he knows all the answers. Even if the facts are staring him in the face he refuses to re-analyse and re-examine his philosophical position. Let me say to him that it does not really matter when the election is held; he will be out of power for a long time while he persists with that position. It is about time he realised that we live in a mixed economy . He talks about the huge public sector in this country but it is one of the smallest public sectors in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, so what is he talking about? Why does he want to reduce the public sector even further? Is it nothing more than ideological blinkered nonsense?

SPEECH.PARA: This whole policy document is so thin that anyone who objectively reads it would know that any group that pretends to go into an election with it must be the thinnest and most discredited group that has ever tried to put anything before the Australian people. It has nothing in it; all it does is attack the Hawke Government's general philosophical strategy on the economy and make claims which are totally wrong. The fact of the matter is that if there had not been an expansionary Budget we would not have been able to pull out of the recession in the way we have. Even Malcolm Fraser realised that right at the end and overrode the former Treasurer in trying to get something done, but it was too late.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the Minister wish to make a personal explanation?
—If it is possible.
—The Minister may proceed.

—Today the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) declared that I said it is not unreasonable that the Vietnamese attack the Khmer Rouge, or people in the coalition, including civilians. I have here a transcript of what I did say, which is considerably different from what the Leader of the Opposition said. I regret that it is a somewhat lengthy quote but it is necessary to get the record correct. In response to a question, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot see any evidence of that-
that is in relation to the allegations in the question-
and nothing I said creates any embarrassment or problems for me. What I did say while Thach was there-
that is, in Australia, during his recent visit-

was at a dinner for him to condemn the continued occupation of Kampuchea by the Vietnamese, to point out as I had done earlier that at least up to that point which I stressed, that there had been no dry season offensive but also added that if the elements of the coalition forces particularly in the Khmer Rouge were to undertake attacks against the Vietnamese one would expect not unreasonably that there would be retaliation and Thach certainly made that clear .

I will not go on with the rest of the quote. What I said was that one would expect, not unreasonably, that there would be a retaliation. However, whether the level, the nature and the extent of the retaliation was reasonable is another thing. I have made it clear elsewhere that we condemn aggression. We particularly condemn the presence of the Vietnamese in Kampuchea and I have condemned attacks on civilians. However, that does not resolve the problem of Kampuchea. Finally, I regret very much that the Leader of the Opposition has been reduced to such dire straits that he is now in the business of professionally misrepresenting what has been said and which can be verified from the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister has made his explanation. He will not debate the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PEACOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented.
—Indeed.
—He may proceed.
—In a question to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time today, I put to him in the last part of the first question I asked relating to Cambodia:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Prime Minister dissociate himself from the remarks reportedly made by his Foreign Minister recently in Tokyo that these actions-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you apologising?
—I certainly am not, for reasons I am about to state.

—I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I draw to your attention the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has not yet shown where he has been misrepresented. I ask you to bring him to the point.
—We are waiting to hear where he has been misrepresented.

—There is a great deal of anxiety on the other side of the House. May I put it to rest? I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in his own personal explanation. I remind the House of what I said at the conclusion of that question on Cambodia to the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Prime Minister dissociate himself from the remarks reportedly made by his Foreign Minister recently in Tokyo that these actions by the Vietnamese forces were 'not unreasonable'?
The Prime Minister did not know what the Foreign Minister had said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is that the Leader of the Opposition's explanation?
—No, it is not.
—The matter is not open to debate.
—Hang on a flash; you listened to the Minister for some time.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will proceed with his explanation, but he will not debate the issue.
—I take your point, Madam Deputy Speaker. The Sydney Morning Herald of 21 April, in an article written by Michael Richardson, contained the following:

SPEECH.PARA: Questioned in Tokyo on Tuesday, Mr Hayden said it was not unreasonable for Vietnamese forces in Kampuchea to retaliate . . .
This statement was also quoted in the Age of 21 April, where Michael Richardson said:
Questioned in Tokyo on Tuesday, Mr Hayden said it was not unreasonable for Vietnamese forces in Kampuchea to retaliate against attacks . . .

This report was filed by Michael Richardson to the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald. The very words I used in my question were 'reportedly made by his Foreign Minister'. If the Foreign Minister could actually recall what he had said he would have got up at the first opportunity at the end of Question Time and put forward the sort of tortuous and rambling explanation that he gave as he read from his statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is now debating the issue. He will resume his seat.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been grievously and painfully misrepresented by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock).
—Impossible.
—A feather sometimes hurts; the Leader of the Opposition did it.
—The Minister may proceed.

—The Leader of the Opposition quoted Michael Richardson as a justification for what he said. Firstly, I did not say 'not unreasonable'-I said 'not unreasonably'-in the context which I have already quoted.
—You said 'not unreasonably', did you? And Michael Richardson had the quote wrong, did he?

—No, in the context in which I used it, which was considerably different from the way in which the Leader of the Opposition has quoted it. More importantly, Michael Richardson was thousands of miles away. He was not even in Tokyo. I suggest that in future the Leader of the Opposition should get a copy of the transcripts of what I have said. I give copies to anyone who asks for them. I will post them to anyone I can think of. No one on my side asks for them . As the Leader of the Opposition now wants them, I will put him on my permanent mailing list.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to make two separate amendments to the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981. The Act determines the amount of general purpose payments to the States in the forms of tax sharing grants and identified health grants until 30 June 1985 and provides for the distribution of the total amount of those grants among the States. The two amendments proposed in this Bill are designed, firstly, to give effect to an agreement with the States, made in the context of the negotiation of the Medicare agreements, that general purpose payments to the States after 30 June 1984 would be reduced by amounts in respect of the operation of Commonwealth pathology laboratories not taken over by the States; and, secondly, to make provision for continuing the payment of general purpose assistance to the States after 30 June 1985 pending the enactment of new legislation to replace the existing Act.

The first amendment corrects an anomaly which goes back to a decision announced by the previous Government at the May 1981 Premiers Conference. At that time the Commonwealth announced its intention to transfer its pathology laboratory operations to the States. As a consequence, an amount was added to the States' tax sharing grants for 1981-82 and subsequent years to compensate them for this additional responsibility. With the exception of Western Australia, however, the States have not taken over the laboratories. The result has been that since 1981 -82 the Commonwealth has effectively funded the operation of the laboratories twice, both by direct funding and indirectly through the tax sharing grants.

At the June-July 1983 Premiers Conference the Commonwealth indicated its intention to remove the anomaly and it was agreed with the States that an appropriate adjustment would be made to apply from 1 July 1984. The Commonwealth 's original proposal was for the adjustment to be made to the Medicare compensation grants specified under the Medicare agreements with each State. Some States, however, indicated that they considered the adjustment to be a matter separate from the establishment of Medicare. The Commonwealth therefore agreed that the adjustment would be made instead to the identified health grants and Medicare agreements were subsequently concluded with all States on that basis. The amount of the adjustment to be made in 1984-85 comprises the amounts agreed at the Premiers Conference increased in accordance with the increase in the consumer price index in 1984-85.

I now turn to the second amendment. The States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 requires that before payments under the Act cease on 30 June 1985 the Commonwealth shall consult with the States to review the provisions of the Act. The States have already been involved in the preparation of terms of reference under which the Commonwealth Grants Commission has commenced a review of the distribution of tax sharing grants amongst the States. The Commission's assessments will form an important element in the negotiation of new arrangements. The Commission is due to report by 30 March 1985.

As consultations with the States on new tax sharing arrangements could not be commenced in detail until after that time, it seems highly unlikely that new legislation to provide for general purpose payments to the States from 1 July 1985 could be introduced into the Parliament until the Budget session of 1985. The amendment now proposed will allow the Treasurer to continue the regular payment of general purpose assistance to the States beyond 30 June 1985 until new legislation comes into force. Payments may be made during the six months from 1 July 1985, with the amount payable being limited to half the amount paid to each State in the previous year. Similar provisions have been made in other legislation involving regular payments to the States including the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1983. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give legislative effect to changes to the income equalisation deposits scheme, first announced in the economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the Parliament of 19 May 1983. Further ministerial announcements on 16 June 1983 and on 23 August 1983 expanded upon the proposed nature of those changes. The income equalisation deposits scheme, as amended, will have no taxation consequences other than the taxation of interest as income . The Government decided to remove the scheme from the tax system to prevent the possibility of its use for tax avoidance and so as to make the benefits accruing from the scheme more evenly available to all primary producers. The old arrangements had a degree of inequity in that producers on the highest marginal tax rate, that is, on the highest incomes, benefited most.

As the provisions of the new scheme have been well publicised already and as the details of the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill 1984 are explained in detail in a memorandum which I have arranged to be circulated, I shall confine my comments to outlining the broad features of the amended scheme. The aim of the scheme is to encourage primary producers to deposit moneys in years when their incomes are high so as to provide funds which can be drawn when incomes are lower. The incentive to make such deposits is an attractive interest rate, set quarterly at two percentage points above the short term Commonwealth Treasury bond rate. The eligibility criteria which determine whether this high rate is received on deposits will be broadly the same as under former arrangements. All primary producers, but only primary producers, are eligible for the higher rate. Deposits can be made up to a limit of a $250,000 deposit stock. Above that, they will not be eligible for the higher rate. In respect of any income year a primary producer may make new deposits which receive the higher rate of interest up to an amount equivalent to the lesser of 60 per cent of gross receipts from primary production in respect of that year and taxable income, other than income derived from property, in respect of that year. A deposit made at the higher rate will continue to receive that rate subject to the Commissioner of Taxation's confirmation of eligibility estimates and as long as the depositor continues in the business of primary production.

The determination of eligibility will be a two step procedure. The first step will be taken by the primary producer, self-estimating the eligible deposit level for his or her current income year. This allows primary producers to take advantage of a current high income year to make deposits at the attractive interest rates.

Interest payments in respect of new deposits will be based essentially on this self-estimation process. Provision is also being made, however, for the Commissioner of Taxation to provide an accurate assessment of the income of depositors and to provide that assessment to the administrator of the scheme, who is to be known as the authorised person. The authorised person will only need to make an adjustment to the interest entitlement of the depositor if the Commissioner's assessment effectively lowers the depositors' eligibility for interest payments at the high interest rate below the level which would otherwise be payable in respect of deposits actually made. Provision is being included to recoup any overpayments of interest which arise from overestimation by the depositor. Unwitting overestimation of income and deposit amounts will not be penalised, other than by recoupment. Furthermore, deposits made as a result of overestimates by primary producers will be able to be withdrawn without penalty immediately the Commissioner of Taxation's determination is known. However, overestimation and deposit with intent to defraud is an offence under the Bill.

The Bill provides for primary producer depositors to retain their ongoing entitlement to the high interest rate if they move in and out of primary production, or change primary production endeavours so long as they are not absent from primary production for a period exceeding 120 days. Of course, new deposits may be made after resumption of primary production beyond that period and they would receive the higher interest rate if the eligibility criteria were then satisfied.

The amendment Bill provides that a depositor is required to notify the authorised person of the cessation of primary production business. Withdrawals from the scheme will be possible on a similar basis as in the past. That is, deposits may be withdrawn at any time after 12 months, or within that time on grounds of financial hardship. Hardship will initially be judged by the authorised person. If the depositor who is claiming hardship is dissatisfied with the initial judgment, he or she may approach the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a ruling.

The impact of the new arrangements on the future levels of deposits and withdrawals is very difficult to project with any degree of accuracy. Deposits have been continuing to ease since 1982. There may have been some natural pause in deposit intake towards the end of, and immediately following, the drought and also during the period of transition between the new scheme coming into effect on 1 September 1983 and the application of this amending legislation. It will be necessary to observe the deposit performance over some period before accurate projections can be made about the longer term trend of deposits.

The level of interest payments will depend on the level of deposits and so they are also very difficult to project accurately. The interest rates applying to the new scheme have been higher than those offered under former arrangements. However unrecouped income tax deductions will be brought to account at the time of conversions and this will offset the cost on the Budget of the higher interest rate.

Furthermore, the new scheme has none of the characteristics which enabled depositors to avoid tax under former arrangements. The difference in administrative cost caused by the changed arrangements is expected to be small.

The new IED scheme has been designed to allow primary producers to deposit funds with the Commonwealth at interest rates higher, and conditions more favourable, than those on Commonwealth securities offered to the general public. This subsidy is intended to motivate primary producers to prepare for lean years but does not enable the wealthy to benefit more per dollar deposited, as did the former scheme. As such, this scheme should be particularly welcomed by smaller primary producers and those concerned with equity in our community. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT (INCOME EQUALIZATION DEPOSITS) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is complementary to the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Amendment Bill 1984 which I have just introduced. In introducing that Bill I outlined the features of the new income equalization deposits scheme which has been developed by the Government and which will operate with effect from 1 September 1983. The new arrangements are far more equitable than the ones they replace and will better serve to encourage primary producers to make due provision for adverse seasons.

The provisions of this Bill are consequential upon amendments of the Loan ( Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976 proposed by the earlier Bill. Their main purpose is to amend the income tax law to make changes to the taxation treatment of income equalisation deposits in harmony with the decision to replace the former tax incentive basis of the scheme with one based on the payment of attractive interest rates on deposits. Accordingly, deposits made after 1 September 1983 will carry no special tax consequences. In particular, the income tax deduction previously allowable for eligible deposits made within specified limits is to be terminated.

In outlining the provisions of the earlier Bill, I made it clear that, under the new arrangements, drought bonds and deposits made before 1 September 1983 may be transferred to the new scheme to enable depositors to take advantage of the special rate of interest payable under that scheme. Consistently with the basis on which income tax deductions were allowed under the former arrangements, where drought bonds or pre-1 September 1983 deposits are converted to the new scheme the amount so converted will be included in the depositor's assessable income of the year of income in which the conversion takes place.

Depositors who apply to convert to the new arrangements within 60 days after the Bill receives royal assent will, for these purposes, be taken to have done so on 1 September 1983. Of course, no amount will be required to be included in assessable income in respect of drought bonds or income equalisation deposits that did not qualify for deduction.

The Bill will also permit the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers to furnish relevant information contained in tax returns to authorised persons involved in the administration of the new IED scheme. This is necessary because eligibility criteria applying to depositors under the new scheme will continue to be based on tax related factors. A technical explanation of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable members. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of the Bill is to amend the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 to modernise the structure of the constituent banks of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and to substantially improve the capital position of the Commonwealth Trading Bank. These amendments were decided upon following a major review of the financial structure and organisation of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation which was conducted by the corporation board and management and the Department of the Treasury.

The structure of the Australian financial system has changed markedly since the Corporation banks were established under the Commonwealth banks legislation passed in 1959. The proposed changes are designed to place the Corporation banks in a position where they will be able to compete on a fully comparable basis with the major private banking and non-banking institutions.

The main provisions of the Bill were foreshadowed in the Press release by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 2 April 1984. A major aspect of the Bill provides for the Commonwealth Savings Bank to become a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth Trading Bank. At present, the Commonwealth Savings Bank and Commonwealth Trading Bank are separate public statutory bodies. Reorganisation on this basis will establish a structure similar to that of the private banking groups and will allow a more effective organisation of the resources of the two banks. This reorganisation will not change the basic functions of the Commonwealth Savings Bank. However, it should allow for an improvement in the range of the services offered by both the trading and savings banks.

Following from this reorganisation, the Bill also provides for the name of the restructured Commonwealth Trading Bank to be changed to the 'Commonwealth Bank of Australia'. This re-establishes the original name of the Commonwealth Bank when it commenced operations in 1912. The name of the Commonwealth Savings Bank will not be changed. The Bill also allows for the capital position of the Commonwealth Bank to be bolstered in order to strengthen its competitive ability and profitability.

In the 1983-84 Budget, the Treasurer announced that there would be an injection of $15m in additional capital into the Commonwealth Bank. This will be effected through the Bill. The Bill also provides for the transfer of $75m from the reserves of the Commonwealth Development Bank to the Commonealth Bank. The transfer of reserves from the Commonwealth Development Bank will still leave the Development Bank with a level of capital and reserves equivalent to the very high ratio of about one-quarter of its liabilities. I would emphasise that this transfer of reserves will not affect the current or prospective operations of the Development Bank. In addition to these measures, I would mention that the Board of the Corporation has also decided that the Corporation and its constituent banks will revalue premises to reflect current market valuations. This will have a substantial positive impact on the capital position of the Commonwealth Bank.

The Bill also provides for the Government to increase the scope available to it in future to add to the capital of the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank through allowing higher retained earnings. The existing statutory provisions require that half of the after-tax profits of the Commonwealth Trading Bank and half of the net profits of the Savings Bank be paid to the Commonwealth. The new provisions will introduce flexibility into the profit sharing arrangements and allow for dividend arrangements more broadly in line with the private banking groups. They provide for the proportion of net profits to be paid by the Commonwealth Bank to be determined by the Treasurer, with a maximum payment of 45 per cent of the net profits of the Commonwealth Bank and its savings bank subsidiary, the Commonwealth Savings Bank. The Savings Bank will pay a dividend to the Commonwealth Bank, and the amount of that dividend in any year will be determined by the Corporation Board. There will continue to be no dividend requirement on the Commonwealth Development Bank.

The Bill also includes specific provisions relating to the present financial year, that is, prior to the main provisions of the Bill coming into effect. Those provisions provide that for the year ending 30 June 1984, the dividend payable to the Commonwealth by the Commonwealth Trading Bank and the Commonwealth Savings Bank shall be determined by the Treasurer but shall not represent more than 45 per cent of net profits. Under the present Act, the Commonwealth Savings Bank, the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, but not the Commonwealth Trading Bank, have been exempt from Commonwealth company income tax. The Bill removes the exemption enjoyed by those banks. However, the Bill does provide for a rebate to be given for any profit sharing payments made by the Commonwealth Savings Bank under the State savings bank amalgamation agreements. Those payments are made on a pre-tax basis and to not provide a rebate would impose an unfair burden on the bank relative to its competitors.

The Bill also provides for a more flexible management and board structure for the corporation banks by removing the statutory general manager positions for the Trading Bank, the Savings Bank and the Development Bank and also the statutory executive committees of those banks. The statutory positions of Managing Director and Deputy Managing Director will however remain. The present Act imposes certain restrictions on the Corporation's employment of graduates. The Bill removes the present age limit and the restriction on numbers of graduates, and allows the Corporation to include graduates of colleges of advanced education and other tertiary institutions. I commend the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1984 to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 4]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On Budget night I introduced into this House a Bill identical in all respects with this Bill. The Budget-night Bill was a revision of an earlier Bill introduced by my colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). Honourable members will recall that both those Bills were passed by this House but defeated in another place. The Bill I am now introducing is designed, as indeed was the Budget-night Bill, to give effect to this Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of bottom of the harbour schemes. In addition, the Bill proposes to strengthen and improve in several identified areas the legislation introduced by the Opposition parties in 1982 to recoup company tax that was evaded by the use of those schemes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as I have said, the present Bill does not vary from the Budget-night Bill and I think it will suffice if I draw honourable members' attention to my second reading speech on introduction of that earlier Bill for an explanation of the main features of this Bill. In that second reading speech I also referred to an amendment of an evidentiary provision in the recoupment tax law that was being made for reasons connected with a constitutional challenge in the High Court of Australia to the validity of the legislation. The amendment proposed to vary the evidentiary provision so that a certificate by the Commissioner of Taxation specifying the amount of a company's liability to company tax would be prima facie, rather than conclusive, evidence. Honourable members will be aware that the High Court recently held unanimously that the substantive provisions of the recoupment tax legislation are constitutionally valid. All members of the Court, however, expressed views that the existing conclusive evidence provision might, at least in part, be invalid. The proposed amendment will ensure that the evidentiary provision is constitutionally valid in all respects.

By re-presenting the measures contained in the Budget-night Bill, the Government again demonstrates its determination to make every effort to give effect to its election commitments in relation to bottom of the harbour schemes. I now give notice that the Government is resolved to press this matter before the Senate and intends that the Opposition parties should stand and be counted by the Australian public for their obstructive attitude on anti-tax avoidance legislation. The measures contained in the Bill are estimated to yield $270m in total, and they deserve to be given the approval of the Parliament. As is usual with amendments of the taxation laws, an explanatory memorandum giving technical details of the amendments contained in the Bill is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

This Bill, like the one I have just introduced, is identical with the Budget- night Bill by the same title. That Bill was passed by this House but was not proceeded with in another place. This Bill will formally impose a tax, to be called dividend recoupment tax, on the dividend amount determined in accordance with the rules being inserted in the recoupment tax legislation by the amendment assessment Bill.

The underlying purpose of the amendments is to recover personal income tax escaped by individual former owners of stripped companies. That will be done in a direct manner wherever possible. However, in cases where former owners held their shares through interposed companies or trusts recovery may in certain circumstances be by way of imposing on one or more of the interposed companies or trusts a tax equivalent to the maximum personal rate of tax applying in the year of income in which the shares in the stripped company were sold. This Bill will impose that tax. I commend the Bill to the House.
