DEBATE.TITLE: SUBMARINE WARFARE SYSTEMS CENTRE, HMAS 'WATSON', SOUTH HEAD, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a Submarine Warfare Systems Centre, HMAS Watson, South Head, New South Wales.

The proposal is for the construction of a new building at HMAS Watson for the Submarine Warfare Systems Centre, which provides operator training for the combat system of the Royal Australian Navy's Oberon class submarine force. HMAS Watson is located on South Head, Sydney, and is a training establishment providing advance courses in tactics, navigation, anti-submarine warfare and training on the fleet's weapons systems. The submarine warfare systems centre is located at HMAS Watson but existing facilities are inadequate and are unable to be extended to overcome present shortcomings and to meet the requirements of the latest weapons systems. Functions to be accommodated in the new facility are tactical development, training including simulators, computer facilities, technical support and administration.

The proposal involves demolition of an existing structure and construction of a three-level building partly set into the site to minimise its height above ground level and impact on the skyline of South Head. The building will be of concrete construction with external finishes designed to match the colour and texture of the natural rock prominent in this area. The proposal has been discussed with State and local government authorities including the Woollahra Council and the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $3,340,000 at November 1983 prices. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is twofold: First, and as a consequence of the Government's decision to provide departments with more flexibility in financial management, to enable the Minister for Finance to exercise a degree of discretion over expenditures to ensure that the greater flexibility so afforded to departmental heads is translated, as far as possible, into more effective and efficient management; and, secondly, to effect minor amendments to the Act in relation to the provisions related to the appointment of the Auditor-General, act of grace payments, audit fees and some machinery matters.

In connection with the primary purpose of the Bill, in December 1983 I advised the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and each Senate Estimates committee of the Government's proposals to consolidate certain administrative appropriations from 1984-85 to permit improved and more flexible financial administration by departments. Those proposals were amplified in the paper I issued on 16 April 1984 entitled 'Budget Reform' and I draw honourable members' attention to Chapter 5-'Financial Management of Government Programs'-of that paper.

In keeping with the intentions I have foreshadowed, it is proposed that Schedule 2 of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), 1984-85 will show, for each department, consolidated appropriations for each of 'Salaries and Payments in the nature of Salary' and 'Administrative Expenses'-that is, as a general rule, at the appropriation subdivision level-rather than the sometimes quite fine detail of proposed expenditures by item that has previously appeared. To enable the continued effective parliamentary scrutiny of departmental estimates, information provided to the Estimates committees on these consolidated votes will, for the time being, continue in essentially the same form and at the same level of itemised detail as in explanatory notes previously provided. However, as indicated in paragraph 3.18 of 'Budget Reform', the Government proposes consultations to improve the basis for parliamentary scrutiny of the Estimates, particularly through the provision of more program-oriented information.

The springboard for consolidating appropriations is the Australian Labor Party' s policy document on 'Labor and Quality of Government'; the impetus for reforms of this kind, however, has come from such authorities as the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure on 'Parliament and Public Expenditure' and the Reid report on the review of Commonwealth Administration.

The move towards greater consolidation of certain appropriations, bringing with it the capacity for departments to respond more effectively to an environment which is constantly affecting spending priorities, particularly in the area of administration, is an important step towards the goal of departments assuming greater responsibility in their financial management. The Government recognises, however, that this enhanced flexibility will have an impact, if only initially, on the way in which departments have traditionally managed their administrative resources and it is important to ensure that this is translated into more effective and more efficient management. It would, therefore, be sensible to retain, particularly during the transitional stages, the ordinary scope for monitoring the extent to which departments may reallocate expenditures within the consolidated amounts appropriated by Parliament. Thus, it is envisaged that such expenditure reallocations should be subject to the agreement of the Minister for Finance or his delegates.

To this end, minor amendments to the Audit Act are necessary. These amendments, which are set out in clause 8 of the Bill, will empower the Minister for Finance to direct that the consolidated amounts approved by parliament be divided into items of expenditure-termed notional items-that accord with the previously agreed estimates; and to approve the reallocation of expenditure between notional items within a subdivision of the Appropriation Act. This process will not, of course, permit the amounts appropriated by parliament to be varied. Moreover, the power to direct notional items will be exercised only to the extent and for the period necessary for departments to adjust effectively and efficiently to the new appropriations.

I turn now to the other amendments before the House. The first, being those at clauses 3 to 6 and clause 15, relate to the appointment of the Auditor-General and associated matters. They bring the legislation into line with current appointment practices and drafting policy. The second noteworthy inclusion in these other amendments is that at clause 9 which will permit the attachment of conditions to payments made under section 34A of the Act. Section 34A of the Act deals with act of grace payments, being discretionary payments which may be made by the Commonwealth, notwithstanding the absence of any legal obligation to do so. For example, under the terms of a social welfare enactment, a person's particular circumstances may not qualify him or her for the receipt of benefits, despite the underlying intentions of the statute. In such circumstances, an act of grace payment, or payments, may be considered justified, pending amendments of the enactment. The Government has been advised, however, that, in such a case , if a person had received dual benefits, that is, as an act of grace payment and subsequently in accordance with a new statutory entitlement that, say, had retrospective effect, no power exists to recover the amount of the act of grace payment. Thus, it is proposed that section 34A of the Act be amended to permit the attaching of conditions to such payments, including a condition of repayment where appropriate. In the event of default by the recipient, the Commonwealth will be empowered to recover the payment by court action, if necessary.

The remaining clauses of the Bill encompass amendments of a minor nature that would otherwise have been included in a Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. These clauses are intended to clarify the provisions relating to the transfer of certain moneys from the credit of the Trust Fund, the levying of fees for certain audits conducted by the Auditor-General and definition of ' approved bank' in relation to statutory authorities' operations; to give recognition to the power to recover by instalments amounts owing to the Commonwealth; and to increase to present day values certain amounts struck in 1979 and specified in the Act in relation to act of grace payments and waiver of debts.

The financial impact of the proposals reflected in this Bill is indirect and not easily quantified. The initial control procedures which are being proposed to apply in the context of consolidated appropriations are not intended to be an end in themselves. Rather, they are to assist and encourage departments to establish quickly the necessary degree of financial management capability to operate within that changed appropriation format. The Government believes that the consolidation of appropriations, especially for departmental administrative expenditures, will promote efficiency and effectiveness in the management and delivery of programs by overcoming the somewhat cumbersome procedures hitherto required to redirect expenditure from one item to another. The new arrangements will also allow departments to respond more rapidly to changing circumstances and priorities in the course of the year. The achievement of these benefits will be accelerated by establishing, from the outset, soundly based control mechanisms that can, progressively, be devolved on departments to administer themselves.

The provisions relating to the appointment of the Auditor-General have no financial implications. The financial impact of the remaining provisions of the Bill should, in practice, prove relatively insignificant. They are primarily supplementary controls included in a piece of legislation-the Audit Act-that is, itself, a controlling statute. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of this Bill is to put into operation the Government's commitment to reactivate the former Curriculum Development Centre within the administrative structure of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. By this means the Commonwealth will have the capacity to provide schools and school systems with curriculum and educational materials, information and expertise. The legislation will also strengthen the integral relationship between curriculum issues, research priorities and the funding and program responsibilities of the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

To achieve its primary purpose the Bill repeals the Curriculum Centre Act 1975 and in doing so abolishes the existing Curriculum Development Centre as a statutory authority. The assets and liabilities of the existing Centre are to be vested in the Commonwealth and will be administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The legislation will establish a new Curriculum Development Council, reporting to the Minister, which will work in close consultation with the Commonwealth Schools Commission. The Chairman of the Commission will have permanent head powers in relation to the staff appointed under the Public Service Act 1922 to assist both the Commission and the new Curriculum Development Council.

In addition to the primary purpose of the Bill, the legislation also updates general provisions in the Commonwealth Schools Commission Act 1973 to take account of current legislative practices. The legislation also provides authority for the Commission to inquire into, and to furnish information and advice to the Minister, with respect to matters affecting the education of handicapped children who have not attained school age.

In accordance with the Government's pre-election education policy this Bill will reverse the decision taken by the Fraser Government to abolish Australia's national curriculum body. The earlier decision, arising from a recommendation of the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions-otherwise known as the Lynch Committee-was made despite considerable public debate and a flood of objections from all quarters of the educational community, including the national parent and teacher organisation. It was a pointless decision given the significant achievements of the Curriculum Development Centre in its all too short history. It was a decision that could not have been made on the basis of any rational educational argument and a decision made all the more remarkable given that the then Minister for Education had only six weeks previously officially opened the Centre's premises with a speech praising at considerable length the Centre's achievements. That decision reflected the Fraser Government' s lack of real concern for the education of our children. In contrast, the Hawke Government is committed to an educational program that will ensure that the greater majority of children in our schools are given a worthwhile and rewarding education. Central to such a goal will be the re-establishment of the Commonwealth's national curriculum role as proposed in this Bill.

One of the main outcomes to be expected from the proposed new arrangements will be a commitment to forge a closer relationship between national curriculum development and the program activities of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This link will be instrumental in enabling the Commission to implement fully the Government's national educational priorities, in particular, to promote curriculum initiatives in such areas as Aboriginal education, the education of girls, computer education, secondary education curriculum renewal and those programs concerned with Australia's multicultural character.

The close links to be forged between the Curriculum Development Council and the Commonwealth Schools Commission will strengthen the capacity of the Commission to bring about long term changes in Australian education. In the immediate future this increased capacity will be evident in the curriculum inputs that will be made to the announced participation and equity and computer education programs.

The cost of reactivating the Curriculum Development Centre is expected to be between $2.5m and $3m a year, less expected revenue from sales of curriculum publications of $500,000 a year. The transfer of curriculum activities presently conducted by the Department of Education and Youth Affairs to the Curriculum Development Council will involve savings in the order of $1.5m a year which will be an offset against the costs of reactivating the Curriculum Development Centre .

The Government's participation and equity program is a cornerstone of our strategies for educational improvement and through this program it will be possible to break down the persisting patterns of disadvantage, those patterns which have made educational outcomes dependent to an unacceptable extent on the socio-economic background of the student or the student's sex, ethnic background and geographical location. The immediate emphasis of the program will be to increase the participation of young people in post-compulsory schooling, particularly Aboriginal people, working class youth, some migrant communities, rural youth and the handicapped. However, in the longer term the Government will be seeking to make education a more challenging and rewarding experience for all children.

The Government's computer education program recognises the need for all students to have an understanding of the uses of new technology and of the impact these new technologies will have on the student's social, environmental, industrial and working life. From the teachers' point of view, there will need to be planning for, and guidance in, the ways in which the computer and related technologies are to be introduced into the curriculum and into the professional development programs of both the practising teacher and the teacher trainee. The promotion of these needs, including the professional development needs of parents and community members, will be a major responsibility of the new Curriculum Development Council.

Achieving these objectives will require the full co-operation of all groups with an interest in education. It will not be an easy task and it is not one that can be left to individual schools or systems. Co-operation, co-ordination and facilitation will be necessary if the initiatives are to have a broad system impact. Central to the process will be the need to give close attention to the school curriculum, in particular, to the curriculum content, structure and organisation. In this demanding task there is a clear need for national initiative and this is being provided for in the provisions of this Bill.

Among the initiatives that will need pursuing on the wider national front will be such issues as credentialling and assessment procedures, the analysis of curricula, the consideration of alternative organisational and structural patterns, the retraining of teachers, changes in teacher attitudes, the design and development of new courses and, very importantly, the improvement of school- community relations and community attitudes towards both education and the outcomes of education.

The Labor Party and Labor governments have traditionally been concerned with justice and equity. We have a commitment to creating a more equal society where each person can achieve their full potential. In education this means we are committed to assist schools to give a positive and effective education to all children, and to make substantial progress towards the more equal distribution of other outcomes of education such as access to paid employment and higher education. We believe there is an urgent need to encourage all children to obtain a full twelve years of education and thereby to increase participation in tertiary education and in the country's capacity to adapt to, and make significant contributions to, technological change. At the present time too many of our children are leaving school without completing an adequate level of education and without developing those skills that will enhance their opportunities for satisfying employment. It is also true that of those children who are leaving early a disproportionate number are coming from working class and disadvantaged groups.

In response to this situation the Hawke Labor Government has a long term goal to ensure that most young people complete a full secondary education, either in a school or in a technical and further education institution, or in some combination of work and education. Achieving this goal will require far reaching initiatives paramount among which will be the curriculum reforms I have already mentioned.

The interest of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) in the education of girls and of Aboriginals is well known and the re-activation of the former Curriculum Development Centre will be a vital element in the Government's policies in these areas. It is only recently that there has been a widespread recognition that schooling was not preparing girls for the economic and social realities of adult life. We do not yet have a comprehensive history of schooling for girls in Australia and that is significant in itself. We know that over the greater part of our history there have been major differentiations between the schooling offered to girls and boys, except for that minority of girls who followed an academic path traditionally designed for privileged males. In Aboriginal education the situation is no better. It is only recently that Aboriginal history and culture has been considered a legitimate study in our schools. Virtually all of us here were treated to the history of the world and of Australia from a British perspective. This Bill will enable the Government to take positive steps to set about redressing these imblances. In the same way that Aboriginals and girls have been limited in the benefits that they may derive from education and in the contributions they may make to the development of our country so too have several other groups including other ethnic groups and the handicapped. The multicultural nature of Australian society and the rights of all persons is still not adequately understood nor reflected in current educational practices.

The Labor Government acknowledges the diversity of the contributing cultures in Australia and it will be expecting the new Curriculum Development Council to contribute to the development and dissemination of curricula that acknowledges this diversity and provides a perspective of Australia as a nation in the Asia- Pacific region. The challenge ahead of us is to turn schools, and the formal education system, into places and experiences which young people will really enjoy and find value in. We need to reaffirm the traditional and positive concern of schooling with the development of the individual, and to place less stress on the function of school as a social sorting system. It is a debasement of the purposes of education to use schools as a weeding out device. They should not be places where for many students their main experience is one of frustration and inadequacy.

This is not to downplay academic achievement and high educational standards and , indeed, the Government fully recognises the need to improve the education and preparation of those who are moving into higher levels of education. However, this must not be done at the expense of the many students for whom schooling is the route to gainful employment and a satisfying adult life. The objective must be to provide a satisfying and demanding education for all students. The Hawke Government believes that this objective will be achieved if the Commonwealth supports school curriculum and practice in a positive and direct way. Such support should build upon the intellectual and social resources of students and their school communities and give to students the confidence and understanding necessary to shape individually and collectively the circumstances of their own lives.

In the curriculum context the emphasis will be on the Commonwealth, through the Curriculum Development Council, taking a positive stance in co-ordinating, facilitating and in broad terms supporting the development of curriculum strategies in association with existing curriculum groups throughout the country . The aim will be to achieve increased co-operation and understanding between the Commonwealth and the States, to extend the involvement of teachers and parents in the curriculum process and to expand co-operation between all sectors of the educational fabric.

Through such endeavours the Government is confident that all Australian children whatever their economic, social, ethnic or geographical background will be able to enjoy as near as practicable an equal and worthwhile educational opportunity. In proposing that the Commonwealth play a positive role in this process the Government fully recognises that State governments have the prime responsibility for education. However, the Government believes it is possible, and indeed highly desirable, for the Commonwealth to participate and for the Curriculum Development Council to work in partnership with the States in building on the work now being done in the States and to seek ways of co- operatively developing new approaches to traditional subject matter as well as new subjects, new organisational and structural patterns, and forms of teaching and learning that will make school a more interesting and constructive experience for all students. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Stand-by Duties) Bill 1984 which is now before the House is to permit the Government to impose, in certain circumstances , a Customs duty on imported light crude oils. Last year, the Government took steps to ensure that the maximum practicable level of indigenous crude oil is absorbed by the Australian refining industry. In this context, the Government announced its intention to prepare the legislation now before the House.

This Bill provides that two requirements be met by the Minister for Resources and Energy before a Customs duty on certain imported oils may be imposed. The first requirement is that the Minister for Resources and Energy has published a gazette notice informing the public that, in the national interest, the rate of absorption of Australian crude oils during a year or other period should not be less than the amount specified in the notice. The second requirement is that the Minister for Resources and Energy forms the opinion that the rate at which Australian crude oil is being absorbed is, because of factors under the control of oil refinery owners, less than the rate specified in the gazette notice. In this circumstance, the Minister for Resources and Energy may convey his opinion in writing to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The Bill provides, however , that such correspondence will not occur earlier than two months after the commencement date specified in the notice.

If the requirements I have just outlined are satisfied, the Minister for Industry and Commerce may make a declaration by gazette notice, thus enabling the imposition of an additional duty on certain imported oils. The Bill also specifies that any additional duty shall not exceed a rate of 3c per litre or approximately $5 per barrel; cannot be applied to certain exempt oils; may be varied or revoked by the Minister for Industry and Commerce by a declaration published by gazette notice. I might also add that declarations imposing or varying the additional duty must be tabled in both Houses of Parliament.

There is a long history of government policy in relation to the absorption of crude oil. Since oil was first produced in Australia in the late 1960s, governments of both political persuasions have adopted policies aimed at ensuring that all available Australian crude oil is absorbed in Australian refineries. Traditionally the refining industry has imported crude oil to make up the rest of its requirements. In 1983, however, for the first time Australian crude oil appeared to be in a state of 'technically' surplus in that available production was being shut in while imports were continuing at relatively high levels. This situation arose as a result of a variety of pressures, including the price of available spot market crudes. In the context of the parlous economic situation which confronted this Government in 1983 it was decided that it was essential to maximise the production of Australian crude oil and hence its contribution to government revenues. This was achieved through two complementary policies-exports of surplus production have been allowed on a spot basis during 1983-84 and a minimum absorption level for Australian refiners has been nominated. The success of this policy is clear. Production levels of Gippsland crude oil have been at record levels in recent months. Aggregate production over the financial year to date is currently some 60,000 barrels a day higher than in 1982-83. Most of this increase has resulted from increased levels of absorption by Australian refiners although exports have made a significant contribution. All available production from other fields has been absorbed by Australian refiners.

The Bill provides a standby measure. Whether or not an import duty is imposed will depend largely on the efforts of refiners to maintain liftings of domestic crude at satisfactory levels. The Government will refrain from implementing the legislation as long as Australian oil refiners continue to lift domestic crude oil at an acceptable rate. Details of the guidelines which the Government will use to assess whether the target will be met have been prepared and distributed to the refiners. An assessment that the import duty may be necessary would require two conditions to be met. First, aggregate domestic liftings would need to be below the target rate in two consecutive months and, secondly, the Minister for Resources and Energy considered that the minimum target rate for the specified period is unlikely to be attained. If the performance of the refiners continues to reflect the Government's target the imposition of additional duties will not be needed. In the event that the standby duty is required, its financial impact will depend on the circumstances and the performance of the refinery industry against the nominated target.

The Bill provides for topped crudes and the other heavy refinery feedstocks suitable for the production of lubricating oil, bitumen and fuel oil to be exempt from the duty as these products cannot be obtained from the light Australian crude oils. Imports of naphtha, a feedstock for the petrochemical industry, are also exempt. Imports of refined products which require no further processing before final sale are also exempt in order to ensure that extra costs are not added to the northern and north-western regions of Australia which are solely dependent on imported refined products. However, it would be a matter of concern to the Government if this exemption for refined products were to lead to an increase in imports of refined products, prejudicing the absorption of Australian crude oil. Should the legislation be invoked, this matter will be kept under review. The Minister for Resources and Energy will determine whether the level of liftings is consistent with the achievement of the absorption target. After imposition of the penalty duty the Bill provides for variation in the rate of duty as well as for its revocation. This would occur when the level of liftings had improved to a level consistent with achieving the nominated absorption target. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr John Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to amend the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Act 1980 to extend the operation of the liquefied petroleum gas subsidy scheme to 31 March 1987 in a modifed form. During the extended period, eligibility for the subsidy will remain unaltered but the subsidy rate will be based upon a wholesale price for LPG as determined by the Minister for Resources and Energy. Proposed section 6A(4) in clause 5 of the Bill sets out the factors to be taken into account in the determination of this wholesale price.

The use of LPG in automotive, petrochemical, mining of oil and gas or the refining of petroleum remains ineligible for the subsidy. Users who converted to LPG after 25 September 1981 will continue to have their eligibility for subsidised LPG restricted to 1,000 tonnes per annum unless they have been issued with a determination under section 7A of the Act.

Under the new arrangements the subsidised wholesale price for LPG will be linked to movements in the fuel and light component of the consumer price index. From now on the rate of the subsidy will be calculated by subtracting from the determined wholesale price per tonne of LPG the amount that was the subsidised price for the preceding six monthly period adjusted in accordance with movements in the fuel and light component of the CPI. The related formula is set out in clause 5 of the Bill. For the period from 29 March 1984 to 30 September 1984 the determined wholesale price will be $244.75 per tonne and the subsidised price per tonne will be $224.44. This means that the rate of subsidy will be $20.31 per tonne.

These new arrangements which have been determined as a result of a review of LPG pricing and subsidy should result in many consumers paying less and no consumers paying more for their LPG and reticulated gas requirements. Under the Government's pricing policy which determines the wholesale price of LPG the wholesale price was reduced from $304.44 per tonne to $244.75 per tonne on and from 29 March 1984. This is a reduction of about 20 per cent.

In the course of the review some 200 submissions and representations were received from State and local governments, from industry and from consumers. The revised LPG pricing and subsidy arrangements decided upon by the Government are designed to meet the principal concern raised in many submissions-that is, that the price of LPG should be stabilised and price movements made more predictable. It is intended that a further review of the subsidy be conducted early in 1987. A number of submissions proposed that the subsidy should be continued at $80 per tonne. Because future movements in LPG prices will be more in line with movements in prices of other forms of energy such as electricity and natural gas the Government is of the view that it would be inequitable to subsidise LPG to this extent.

Since the subsidy was introduced in 1980, the subsidised wholesale price has risen by 80 per cent compared with an increase in average retail electricity and natural gas prices of roughly equal magnitude. The cost of energy in all its forms has significantly increased in recent years and the Government believes that it would be unreasonable to exempt one set of consumers from the general movements in prices by a large subsidy financed from govenment revenue.

The continuation of the modified subsidy scheme for a further three years will alleviate future sharp increases in the price of LPG which would be faced by consumers if the subsidy were withdrawn. Administrative arrangements for payments of the subsidy will not vary to any great extent. Claimants will however be advised by the Department of Industry and Commerce of any revised procedures.
Financial Impact Statement
The cost of extending the subsidy is expected to be $1.2m for the 1983-84 financial year, and about $7.2m for 1984-85. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Uren, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Under section 4A of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, the Commissioner of Taxation is required by the end of July each year, to make a determination as to the amount of personal income tax collections which is used as the basis for local government tax sharing arrangements. Prior to the introduction of the prescribed payments system, which operates under Division 3A of Part VI of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Regulations, collections of tax payable on income to which that system now applies, were reflected in the amount of provisional tax and balances of tax payable that were collected in a particular year of income, and which are specifically included in the definition of personal income tax in the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976.

The purpose of this Bill is to make amendments consequential upon the introduction of the prescribed payments system to allow payments made under that system to be taken into account in the personal income tax which forms the basis of local government tax sharing. Without these amendments to include specifically the appropriate part of collections of prescribed payments system deductions, that is, collections from individuals in the year in which they are received, the amount of net personal income tax collections forming the basis of local government tax sharing arrangements would in future be permanently reduced by the amount of those prescribed payments system deductions.

The reason for this is that, in the year following their receipt, prescribed payments system deductions will reduce both the amount of tax otherwise to be collected on an assessment of the income of the preceding year, and the amount of provisional tax to be levied in respect of the then current year. Such a result would not only be contrary to the intended basis for local government tax sharing arrangements, but it would also be inconsistent with the tax sharing arrangements with the States which include prescribed payments system deductions in the base on which the tax sharing amount is calculated.

The amendments are essentially technical amendments designed to maintain the original intention of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976; to ensure consistency with the provisions of the tax sharing arrangements and to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to include receipts received in 1983- 84 in the base figure for calculation of the 1984-85 grants to local government.
Financial Impact Statement

It is estimated that the amendments will allow an additional $2m to $3m to be paid to local governments under the income tax sharing arrangements for the 1984 -85 financial year. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.
