SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying when the debate was adjourned before lunch, there are some worthwhile measures in this Bill, such as that allowing for the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the decision of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The principal drive of the Bill is not to make Australian citizenship more important or more valued but to make it quicker, easier, duller and cheaper. The Minister and the Government are taking steps which the Australian public does not want to see taken. I think that has come out in the last few days in the controversy aroused by Professor Geoffrey Blainey, a controversy which I am sure has caused Professor Blainey some distress. I think that the Minister was right to point out that total Asian migration is very small. I am sure also that the Asian migrants will be either good citizens or decent workers. But it is foolish for the Minister to speak of Australia as being Asianised when Australia is and must be a European civilisation, with traditions, customs and institutions which are European, with its main sources being Britain, Southern Europe and Eastern Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: The people value these deep and historic traditions and institutions and are alarmed when they hear Ministers of the Crown dismissing them and talking as if they did not exist. They rightly see in the Minister and in the Government a prejudice against Britain, Eastern Europe and Southern Europe. I think Professor Blainey is to be congratulated for having broken an unnecessary taboo and for having raised the issue and opening it for discussion instead of it remaining under an unnecessary taboo. It is plain that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in effect agrees with Professor Blainey. In the speech he made a week or so ago to the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils he agreed that the change in pattern is as a result of the application of the current Government's family reunion program. I think Professor Blainey should be congratulated, rather than have criticism poured on him, for opening this subject up for discussion and for breaking the unnecessary taboo.

The same situation applies with Australian citizenship, which Australians take seriously, just as they take their European traditions seriously. They are alarmed when the Minister treats Australian citizenship lightly, as obviously he does. They do not see merit in making Australian citizenship quick and easy. They do not want cut-price citizenship. They do not want no-frills Australian citizenship, yet that is what the Minister and this Government are offering them .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -I am concerned about the way the Opposition has conducted itself in this debate . It has missed the fact that the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill gives effect to the Government's commitment to ensure that the Australian Citizenship Act reflects the common national identity of all Australians and that it does not discriminate between persons on the basis of their sex, marital status and present or previous nationality. We are concerned that the Act should provide for reviews of decisions to deny or deprive persons of citizenship. We want to amend the Act to ensure that it is thoroughly Australian in character.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has had regard to the review of citizenship by the Human Rights Commission in 1981 and the national consultations on the Act undertaken by the previous Administration in 1982. As a result, we included measures to eliminate various anomalies, reduce subjectivity in criteria of assessment for eligibility for citizenship, and sought to clarify and simplify administrative requirements and to remove redundancy provisions. We are doing all this to assist the 1.1 million people in Australia who as permanent residents are eligible for citizenship but who have not yet applied to take it out. We are doing quite well . For most of the year the Hawke Labor Government has been in power the applications went up by 20 per cent. We hope that this legislation will assist that trend to continue.

At the outset of my reply to this debate I should comment on the abysmally poor quality of the Opposition's argument against the major measures in this Bill. It is the most significant piece of amending citizenship legislation since 1949. The Opposition has absolutely refused to debate the major measures in the Bill. It has reneged on its responsibility to debate the real issues involved with citizenship applications and it has reneged on its responsibility to a multicultural Australia. Virtually all of the speakers from the Opposition concentrated on the alleged bias in the proposed changes to the oath of allegiance. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), made a number of allegations. He said that we had no mandate to effect these changes. I draw his attention again to the consultations that were conducted by the former Government. Many of those recommendations have been picked up in this Bill. Virtually all the major changes in this Bill, including the changes to the oath of allegiance and the removal of the British subject status as a criteria for Australian citizenship, were flagged in our policy commitments before the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they were not.

—They were, and I invite the honourable member to look at the information that was published at the time. I took great note of what the shadow Minister was saying in his speech on the second reading debate. It was only in the last eight minutes of a half-hour speech that he attempted to address the real issues in this Bill, and then he mentioned only two. With eight minutes to go he mentioned the fact that we were going to reduce the qualifying time and reduce the English language requirement, including exempting people who are over 50 years of age from the English language requirement. It was only in the last three minutes that he said that he supported most of the major changes being made in this Bill. So it was only in the last three minutes that the House finally discovered that the Opposition was in favour of virtually everything in the Bill, except the oath of allegiance and the British subject status, on which members of the Opposition saw fit to concentrate for the whole of their speaking time. I am sorry to say that with few exceptions the large number of speakers from the Opposition exhibited a very lamentable degree of political opportunism towards this very serious subject which concerns multicultural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address some of the few points that were made by the Opposition speakers . The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) actually called for Australian citizenship to be made a great deal harder to obtain. He said that we ought to see that greater benefits go to naturalised Australians than to permanent residents. I wonder how well that will be received by the virtually millions of people who are in Australia as permanent residents. Some 1.1 million are already eligible for citizenship but there are many more who are not yet eligible. Perhaps the low point in the debate, as far as the Opposition's abysmal performance was concerned, was when the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) said that, as 81 per cent of Australian people believed in God, he must rise to his feet to protest at my decision to make the reference to God optional . I must say that I do not profess to have the divine power to make God optional but obviously what he meant was that I and the Government were introducing in this Bill something which was not previously in operation. Of course that is not true. In the current legislation applicants for citizenship have the right to make either an affirmation or an oath. This Bill removes the necessity to swear allegiance to the monarchy but we have not removed the right to make a pledge in line with a person's religious beliefs. The position will be exactly the same as it is now. So I assure the migrants of Australia that the honourable member for Wakefield is wrong and that I am not attempting to make God optional.

Perhaps the contributions of members of the National Party of Australia were the worst of all. They showed that they were prepared to ignore this nation's own political and social history, because we really are a nation of immigrants whether the National Party likes it or not. The propensity that they showed during the debate to hark back to the so-called benefits of anglophilism simply does not go over at all well with the many non-English speaking migrants who have come to join us from other lands. Members of the National Party just refuse to accept the fact that we have seen successive great waves of immigrants join us, particularly since the Second World War.

Only two honourable members from the Opposition attempted to address the major measures in the Bill, for at least part of their addresses. At least that showed they had taken the trouble to read the Bill. Apart from the shadow Minister, who I think did know something about it-he chose not to exhibit that knowledge, by speaking for 27 minutes about the oath of allegiance and 3 minutes on the major parts of the Bill-only the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), the last speaker, showed that they had any knowledge of the Bill, thus exhibiting the fact that they had taken the trouble to read it. I certainly do not agree with the closing comments of the honourable member for Wentworth because the Government is not, and I have never said it is, attempting to Asianise Australia. I have said that Professor Blainey is wrong when he says that we are anti-British and pro-Asian. We are simply practising non-discriminatory assessment policies on a global level according to our family reunion, business migration and skilled labour programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same thing.

—No, it is not. What the honourable member really means if he is saying that is that he agrees with Blainey, that if those programs provide a result that he does not like, he would have us alter the programs themselves; that is to say, in his view the family reunion program provides too many Asians, we will have to alter that program because there is something inherently bad about Asians. We say the family reunion program is worth while in its own right and that all permanent residents of Australia have rights under that program, regardless of whether they come from Asia or Britain. That is the crux of the argument. We do not see a need to change our humanitarian policies simply because they might be providing just a few more Asian people. If honourable members really want to do their sums on the matter, this whole stupid and trite debate is a misrepresentative one as it is about whether we take 7,000 or 8,000 more people from Asia in a program each year of, say, 70,000 to 80,000 people.
—The sums don't matter; it is the trend.

—Oh, it is the trend. We are having a great argument about whether we take 8,000 more Asian poeple than we did last year. Of course the very people who criticise that would be the people who would go out in the community and support what we say about becoming enmeshed in the economics of the South East Asian region. I would like to know how we could say to all the Asian nations, from Japan through to, say, Indonesia, that we do not really want their people coming to Australia but we are quite happy to get as much trade from them as it is possible to get.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I was pleased to see that a large number of speakers from the Government ranks were prepared to debate the real issues. I note that the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear), the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard), the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous), the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), the honourable member for Diamond Valley (Mr Staples), the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Canning ( Ms Fatin), the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) all made significant contributions to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You gagged Kalgoorlie because he is an anti-republican.

—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie would have been quite welcome to speak but unfortunately he probably did not realise the debate was resuming exactly when it did. No one at all was gagged. Let me quickly repeat some of the major measures in this Bill which members of the Opposition failed to debate. They refused to take up the challenge and concentrated on two matters, the first of which was the oath of allegiance. I do not apologise to the Opposition for this measure. This is one of the most striking features of a Bill which now makes the Australian Citizenship Act thoroughly Australian in character. The declaration of allegiance made at the time that Australian citizenship is granted is quite properly regarded as being of singular importance to many people. The present renunciation of allegiance is ambiguous and does not make it clear whether people are being asked to renounce their previous nationality, their previous language or their culture, or all three. Further, wording of the renunciation should make it clear that it is only allegiance as a citizen to one 's former state or nation that is being renounced. The two proposed forms of the pledge of citizenship will allow all people to make a full commitment of allegiance to Australia, whatever their views on religion. Neither form differentiates between Australians on the basis of their attitude to the monarchy. The monarchy should not be a matter of division. Although I believe the Opposition is making some progress in its attitude to this so-called Asianisation debate and is moving more towards a correct bipartisan position, there is no question that its attitude on the oath of allegiance is directly aimed at causing division in the community when all that the Government is trying to do is provide a pledge of allegiance to the nation and the Constitution of Australia that will be non-divisive and equally attractive to all people who may wish to take out citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, the Opposition has tried to make political capital out of the very necessary move to repeal the British subject criterion as a basis of defining Australian citizenship from the Act. As I have said, the fact is that no other Commonwealth nation still describes its citizens as being British subjects; why should Australia? Even the British themselves do not do that now. We will give the States, and Commonwealth departments too, for that mater, time to make any consequential amendments, such as will be necessary now to the Public Service Act. No doubt some State legislation will need to be amended in line with this decision to remove the British subject definition of Australian citizenship. We do not propose to proclaim this section of the Act until the States and the Commonwealth, have their acts together, so to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Act or Acts?

—There will be a number. I will come to the attitude of the States in a moment. In regard to both of these matters, the pledge of allegiance as it is now and the removal of British subject status from the Act, there is absolutely no intention at all to discriminate against or attack British settlers. Its purpose is simply to provide equality under the law to all migrants from any land. So it is not a matter of discriminating against the British; it is a matter of removing discrimination against migrants who are non-British.

SPEECH.PARA: Very little was said, although there was some mild criticism, of the residence requirement. The fact is that the Bill reduces the qualification period for citizenship by grant from three years to two years. It also proposes to relax the continuous residence requirement from 12 months immediately preceding the application to 12 months in the previous two years. This change recognises the increasing difficulty which the current requirement can cause to people in a world which is increasingly mobile. I might also say that the effect is to compress the time required to be spent in Australia over a more recent period, because previously it was three years out of eight.

Another matter very briefly addressed by some Opposition speakers was the English language requirement. We accept that knowledge of English is essential to full participation in Australia's social, cultural and political life. This Bill seeks to strike a balance between a desirable knowledge of English and giving an opportunity to those who have lived in Australia for some time and who cannot speak English very well but would take pride in becoming citizens. We therefore propose that applicants for citizenship should have a basic knowledge of English rather than an adequate knowledge, which is currently required under the Act. It is not all that much different in practice.

I have been asked by certain members of this House and the Senate to spell out what is meant by 'basic English'. We will be very pleased to put down exactly the policy guidelines on what 'basic English' means. I think I can say that applicants will need to be able to discuss verbally the rights and privileges of Australian citizenship, but they will not be required to be able to read or write English. To ensure a consistency of interpretation of meaning, my Department is already developing guidelines. These guidelines will be published and made available to the public, as with other guidelines, in the citizenship handbook. I hope that the Opposition will give us its support on the exemption of those who are now over 50 years of age. (Extension of time granted) One of the most progressive aspects of the Bill is the provision for review of decisions to deny or deprive citizenship. There was virtually no reference to this matter from members of the Opposition, so I expect they all support it. It is consistent with the Government's support for external review. Clause 36 of the Bill proposes to insert new section 52A, which will give the Administrative Appeals Tribunal power to review on merit certain citizenship decisions. A whole range of decisions can be reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support them.
—I do not actually remember the honourable member referring to his very complete support of this section of the Bill.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, we have already indicated our support and, to save the Minister time, we support the Government's further amendments.
—Members of the Opposition have simply refused to debate some other matters in the Bill, which I also hope they support. Sex discrimination has been removed from the current Act.
—We support that.

—That is very good. Not one of the Opposition speakers accepted or even noted that under current legislation an adopted child must receive citizenship by grant. This Bill will enable automatic acquisition of citizenship by a child on the granting of an adoption order.
—We support it. We support in vitro as well.

—What is all the fuss about then? Apparently there is nothing in the Bill that the Opposition does not support. It has taken a terribly long time to come to that conclusion and has wasted a lot of hot air to show that it supports virtually everything that is in the Bill.
—You either did not listen to my speech or you cannot read.
—Order! I ask the Minister to ignore the interjections.

—I will now inform the House of the attitudes of the States to this Bill . It may be of some interest to such a determined States' righter as the honourable member for Denison. At the Federal-State Ministers conference last June, the States were informed of the basic thrusts of this Bill. I told the Ministers then that we would introduce it and await their comment. I introduced the Bill in December 1983 and sent all the relevant material to all State Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs matters. I received written communications from all the States. In early April 1984 at a Federal- State Ministers conference held in Brisbane I discussed their replies. The only substantial dissent on anything came from the Queensland and Tasmanian governments, which raised the matter of the alteration to the pledge of allegiance.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland raised a very moderate degree of opposition to the reduction in the qualifying time from three years to two years. No other problems of any consequence were raised by any of the States at the Federal-State conference to show that the Ministers were not satisfied with my explanations. I reiterated that they would be given time to effect any consequential amendments in their State legislation before we would proclaim the Bill.

I hope that this Bill, which contains the greatest and widest amendments of a far-reaching nature to the Chifley Government's 1948 Australian Citizenship Act, which created Australian citizenship for the first time, is passed unaltered by this House and the Senate and comes into law as quickly as possible. I am certainly quite proud to be the Federal Labor Minister who has had the honour of introducing these changes. I am pleased at least to note that, although the Opposition does not support everything in the Bill, it has indicated that it supports approximately 90 per cent of it.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Hodgman's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 11-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Professor Geoffrey Blainey was completely correct when he described the present Hawke socialist Government as the most anti- British government in Australia's history. If ever we have seen it clearly and positively identified, we see it in relation to clause 7 of the Bill whereby the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), urged on by his socialist republican colleagues, has completely taken out Part II of the principal Act. Part II of the principal Act deals with British subjects. I refer to that part of the Act briefly to indicate once again the paranoia and the hatred that the Hawke socialist Government has for anything British or anything relating to Britain from the Queen down.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members are the most extraordinary bunch of hypocrites one could ever meet in one's life. They are royalists when they are in England. They put their arms around the Queen Mother and they play with Prince William. But when they come back to Australia they want to stab the knife deep into the back of the Queen. Each and every one of them stands condemned for their double standards and duplicity because not one of them can take a seat in this Parliament without taking an oath of allegiance or an affirmation of allegiance. In a few minutes they will vote to stab the Queen of Australia in the back. Before they do that they will vote to discriminate against every British migrant in Australia today. By taking Part II out of the principal Act, the Minister will achieve one of his main objectives. He is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. He seems to forget that the largest ethnic groups in Australia today are the British, Commonwealth and New Zealand migrants. I have never heard this Minister utter one word of approval or support for British, Commonwealth or New Zealand migrants. Quite frankly, the trouble with the Minister is that he is well and truly under the thumb of a small and totally unrepresentative group. I have had the opportunity of meeting Miss Franca Arena. She might be a charming person but she is dangerous. She has this Minister under her thumb. Regarding Part II of the Act, the removal of which the Minister has been dreaming about ever since he got the position, he has declared war on every British migrant in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense!

—I do not know what the loyalties of the honourable member for La Trobe were when he was in Britain, but after what he said in this chamber today I would not like to go into battle alongside him. I could not be sure on which side he would finish up. I put it to him quite bluntly: It is extraordinary that some of those who are quickest to stab the Queen in the back came from some parts of the United Kingdom. Now the status of the British subject is to be ripped out of the Act. Prime Minister Whitlam was no Anglophile. Prime Minister Whitlam did not move to drag out of the Australian Citizenship Act the provisions relating to British subjects, but this Government has. What is more, it has led the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the nose through this maze. At the moment he probably thinks it is good to let the socialist Left get a win on one or two issues. I predict that this immigration policy will be one of the major issues in the next Federal election and that it has already cost the Government unknown tens of thousands of votes.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn specifically to clause 7 of the Bill. In that clause this anti-British, anti-European Government, has its great moment of victory because it will rip out the provisions concerning British subjects. Let me inform the Committee what else the Government has done. Late last year the Minister said-on behalf of the Opposition I supported him-that we wished to encourage a removal of the dichotomy between British and non-British residents in Australia. When the Government brought an amendment to the Migration Act before the Parliament we supported that amendment to take away that dichotomy. When the Government said that it wanted people to become Australia citizens we supported it but what did it do to the British subjects in Australia, many of whom have been in this country for up to 40 years but have not yet taken out Australian citizenship? The Government said to those people: 'Unless you put your name on the roll by six o'clock on 25 January 1984 you will lose forever your right to cast a vote in the country you have chosen as your home and in which you pay your taxes. That will occur unless you become an Australian citizen'.

Having done that, what did the Government do then? It did not even advertise in all the British and Commonwealth publications in Australia. I cite a good example. The Government did not even advertise in the Maltese Herald. The Maltese, believe it or not, are proud of the fact that they are British subjects . They are proud of the fact that their island was awarded the George Cross. They are proud of the fact that they have had the opportunity to come to this country. The Government advertised selectively, and I suggest that it probably disenfranchised a quarter of a million Australians by what it did. Those people are already resenting it. I cannot believe that any British migrant in this country will ever vote for the Australian Labor Party again after what it has done to them today.

The other relevant point concerning Part II is that, in dealing with the status of British subjects, the Government is not only taking away what they had and bringing them back to square one, it is also positively discriminating against them. It is a positive disadvantage to be a British subject if one wants to migrate to Australia. Let me give an example. Only six months ago the Minister expelled from this country a young British journalist who was in Australia working on a visa. He wanted to apply for permanent resident status. He was told that despite the fact that the newspaper wanted him and he wanted to work for it , he had to go all the way back to England and make an application. That young man has now been told that he will have to wait 12 months before his application will be considered. Why is the Government discriminating against European migration? The Government has cut it by 22 per cent. If the Government believes that that is not upsetting Italian and Greek constituents in every part of Australia it is not doing its homework.

The plain fact of the matter is that this Minister heads a Government whose policy is deliberately discriminatory and positively biased against British and European migration. He has now declared war on behalf of the Hawke socialist Government against every British migrant. I place on record, on behalf of Her Majesty's loyal Opposition-and we are-that we will be demonstrating right throughout the electorate over the next few months. The Government might think it is safe, that its actions will not come to the notice of the people in the electorates, but they will. Every British migrant in this country will know that today, 2 May, one day after May Day, the Hawke socialist republican Government declared war on every British migrant living in this country. The Hawke Government will take tax from those people but it will give them nothing in return. Shame on the Government. This is a black day for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join briefly in the consideration of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. Some of the rantings of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who has just spoken, were far from the truth of this legislation. The present Government is not anti anyone. Indeed , the present Government is attempting to ensure that some equity is put back into the immigration laws in Australia. We all know that the honourable member for Denison is a terrible lawyer. In the debate on this legislation a few weeks ago he demonstrated his inability to understand what is in the Australian Constitution. We now find that he did not even receive any attention in his own Party room when his Government, under the previous Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, proposed amendments to the Migration Act.

SPEECH.PARA: If the honourable member for Denison had been awake and had taken any interest in the immigration debate in this Parliament over the years he has been a member , prior to becoming the Opposition shadow Minister, he would have known that previous governments deported many migrants who came to Australia on a visitors' visas and applied for permanent residence. In my electorate of Grayndler, which has one of the highest proportions of migrants of any electorate in the country, I would have had at least two or three cases a week under the previous regime where the Minister was refusing permanent residence to people who had come to Australia on visitors' visas. The honourable member for Denison knows that that is a fact. The honourable member knows that that was the policy of the previous Government and that what this Government has done is continue that policy. For the honourable member to stand up in this chamber and say that that is not so is a massive misrepresentation of the truth. It is a slur on the people of my electorate, who have borne the brunt of the very unfair immigration policies of the previous Government. The previous Government was not pro-British or pro anyone, but it was certainly anti many people. It was anti people from the Middle East. It was anti people from parts of Asia and it was anti many other ethnic groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Greeks and Yugoslavs.

—As my colleague says, Greeks and Yugoslavs, and people from the Pacific islands, our nearest neighbours. The honourable member for Denison said that the Government has tried to stop people coming here from Britain. He should have tried to come here from Fiji when his colleague, the previous Minister, was administering the immigration program. People just did not get here. A person from the Middle East would never receive a permit, even if his wife was here, because he was not the sort of person the previous Government wanted.

SPEECH.PARA: I address myself to another remark the previous speaker made about how terrible it was that the Government was changing the Australian Citizenship Act as it pertains to British migrants and their chance to become permanent residents. I would have thought that this provision, which has been in the Act for over 30 years, would have allowed any British migrant who had come to Australia and decided that he or she wanted to be an Australian citizen to make that decision. Surely the honourable member for Denison is not telling the Committee this evening that it has taken people 30 years of living here to make up their minds whether they wish to become Australian citizens. It is like saying that if one cannot make up one's mind after 30 years one is obviously not going to do so. That is really taking 'try before you buy' to the nth degree, to suggest that people could be here for 30 years and be not quite sure whether they like Australia. The honourable member for Denison is probably not quite sure whether he likes Australia and he has been here for a little bit longer. He might understand what is in those people's minds. But any rational person would be able to make a decision after 30 years about whether he or she wishes to become a citizen.

What the Government is saying is that that section of the immigration Act gave a positive discrimination to one group. For instance, it said that people who are Greeks from Cyprus should have different rights from people who are Greeks from Greece. It said that people who are Turks from Cyprus should have different rights from people who are Turks from Turkey.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all Cypriots.

—We do not need remarks from the honourable member. He would not know where those places are. The point is that the same rights should apply to everyone in this country; not some special rights for some special group, not some special right because a person happens to have been born in one part of the Aegean, one part of the English Channel or one part of Europe and not another part. The Government has quite rightly said that it will do away with this discrimination and will make all people who emigrate to Australia equal before the law in this country. That is the right and proper thing to do. It removes an anomaly that causes some problems to people who come here from other lands. The Minister should be commended for this.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us once and for all put behind us this bogy raised by the inane pandering of the honourable member for Denison this evening about this Government being anti-British. This Government is not anti-British. In fact the only two British migrants at present in the House, the only two members who migrated here from England in recent years, are on this side of the chamber. They are supporting this legislation because they know it is equitable, just and proper. I commend the clause to the Committee. I am sure it will be carried with an overwhelming majority and that there will be rejoicing in all parts of the Australian community, not just in the one part for which the honourable member for Denison exercised some special pleading this evening.

We are hearing the last bleatings of the vestiges of the British Empire here tonight. Most of the rest of the people of Australia have grown up and realised that we are an independent country in this part of the world. Unfortunately some people in the Opposition have not realised that. Surely the Leader of the Opposition should realise that the types of outlandish statements that have been made publicly by the Opposition spokesman on immigration can cause only division in the Australian community. In fact until the honourable member for Denison became the Opposition spokesman on immigration, there was a fair degree of agreement between the Opposition and the government on where the Australian immigration system was going. But since this lunatic has taken over the spokesman's position we have had division and we will have more of it. I hope the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) will look to the best interests of Australia and remove him from the position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would the honourable member for Grayndler withdraw the word 'lunatic'. It is unparliamentary, in my opinion.

—I see that the honourable member for Denison does not mind being called a lunatic. But, Madam Chairman, if you wish to protect him, I am quite happy out of deference to you to withdraw the word 'lunatic' which the honourable member for Denison obviously does not mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members on the other side of the chamber seem to forget that the great expansion in immigration policies in this country was the result of programs mapped out by their Party, the Australian Labor Party, when in power in the 1940s. The tags which have been flung from the other side of the chamber to this side of the chamber, that the Opposition is supposed to be racially motivated, are quite unfair and unfounded. If one were to go back to the Labor Party Cabinet which existed at that time and say 'What caused you to lean heavily on Great Britain as a source for the growth of this country?', the reply would be something like: 'Well, we had to ensure that when we increased the numbers in Australia we did it in a way which enabled people to blend in in terms of culture and traditions without causing any giant hiccups'.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were to apply the theories of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), one could stretch a point and say that he was advocating that in the last few years we should have brought in, say, five million or six million people from Turkey, Afghanistan and India. I suggest that if that had been done the racial mix in this country would be one of total chaos . There would be friction in this country.

The previous Government adopted a policy of ensuring that people who came to this country had backgrounds and abilities to blend in. Many an ethnic spokesman has said that Australia is probably one of the greatest, most tolerant countries in the entire world in terms of the changes which have taken place here since the late 1940s. Honourable members opposite should remember that during the last 35 years this country has been in the hands of a Liberal-National Party Administration for 30 of those years. People from all countries across the world have been allowed to settle in Australia.

I truly believe that the Government is being anti-British and anti-European in its emphasis in this day and age. Whether it is being done intentionally is a matter of debate; that it is being done is not a matter of debate. One has only to cite the Big Brother movement. Within 19 days of coming to office, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) wiped it off the board-an organisation which had existed in this country since 1925 and which had had on its board between 1942 and 1947 people such as Ben Chifley. Yet the Minister could not get rid of that British oriented organisation quickly enough. What is more, I am aware of the fact that that organisation has been asking to see him for well over a year but he has just refused even to let representatives of it into his office. That organisation represents probably a quarter of a million people who have either been brought out here in the past from Great Britain or are members of families of people who have been helped and assisted to settle in this country. That is just one example. I notice that Government members have gone silent. I believe many of them would not be aware of the facts.

I have friends in the ethnic communities. When I was the member for Griffith I was known as Cameronopulis, so much was I part of the Greek community. So many members of the community say to me today: 'There is no point in our trying to sponsor members of our family to come to this country because the Government completely wipes them'. Italian people tell me exactly the same. They feel they are being squeezed out, that this Minister and this Government have adopted the attitude that if one is from Europe one is almost relegated to the status of second class.

Government members have almost turned the phrase of 'go home Yank' to 'buzz off Brit'. I think that is a fair assessment and analysis of how current policy is being implemented. The Government cannot get rid of everything to do with Great Britain quickly enough. It has removed the oath and reference to the monarchy. It has hoyed out of the window the national anthem. It is racing around this country pulling the photo of the Queen off every government building. It tried to get rid of the Queen's Medal last year which was an Army medal for the best shooter in the Commonwealth of Australia. It is ready to get rid of the flag. The reason it wants to get rid of the flag is that it has a Union Jack on it. All this points to the fact that the Government cannot strip away quickly enough all traces of our ancestry.

I was saying to a group of people only the other day at the QE II Hospital-that stands for Queen Elizabeth II-that under the Government in Canberra very shortly the hospital will be forced to change its name. The Government is so consistent with its whole approach. I love some of the more right wing members of the Australian Labor Party who jump up in this place and say: 'No, this is not being done. We are being misunderstood. We are being misrepresented.' I admire the lefties who sit silently, recognising the truth and who are prepared to say: ' Yes, I believe in what is being done.' But there are the cowards of the Right who sit silently in Caucus watching the traditions of this country being streamrolled week after week. I say to people in the electorate that it is up to them to become aware of what is going on.

The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) is scratching his back. He has 16, 000 people of United Kingdom and Irish ancestry or background in his electorate. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall) who seems to have disappeared has 22,000 people from Great Britain in that electorate. The honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh)-he is not here at the moment-has about 18,000 such people in his electorate. Come the next election those honourable members can be sure that these people will have noted the way they have handled the reins of government since they have been elected to power. People will not stand idly by and watch the Australian Labor Party completely wipe off decades and decades of tradition in this country.

I submit that one of the great problems of Labor in power is that it seeks to make vast changes to try to Australianise everything because it suffers from a huge inferiority complex. Labor Party members feel that they can run around in the pouch of a kangaroo and say: 'We are Australians'. But if we are associated with some other country they feel that it makes us inferior and less than respectable. Only the other day in Libya when that great creature of morality, Gaddafi, was moving in on all people from Great Britain, it was the British Government which offered protection and services to the Australians working in that country. In so many parts of the world this is the case. Whilst we are not in the lap of Great Britain, she has always regarded Australia as a country with which to have ties and with which to work. This remote island in the Pacific has been privileged in the past to have connections with Great Britain and yet this Government cannot bundle out Britain quickly enough.

In conclusion, I join with other members on this side of the House in expressing not only displeasure but also disappointment at the indecent haste which the current Government uses to destroy the history of this country. I say that as someone with a Scottish background, not as a Pom as I have heard one or two on the other side refer to British people. When one looks back in history one sees that the Scots have no reason to love the English. But we have the English language and parliamentary and legal systems from Great Britain. I submit most seriously that everything from England should not be destroyed as this Government is endeavouring to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industry)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rarely that I am provoked into coming into the House to talk on matters other than primary industry matters now I am the Minister.
—Nice to see you here.

—That is good. I thank the honourable member very much. I am happy to be here. I have an electorate with a high migrant population dating back to after World War II. The first influx of people were known as refugees. They were largely of European origin. The electorate of Werriwa, being on the edge of Sydney, has absorbed succeeding generations of people in the general migrant policy area and also it has absorbed a proportion of refugees under the programs of various governments. The Opposition is trying to build up racist, opportunist , prejudicial views because it thinks there are a few votes in it. The last people to talk about Asian migration and Asian refugees should be members of the Liberal Party, after their involvement in South East Asia. There are no votes for us in supporting South East Asian immigration. We do it because of the principle. We do it because of the truth. We do it because we have a refugee program. The Vietnamese in my electorate hand out how to vote cards for the Liberal Party except for one chap who used to be in the Central Intelligence Agency but who has now joined the Australian Labor Party. I will not get on to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the Opposition's problem is that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has no leadership. I am sure that he does not agree with the nonsense and the mad ranting that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is going on with. I do not mind if he is pro-British. That is his problem. It is his choice. But why should he pick on Asians particularly? I turn back to my electorate. There are lots of Italians and Greeks in my electorate who come to me wanting to get their remaining relatives out to Australia-cousins, uncles and all sorts of people. They go through the usual process. Some win, some lose. Some criteria have to be laid down and many principles are contained in the criteria laid down by my friend the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) and Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. We had to get some rigour into the system. In my electorate the first influx of refugees was from South America . I have Argentinians, Chileans and Uruguayans. They came here to escape political persecution by the facist regimes in that country with which the honourable member for Denison would feel quite happy, I am sure. They came in as refugees. There are now over 3,000 people from the South American countries in my electorate and they too are applying to bring their relatives into the country. The next wave were the Lebanese people. They are not Asians. They have had problems with--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Chairman, I take a point of order. At no stage have I mentioned Asian immigration but my point of order is that clause 7 of the Bill deals with British subjects and nobody else.
— We are dealing with clauses 1 to 11. There is no point of order.
—With respect, Madam Deputy Chairman, there is no other clause upon which the Minister can speak.
—The Minister must be relevant to the clauses under discussion.

—The next wave of people came from Lebanon. The last came from South East Asia. They are Vietnamese, ethnic Chinese and the Khmers. The reactionary response from the honourable member for Denison is plain nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard very good reasons today why the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) should never again be a Minister in an Australian Government. Today he has put out an extremely misleading statement . When I first heard it I thought I had better check it out with the officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to see whether it was accurate. In fact, it is inaccurate. That statement is that persons who are British subjects and who have previously had the right to vote will no longer have that right. That is what he said. Not only is that completely incorrect but also it will create a situation of concern in the community for people--
—I take a point of order. I have never made the statement attributed to me by the honourable member. I have never said that. I have not said it in the House; I have not said it outside the House.
—That is a personal explanation rather than a point of order.

—Madam Chairman, I am prepared to let the Hansard record determine the situation because I listened very carefully to what he said. Let the Hansard record determine what he said. One just cannot get up and make statements in a national parliament and then repudiate those statements--

—I take a point of order. Accepting that the honourable member's knowledge of English might not be perfect, I have never said what he is attributing to me. What I have said is that those who were not on the roll as at 6 o'clock on 25 January have lost their right to vote unless they--
—Order! This is not a point of order. If the honourable member wishes to make a personal explanation when the honourable member for Burke has finished, he may do so.
—Madam Chairman, the points of order are being taken in order to take up my speaking time.
—You are provoking him.

—Of course I am provoking him because that is what he said. The fact of the matter is that British subjects who have come to this country over many years have been automatically entitled after a six-month period to go onto the rolls and that situation was not changed by this Government. We said quite clearly that people who arrived after a particular date would be subject to the new rules. The honourable member knows that that is the position. He knows that he has misled the community in the statements that he has been making because--
—I take a point of order.
—I hope this is not another frivolous point of order. The honourable member for Denison has the right to speak again in this debate. He can then answer the honourable member for Burke.

—Madam Chairman, in view of the honourable member's last statement, might I respectfully suggest that he apologise because he has now admitted that I did not say what he is saying. What in fact he is doing is lying and misleading the Committee.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will withdraw that remark .
—I withdraw 'lying'. He is misleading the Committee.
—Let me say, Madam Chairman, that I am ready at any time to match my reputation in these matters with the reputation of the honourable member for Denison.
—I suggest that the honourable member get back to the clauses under consideration.
—He has been a total disgrace as a shadow Minister in these matters and he has gone around--
—I take a point of order. I make the point that this is not a second reading debate. This is the Committee stage during which we are looking at particular provisions of the legislation.
—There is no point of order. I ask the honourable member to get back to clauses 1 to 11, which are being dealt with at the moment.

—Let me get back to that point. The clauses we are debating relate to the situation of British subjects. I make this point in particular because of the statements made by the honourable member for Denison. He knows that the kinds of misleading comments which he keeps making in the House in relation to these matters are widely disseminated in the ethnic media and are creating concern. This is not the first time that this sort of situation has arisen. It has arisen on several occasions. I have received correspondence and expressions of concern from a wide number of people in the ethnic communities in relation to the activities of the honourable member for Denison in this matter.
—Produce them.

—I will produce them-the honourable member should not worry about that. Let me now make a couple of further points in relation to British subjects who have failed to take up citizenship. We have set down a particular date which will affect people in the future and not people who already have the right to vote. Those people do not need to go through any citizenship ceremony at all in order to continue to vote. That is not the position. Our legislation simply concerns people in the future. No one who has the right to vote at present is going to have that right taken away. I want to make that point because of the misleading remarks that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: The question arises whether this is an anti-British measure. In what conceivable sense could it be seen to be anti-British? People who are classed as British subjects are not only people from Britain but also people from other Comonwealth countries. Previously, anyone who came from anywhere in the British Commonwealth could vote and participate in Australian elections even though he was not a citizen. Yet persons from other countries could not do so. For example , Greek people who came from Cyprus were entitled to vote after six months; but Greek people who came from the Greek mainland had to wait for three years and become citizens before they could vote. What is happening in this provision, like the many positive provisions in this legislation which the honourable member for Denison has failed to recognise, is that that anomaly is being taken out of the legislation once and for all. How can this part of the legislation be seen to be some kind of attack on the British Queen? The honourable member for Denison somehow thinks it is very significant to come into the Committee and even when talking to specific clauses to refer to the Australian Labor Party stabbing the Queen and using rhetoric of that kind. The fact of the matter is that this clause, as I mentioned, irons out a provision in relation to citizenship arrangements which should have been ironed out a long time ago.

The honourable member for Denison has also failed in his duty to encourage citizens from the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth countries to become Australian citizens. Is he suggesting that anyone who puts down legislation that encourages this objective is somehow doing this country a disservice? These new clauses are designed to encourage that process. It is time that we took this step. The latest statistics that I have available indicate that as many as 800, 000 British citizens have not taken out citizenship. As I mentioned before, many of them are entitled to vote because of a previous provision. Nevertheless, we should be encouraging everyone who resides in this country to become part of this nation. We should be proud of this nation. We should get together and form one total community out of the various groups in our multicultural society.

I ask the honourable member for Denison and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to rethink the course of action that has been taken in relation to the clause, the Australian Citizenship Act and immigration matters generally because the bipartisan position which has existed on these matters is starting to break down as a result of the cheap political point scoring of the honourable member for Denison. The fact of the matter is that difficult decisions have to be made in the immigration area. However, we ought not to be pandering to the racists; we ought not be pandering to those people who want to destroy the immigration program. We ought in fact to get together in a positive way and recognise that the economic, social and demographic demands of this nation require a continuing , fair and balanced immigration program, to which the Labor Party is committed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister seems to forget that when he took that affirmation of allegiance he took it before this Parliament and before the Governor-General. As Professor Blainey said, this Government-I include in this the Minister for non- Defence-is the most anti-British, anti-European government this country has ever seen.
