SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to pursue the theme briefly and not in the tediously repetitive manner of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). He has about a dozen notices of motion on the Notice Paper all hammering this tedious theme that somehow we are introducing creeping republicanism. He knows that there is no way that Australia can become a republic without a referendum. He knows that to suggest otherwise is contrary to our Constitution. He knows that Labor governments, including this one, have always abided by constitutional processes. He knows that even when people like Sir John Kerr breached the soundest traditions of the British parliamentary system we abided by the letter of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: If anybody is anti-Constitution it is the honourable member for Denison with his false propaganda. He knows that when we swear an oath of allegiance or undertake an affirmation of allegiance to the Queen we do so to her as the head of our Parliament under that same Constitution. He knows that she is a constitutional monarch and not a tyrant or a dictator. He knows that she even declined to intervene when Sir John Kerr took that same reprehensible action. She said it was a matter for the Governor-General of Australia appointed by this Parliament and would not intervene. Yet he still says that we are anti-British.

Let us suppose that Australia did become a republic. It is highly likely; most of the nations of the Commonwealth are republics. Would the Queen thereby be any less welcome in this country? She is welcome in every republic of the Commonwealth. I do not know whether the heads of those countries cuddle the Queen or bounce Prince William on their knees, but I am sure they would be quite happy to. Not one of them has yet stabbed any of the Royal Family in the back, even though a few Britishers did chop off the head of one of their monarchs in years gone by when they were not constitutional monarchies. The honourable member is talking a lot of rot and creating needless anxiety about anti-royalism . Even if we were a republic, if there were creeping republicanism, if any number of Acts and a referendum of the people finally made us a republic, we are not anti-royalist. The Queen is still the head of the Commonwealth-in India, in Pakistan, in every Commonwealth nation, even in Tonga, which is way ahead of us. It has its own royal family and head of state, yet it still regards the Queen as head of the Commonwealth.

The honourable member has accused us of being anti-Christian but, on this argument about the special status of Britishers he wants to introduce a provision of preference for Christians, preference for whites, and preference for Britishers. On what grounds? Only because he is a racist and a bigot. And he calls us anti-Christian! We are treating all creeds and all colours equally, and he objects to that. He is breaking a law of the Christian church, one of the Ten Commandments, which states: 'Thou shalt not bear false witness'. He is bearing false witness against every one of us on this side of the House. Besides being anti-constitutional, anti-royalist and anti-Christian he is also anti-Australian , because he denies the right of Australians ever to change their flag, although the British flag has been changed three times in its history. Even when Captain Cook came here Britain had a different flag from the one it has today. The honourable member objects to Australians ever wanting to change their flag. He says that is anti-royalist, it is stabbing the Queen in the back. He is the one who is schizophrenic, and I am willing to sign the second certificate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat concerned by the lack of understanding shown by the honourable member for Capricornia (Dr Everingham) on the processes that are inherent in this oath of allegiance.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. The call is due on this side of the House. The Minister is entitled to intervene in the debate at any time.
—Yes, I recognise that, but the Minister wishes to close the debate when he speaks. I call the honourable member for Mitchell.

—The honourable member for Capricornia was trying to make the point that the removal of reference to the Queen by the insidious processes being adopted by this Government means nothing. In fact it means a whole lot of things . This process removes the protection of the citizen against any government that happens to occupy the other side of the House. The Government is removing the constitutional position of the Queen, which is important to the citizen. In the process of removing reference to the Queen from the oath, the Government has denied the protection of the citizen. Look at the American oath of allegiance. Look at the Greek oath of allegiance. Look at the Maltese oath of allegiance. Look at the oath of any country. Honourable members will see the protection for the citizen against the state. The Government has removed reference to the Queen from the Australian oath and has not replaced it with anything. It is the most insignificant oath any citizen in the world could take in allegiance to his or her country.
—It is not even an oath.

—It is not even an oath, as my friend says. It is a pledge. Having sorted out the honourable member for Capricornia, I point out to honourable members opposite that this pledge of allegiance to Australia is meaningless by international standards. The Minister sits there with a smirk on his face, content with the damage he has done to Australia's reputation, content with the damage he has done by discounting and devaluing the worth of Australian citizenship. He must be content with his administration of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs because, after countless representations to him, I find the average waiting time for an individual seeking entry to Australia is eight or nine months. Panels of review go to panels of review. Time and again matters go backwards and forwards. The immigration program of Australia is in chaos. The Minister ought to get round his Department and find out what a shambles there is.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order.
—Order! Could the honourable member make his comments relevant to the clauses before the Committee?

—Thank you, Madam Chair. I will continue to address my remarks to this legislation because all matters regarding migration must commence with the Minister and finish, we hope, with an oath of allegiance.
—We are confined at the moment to clauses 1 to 11.

—I am indeed dealing with those clauses because I am looking at the terms of residence for people in Australia. If honourable members refer to clause 11 and to proposed section 13 (1) (d), they will see that the Government has discounted the process of citizenship to the extent where a person has to be a legal resident, and that is a legal term, for two years, but during that two- year period he need spend in Australia an aggregate of only 12 months. We would get shonky businessmen, drug runners and all sorts of individuals using Australia as a base over those two years. They would be no more than token citizens, token residents. Under the current citizenship provisions such people would not be eligible to gain citizenship. Under the present provisions people must spend a total of 12 months continuously in Australia. Under these new provisions an aggregate of only 12 months need be spent in Australia. Is that what honourable members want for citizens of Australia? The Minister has not explained these points to the Committee. I think this is an absolute denigration of the meaning of the word 'citizenship'.

SPEECH.PARA: What sort of commitment can we draw from an individual who spends an aggregate of only 12 months out of two years in Australia? How do we know that he is not spending the other 12 months making a total of two years in his country of origin and is a de facto Australian citizen and a de facto citizen of his country of origin? How can we think this person is fair dinkum? What is the Minister saying to those wonderful citizens who have come from Greece, Italy, Malta and all of the European areas, to those marvellous citizens who have come from South East Asia and are committing themselves to Australia? The Minister is saying to them: 'This is what we are prepared to give people who come from this day forward. We are prepared to give them an easy entry process to citizenship'. The Government will devalue citizenship to such an extent that it will not be worth the paper it is written on. No other country would write a pledge of allegiance in such weak and paltry terms as this Minister and this Government are prepared to do. It is a terrible thing that the Minister is doing. I do not know how he will be regarded in international circles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. How many times do I have to remind the members of the Opposition that we are talking about specific clauses.
—I am dealing with a specific clause. The Minister is wasting my time. I am dealing with clause 11, proposed new section 13 (1) (d).
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell is at the moment speaking specifically to clause 11.
—That was a frivolous point of order, Madam Chair.
—The Chair does not need any assistance.

—The Minister has discounted the value of Australian citizenship. He cannot hold up his head in international circles. If he mixes with other immigration Ministers, no matter from what country, he will have to admit that a person wishing to become an Australian citizen need spend only part of a two- year period in Australia, in bunches of two or three weeks, while he runs his business from some international external port. What sort of citizenship is that ? All this Government is doing is creating a circumstance whereby all the shonkies of this earth who want to do so can use Australia as a safe base from which to operate their shonky businesses, denigrating Australia in the process. What would honourable members think about having as Australian citizens some of the characters who have been mentioned by Mr Costigan in his report? there will be more of them under these provisions. They will be here saying: 'We have the protection of Australian citizenship'. They will be wandering through South East Asia claiming Australian citizenship. They will be moving through the Americas. They will be operating internationally with this discounted and highly insignificant Australian brand of what we will be calling citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister wishes to be specific on this legislation, I refer him to proposed new section 13 (1) (k), and request that he inform the Committee what he means by 'adequate knowledge of the responsibilities and privileges of Australian citizenship'. He is not applying any test of language that is worth the stamp. What other questions will he ask individuals seeking Australian citizenship? He has not specified that in this chamber in any way whatsoever. We should look first of all at the oaths of other nations and the provisions that are required of individuals before they can accept citizenship. If a person is to be a citizen of any proud nation he needs to fulfil certain provisions that indicate that he understands truly the processes of law and the commitment that he needs to have as a character, as an individual, to that nation. What will the Minister do? Will he say that if people can speak a bit of English, that is good enough? I guarantee that no questions will be asked about knowledge of the parliamentary system or knowledge of commitments of a citizen in regard to the fulfilling of the democratic processes of this nation. What sorts of provisions will be made so that an applicant for citizenship can display that he has adequate knowledge of the responsibilities and privileges of Australian citizenship?

I would have thought a young, free nation-one of the 18 free member nations of the United Nations-would be proud of some of its traditions and standards. These traditions and standards have been fought for and they are precious to us. Can you tell me, Madam Chairman, that the early settlers in Australia did not value the freedom that they were gaining as a young colony through the processes that gained complete self-management and self-government and the federation of Australia? They were proud of those achievements, and there were people in the Australian Labor Party who used to be proud of those things as well.

We have seen demonstrated in this House today by the Minister and by the Government the fact that they are not proud to run a worthwile immigration program, they are not proud to operate a system of citizenship in Australia which will stand up in international circles. In fact, the commitment by way of pledge is worthless. Not only that, but the detail of citizenship will not stand any scrutiny on two insignificant clauses of a total Bill of many clauses. The Government has not done its homework. The Minister has brought great shame to his office and to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a short contribution to this Committee stage of the debate on the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. I do so for one reason, and that is that I think there is intruding into this whole question of migration and citizenship an element of the political debate of which we are seeing a little too much in Australia at present, this new McCarthyist tactic whereby if people are against what the Government is proposing, they are racists. It ought to be possible for people of properly liberal instincts, who are concerned about the decency of the welfare of this country and its citizens, from whatever country they come or whether they are Australian born, to have a legitimate difference of opinion with what the Government is doing without being accused of being racists. It ought to be possible for people to stand up here or anywhere else and say: 'Look, what you are doing is divisive and what you are about--
—What you are doing is divisive.

—See, that is an example of it. Because someone disagrees with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), he is a racist. This is an example of the authoritarianism of the Left and the absolute antagonism of people such as the Minister, the honourable member for Cunningham. He is a classic example--
—You disgusting creature.

—There you are; because I disagree with him, I am a disgusting creature. I hope that any fair minded member of the public who hears this will understand that here we have the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the custodian of the integrity of the citizenship of Australia on behalf of the Hawke Government, saying such a thing. Yet this is the first time I have spoken in this chamber on the subject of immigration since we have been in Opposition.
—You are a political opportunist of the worst order. It is the first time that you have spoken on immigration.

—I have not expressed a point of view other than to say that a person should be able to have a legitimately different point of view from that of the Government without being categorised as a racist, and what is the response of the Minister? He said that it is miserable and disgusting, that it is terrible and that I am an opportunist. He does not know what I am going to say, he does not have the faintest idea; but because one is against the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, ergo one is being disgusting and terrible. I want to express a concern that there has intruded into this debate this new McCarthyism, brought forward by some members of the Government, whereby if we disagree with the Government, we are everything under the sun; we are racists and miserable creatures, we are discredited, terrible, mean-minded and opportunistic. It is a very illiberal approach, but of course we have long suspected that there is a deep streak of authoritarianism in the left wing of the Labor Party, and if we scratch that we find that they are the most illiberal , authoritarian group of people in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyway, we will pass that over. I want to say a couple of things about citizenship and about national symbols. It is obvious from this debate that they are things that arouse considerable passions. Let me say to those more balanced members of the Government on this subject that they cannot have a totally static view about national symbols and traditions. I warn them that these are issues about which people feel very strongly and they should not lightly tamper with people's feelings about the traditions of this country. I cannot imagine anything more divisive for Australia at present than for this Government to promote a debate upon, for example, the status of the Australian flag. If honourble members opposite really want to divide Australia, if they really want to deny what they claim to be the basis of their mandate of March last year, they should perpetuate this debate about the Australian flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Chairman. We are not debating the flag. The honourable member for Bennelong keeps talking about the flag. In what clause is the flag mentioned?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I cannot conceive of anything that would be more divisive and more destructive of the national unity of this country than for us to have a long, drawn out debate about the nature of the Australian flag. I am prepared to concede that maybe at some time a majority of Australians will want to change the flag. I am personally opposed to any change in the Australian flag; I happen to think it is attractive.
—Order! I ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to speak to clauses 1 to 11.

—I happen to think that it very accurately reflects the aspirations of the citizenship of the Australian community and I see no point in its being changed. The most important thing is that if we think things such as citizenship , flags and allegiance are unifying factors, we have to have some sensitivity for the feelings of people on these subjects. For almost 10 years I have been the member for the electorate of Bennelong which, whilst it contains large amounts of what is generally called the north shore of Sydney, also contains a number of areas of multiracial character-areas from which I have always drawn very strong support. I have not had one complaint in that 10 years from a citizen of my electorate about the nature of the oath to be taken at a citizenship ceremony. Maybe I am an exception, but I have been re-elected on each occasion and I will be re-elected with an increased majority at the next election, so I am not out of touch with what people in my electorate are saying. I have not had one complaint. If ever, therefore, there was a phoney issue, it is this question of changing the nature of the oath. This oath is being changed not in response to popular demand but because the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) has a hang-up over the oath having some reference to the head of state of Australia. That is the reason the oath is being changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I accept completely what the Government has done recently in regard to our national anthem. I do not approve of the way in which it was done but I accept that Advance Australia Fair ought to be the national anthem of this country. The reason I accept it is that the majority of the Australian people indicated a preference for it when the former Government held a vote on that issue. That is why I accept it. I do not accept it because the Prime Minister decided that it ought to be our national anthem; I accept it for the reason I have given. I am not particularly attracted to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Surely there is no point in our listening to a policy speech from the honourable member for Bennelong as to the fight between him and the honourable member for Balaclava for the leadership of the Liberal Party. We know that the honourable member for Bennelong is well to the right of the honourable member for Balaclava.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will use his remaining few minutes to deal with clauses 1 to 11 of the Bill.

—Having made those points, the point I now make is that if those honourable members on the other side of the chamber were concerned to see that things such as citizenship, nationality and symbols are unifying factors, they would not bring about these changes which must of their very nature be divisive. From the response to these changes not only from the Opposition but also from the community in general it is perfectly obvious that the Government has stirred very strong passions. This country has problems enough at present and is likely to have problems enough for years into the future without stirring up unnecessary fights and arguments about our national symbols. I cannot imagine anything that is more destructive of our national unity or more likely to provoke division between Australian and Australian than the generating-in the name of pursuing some authoritarian view of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs-of these sorts of divisive changes. It is for that reason as much as for anything else that I very strongly support the position taken in this debate by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to see the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) finally taking an interest in immigration. I have been here for almost eight years and I have never heard a comment from him on immigration and ethnic affairs matters. It is interesting to note that the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), is not here. It is also interesting to note that two former Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Mackellar), have not chosen to associate themselves with all the divisive rubbish and with the repulsive nature of the arguments that have been put in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell honourable members opposite the reason why their two former Ministers are not here. It is because deep in their hearts and minds they are absolutely disgusted with the divisive way that the Opposition has sought to use the immigration program of this country. It was honourable members opposite who first sent Australia into Vietnam. It was they who started the Indo-China refugee program. They know deep in their minds that what Professor Blainey is saying is wrong. Yet they are perfectly satisfied to sit opposite and in a divisive, most vitriolic and hateful way misrepresent what this Government is doing with regard to immigration programs for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. On two occasions the Minister called me to order for straying from the content of the Bill. He is doing the same thing now.
—I ask the Minister to stick to the clauses of the Bill.

—Thank you very much for your advice, Madam Chair. No doubt for the rest of the Committee stage of the so-called debate on this Bill the members of the Opposition will be asked not to be so wide-ranging in the nature of their remarks. With regard to the removal of the British status as a criterion for Australian citizenship, there was no Australian citizenship per se until the Chifley Australian Citizenship Act of 1949. It was then that all the British subjects in Australia-that includes people born outside and inside Australia- were given Australian citizenship. There were transition arrangements which for many years allowed British subjects who were here prior to 1949 to become Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: The position is that no Commonwealth nation, including the United Kingdom, any longer regards its citizens as British subjects. That includes the British Government. That definition has been struck from the statutes of the United Kingdom and struck from the statutes of every other Commonwealth nation. Although we are the last nation to remove British subject status as a definition of Australian citizenship-that is virtually all it means-and although we will give the States in the Commonwealth time to tidy up their consequential legislation, honourable members opposite have spent the last hour and a half trying to prevent the passage of this eminently sensible proposition with which incidentally all of the State governments agree absolutely and totally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except Tasmania and Queensland. Do not misrepresent them.

—Tasmania and Queensland do not agree with the oath change, but they agree totally with what we are doing with regard to the removal of British subject status. Every State government in Australia agrees totally with what we are doing here and is co-operating with us. Yet the Opposition has used the last one and a half hours of the Committee stage of the debate to try to present what we are doing here to tidy up the Act as an example of anti-British behaviour. The Opposition is trying to prevent Australia from being the last Commonwealth nation to remove the British subject definition. I became very angry with the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) and the honourable member for Bennelong because I knew the attitude of their State colleagues. I knew how misrepresentative and divisive the honourable members actually were. This Labor Government is trying to do something in the name of all Australians, from wherever they may come, and in the interests of Australia generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we need to remove the remaining discrimination from the Australian Citizenship Act. That is what the removal of the British subject definition will do. I am sure that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), as a fair minded person, would not agree that we should continue to allow British subjects who are not citizens to walk straight into permanent jobs in the Public Service and still require non-English speaking migrants to become citizens and then automatically get British subject status before they can become permanently employed in the Public Service. That is discrimination. We are not discriminating against the British; we are removing discrimination against the non-British. There is a very great difference, as honourable members well know.

I conclude my remarks on this point: There is no self-respect or national pride in the coalition-none at all. The remarks of coalition members this afternoon indicate that they would be prepared forever to see this generation and future generations of Australia regarded as the subjects of a government elsewhere. We are no longer British subjects; we are citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia . Honourable members opposite have spent the last hour and a half of the time of this Parliament in arguing for the retention of British subject status as a definition of Australian citizenship. If we accept that argument we will be the only Commonwealth country to do so. Not even the British Government does that any longer. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 12 (Effect of grant of certificate of Australian citizenship)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will take this clause to a division because, of all the clauses in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill, there is none more repugnant to Her Majesty's loyal Opposition and to the overwhelming majority of Australians than clause 12 which is the clause under which the oath and the affirmation of allegiance are made. The requirement to swear an oath or make an affirmation of allegiance, introduced by Prime Minister Whitlam, are in the Australian Citizenship Act. The oath and affirmation now go out and are replaced by the requirement to make a pledge in a form which is totally unacceptable to the overwhelming majority of Australians. Pledges are for pawnbrokers. We are talking about the citizenship of the greatest country in the world. As the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said, the Government is debasing, devaluing and discounting Australian citizenship when it denies the right of Australians to swear or affirm allegiance to the Queen of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Government talks about misrep- resentation let me say on behalf of the people of Australia that we are disgusted at the way that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West), one of the leaders of the fascist Left in the Hawke socialist government, has gone around this country claiming that it is an oath of allegiance to a foreign monarch. He stood in Sydney in front of 25 ,000 people on Greek independence day and said that we were about to change the law so that, to become an Australian citizen, they would not be required in the future to swear an oath of allegiance to a foreign monarch living in a foreign country. That was a gross misrepresentation of the truth because the oath of allegiance is not made to a foreign monarch. The oath of allegiance is made to the Queen of Australia. That was introduced by Prime Minister Whitlam and accepted by the majority of Australians.

This is the atheist, socialist republicanism of the Hawke Government now coming to light. Government members might laugh about that but I assure them that the division list for the vote on this clause will go right around Australia. People who have claimed in the past to be loyal to the Queen, people who have claimed in the past--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a disgrace.

—To affirm allegiance to the Queen, people like the father of the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) who affirmed and honoured it, will look through that list. I can assure honourable members that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is so out of touch with public opinion that it does not make any difference. Unfortunately, the Minister, in indicating the ideologies of the fascist Left, has misrepresented the position in this Parliament. He has claimed in this debate that the two former Ministers recommended changes to the oath of allegiance by deleting reference to the Queen . That statement is simply not true. One former Minister recommended a change concerning whether the renunciation should be before or after the oath of allegiance. But neither former Minister, the former member for Petrie, Mr Hodges , nor the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), ever advocated that reference to the Queen be taken out of the oath or the affirmation of allegiance .

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to repeat what I said in the second reading debate. I point to the hypocrisy, the double standards and the dishonesty of this sham Hawke socialist Government. It is prepared to deny the right of Australians to swear allegiance to the Queen of Australia. When a person becomes a member of the Commonwealth Parliament or a member of any State parliament, he or she has to take an oath or an affirmation. The Government is not prepared to go to the people of Australia with a referendum. It would get thrashed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the test.

—The honourable member for Braddon made the point that that is the test. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that we will have a referendum at the end of this year in conjunction with the election on simultaneous elections and on one other matter. What about putting to the people of Australia whether we should delete the schedule from the Constitution? What does the schedule provide? It provides for an oath or affirmation of allegiance which each and every honourable member took before he or she could take a seat in Parliament. The Ministers took one or the other in the presence of the Queen's representative, the Governor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Government that if it wants to see what the people think about this matter it should take it to the people. The Government has no mandate to do what it is doing. It is going against the wishes of the overwhelming majority of Australians. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, it is indulging in divisive and disruptive tactics. The Government displays itself as not being loyal to the Queen of Australia and for that it will be condemned. On this issue alone it will lose so many votes in the next election that it will find itself in a position which is not the position it thinks it will be in at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have had the usual parade of name calling and attempts to label people from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). I certainly will not do that in return. It is our belief that it is the overwhelming desire of the people who expect to seek to acquire Australian citizenship that this Bill be passed. Over three million of the six million people in this country who were either born overseas or who have a parent who was born overseas come from non- English speaking countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be frank, honest and non-divisive about this matter. We are not saying that this is the first step towards an Australian republic. We are not saying that the Queen is no longer the Queen of Australia. We are saying that, for some migrants who join us from non-English speaking countries, it is a divisive provocation to require them to swear allegiance to the Queen who is resident elsewhere before they can obtain Australian citizenship. Let us look at what the report commissioned by the former Government and brought down by Professor Zubrzycki had to say. I will conclude my remarks with a quote from the report on the National Consultations on Multiculturalism and Citizenship. It stated:

The strongly-held and predominant view emerging from the consultations was that swearing allegiance to a sovereign, and especially to a named sovereign resident elsewhere, was inappropriate in Australia at its present stage of history. This view was shared by persons from a variety of backgrounds, including holders of Imperial awards and persons who maintained that they were not republicans. No hostility was expressed towards Her Majesty, though one speaker did pose the conundrum as to where her own allegiance would lie if Britain came into conflict with Australia.
She was a very forward-looking woman. She was looking at maybe 100 years down the track. The report continues:
Few speakers were in favour of retaining a mention of the Queen in the Oath of Allegiance, and spoke mainly to register their support, rather than to advance a reasoned case for its retention.
I rest my case. I move:
That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a fascist of the Left and you are the most disgraceful Minister we have ever had in this Parliament.
-I ask the honourable member for Denison to withdraw those comments.
—I say that he is a fascist of the Left.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw those comments.
—Only out of respect to you, Mr Deputy Chairman. The world knows that it is true.

—The amendment is agreed to. Mr Deputy Chairman, can you pull that lunatic into gear?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 38 has the effect of removing from the statute books forever the Schedules to the Australian Citizenship Act which were brought into this Parliament and which passed through this Parliament when Mr Whitlam was Prime Minister. I have to say to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) that this is the last chance that he and the Hawke socialist Government have to pull back from removing from the Schedule set out in the Australian Citizenship Act 1948-1973, firstly, the oath of allegiance and , secondly, the affirmation of allegiance.

SPEECH.PARA: The oath of allegiance is in simple and beautiful terms and is as follows:
I . . . renouncing all other allegiance, swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia,-
I emphasise those words-
Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

The affirmation of allegiance is in similar terms except that the words ' solemnly and sincerely promise and declare' are inserted in lieu of the words ' swear by Almighty God'. These are to be replaced by a pledge of allegiance which , as the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has said, is an insult to this nation, an insult to all Australians past and present. As I said a few minutes ago, pledges are for pawnbrokers; they are not for citizenship. This is what the people of Australia are being confronted with in this Bill. Firstly, the pledge of Australian citizenship will be in the following terms:

I . . . renounce any current citizenship and all allegiance to any State other than Australia. I pledge that I will faithfully uphold the Constitution, obey the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian citizen.

That is placed as the first option. Mr Whitlam, in his Bill, had the decency to place as the first option the oath of allegiance. It so happens that 81 per cent of Australians happen to believe in a God. This arrogant, ignorant Minister, this outrageous socialist republican Government says: 'Your first option is a pledge but, if you want to, as a second option we will give you the opportunity of swearing allegiance. That is the second form of the pledge'. In so doing the Government is insulting four out of five Australians who believe in God or christianity or who are members of a church. Secondly, the Government is refusing them the right to swear allegiance or affirm allegiance to the Queen. Yet those hypocrites opposite do it when they come into this Parliament because if they do not swear or affirm allegiance to the Queen, they cannot take their seats and cannot collect their money.

Thirdly, if we look at the latest gallup poll, Government members are so far out of touch with public opinion on this matter that it just does not count. Power and the public opinion polls have gone to the head of the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). He now regards himself as more important than the Queen and half as good as God. I tell honourable members that this vote is an historic vote because on this vote Government members are demonstrating beyond any shadow of doubt that the allegiance which they swore or affirmed to the Queen was shallow. I put it to them that they are putting in jeopardy their own seats. They can hardly argue that their oaths are worth the paper on which they were written when, less than 12 months afterwards, they are in this Parliament putting the knife into the Queen.

The Minister ought to resign before he is sacked. He has become a symbol of disunity amongst Australians old and new. He thinks he is pleasing the ethnic groups with this amendment. I can assure him that, following his speech in Sydney on Greek Independence Day, the number of people who came up to me wearing an Australian flag and who said 'We believe in the Queen' would have put him to shame. He has listened to the wrong people. The Prime Minister has been sucked in by the socialist Left. The Minister is now about to destroy the right of Australians to swear allegiance to the Queen of Australia. Shame on him. It is a black day. I know my voice is going but my heart is in this because the people of Australia will know Government members for what they are-hypocrites, liars and cheats and disloyal, one and all, to the Queen of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 38 refers to the regulations attached to the Bill. I will not be as viciously or as stupidly repetitive as the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs , the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), on this matter of the changes to the oath; I will merely refute once again two points. The removal of reference to the Queen from the oath of allegiance is not an indication of a rush to republicanism. I wish Opposition members would get that through their heads, nor is it an indication of anti-British feeling; nor does it indicate any resentment against the Queen.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer again to the stupid remarks of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) during the second reading debate when he actually said that I was out to make God optional. As I said, I do not claim such divine powers. It was always an option to make an affirmation or an oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just the first option. There must be some significance in turning around the order.

—I make it clear to the honourable member for Dundas, who I might say, to be charitable, made one of the few reasonable contributions from the Opposition during the second reading debate-I am sure he will be able to understand what I am saying although the honourable member for Denison will not learn-that reference to the Queen is in the current affirmation and the oath. But, of course, an affirmation does not refer to religion or God whereas an oath does. So I am afraid God was always optional in this Act. Now we will give the would-be citizens of Australia a choice between two forms of pledge, one which swears by Almighty God and one which does not. The important point is that it is truly national in character. All people will be asked to do is to swear allegiance to the magnificent country of Australia and to the Australian Constitution. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being past 7.30 p.m., I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Young-I require the question to be put forthwith without debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I felt, having listened to the debate, that there was need to make a contribution because I am deeply concerned at the move that has been made to change the oath. I am one of those people present who , as a former shire president and local government person, has participated over the years in assisting people to take out citizenship in Australia by taking an oath and, in many cases, an affirmation. I am deeply concerned, in the first instance, that we should break a longstanding tradition by not including the Queen of England as the Queen of Australia in the oath of allegiance. The change is absolutely unnecessary. People have always recognised that the Queen is an institution as well a as a person. The monarchy is certainly an institution and, as such, we have included it in our traditions. It is certainly part of our history. Other nations also have backgrounds emanating from the British Isles. The fact that when the Queen visits those places people turn out in their thousands to greet her is evidence that those people have great respect for that tradition. I would not mind if I could see some benefit to Australians in taking the Queen out of the oath. It is a tradition. She is declared as the Queen of Australia and I believe that she should not be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Labor Government is paranoid in its desire to remove the Queen, a desire previously pursued by the Whitlam Government. In that period the Prime Minister of the day tried to replace that institution with his own. He had his photograph hanging on walls as we well know. I see this move as taking away from Australians something that stands up for us to recognise as a higher institution . It is exactly the same thing as we find in some communist nations which demand that everybody dresses the same and looks the same. We are taking away something that people can look up to. More importantly, I see a great problem in the downgrading of God. There is no other way to describe it. This act must be deliberate. Draftsmen do not by accident turn around the position of affirmation and oath. They do it by instruction. That instruction clearly came from the Government.

I am a little astounded by that. I have a good memory and I take notice of things that happen. I have had the opportunity to watch the swearing in ceremony of members of this place on two occasions and I thought that maybe the Australian Labor Party had decided to upgrade God a little bit because when I observed the 1981 swearing in of members I saw the honourable member for Wills ( Mr Hawke) make an affirmation but when I watched the swearing in ceremony after the 1983 elections I saw the honourable member who was, of course, Prime Minister-elect, take the oath. It is amazing to me that the Bible did not catch fire in his hands when he did it because we know very well some of the statements that he has made. Let us hope that his father, the Reverend Clem Hawke, got to him and that he does not have an ambition to walk on water. I think that is what he is planning to do in the future.

I think what the Government is doing is disgraceful. It is just another example of the hypocrisy of a government which throws crumbs to its left wing to keep it pacified while it carries out other things which, of course, its left wing is not so pleased about but in respect of which it is not prepared to roll the Government. We know what those issues are. If the left wing is prepared to survive on these crumbs, good luck to it. I think, of course, that members of the left wing are completely destroying their principles when they take the crumbs instead of standing up for the issues in which they truly believe. I have admiration for people who stick by their principles, but I have no admiration for people who do things such as I have just mentioned. I have no admiration for people who find that they can forgo God when it is interesting to be amongst the boys and make an affirmation but who turn around and rediscover God when they believe respectability is required for their new position. Many people rediscover God but they rediscover Him for good reasons and not for pure and blind ambition. I think it is time that honourable members opposite went back to their Prime Minister and said: 'As you have been able to upgrade God, at least let us upgrade Him and put him on top of the Schedule which is referred to in section 38'. That is where He was; that is where most people wanted Him. It is quite simple to do this. What honourable members opposite have done is quite sinister and they have done it for a definite purpose. I think that this is most unfortunate and regrettable. If any honourable member opposite wants publicly to stand up and say that he is prepared to downgrade God I hope he never wants to be Prime Minister because if he is he will be put in the position of having to upgrade Him again.

TALK.START.PARA: —But I haven't made Him optional.

—No, the Minister has not. However, he has certainly put God in a position where He might be missed. God should have been on top of the list. The Government took a deliberate decision to change the positions around. The Minister cannot deny that because I know his draftsman would not have changed the basic order of words on his own. This was done on the instructions of the Government and the Minister. It is not really funny because we are a Christian nation, even though some of us see God in slightly different ways. Quite a lot of other religions still recognise a God. It is a great pity that this change has been proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying is that members of the left wing have a crumb. God has been downgraded and the Queen has been wiped out. However, they were rolled on uranium and they have been rolled on everything else in which they believe. That does not make them very effective members of parliament. This situation is a disgrace.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr West)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the dying stages of this debate I have the opportunity to speak briefly. I want to say two things to the Government. I say them across party lines and in all sincerity. Because of the highly contentious, extremely divisive and extraordinarily emotional issues that have been raised by this legislation, I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West ) to go back to Cabinet and re- commend to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that this Bill progress no further for a period of, say, three months during which time community reaction to it can be further gauged and assessed. In the utmost good faith, I ask the Minister to stop now before he does irreparable damage to the fabric and framework of this great nation of ours. The Minister's decision to downgrade God and wipe out the Queen will be regretted very strongly by the overwhelming majority of Australians. I appeal to the Minister to hold the matter and take it no further. If the Minister is not prepared to respond favourably to that request put to him and to the Hawke socialist Government by Her Majesty's loyal Opposition, my concluding comment is a message to the other place. I hope that when this Bill reaches the other place those who have the honour to serve in the Senate will more accurately represent the views of the people of Australia about loyalty to our Queen. This is the Commonwealth of Australia and the Constitution guarantees a constitutional monarchy. We are not some republic and the Prime Minister is not President. If it were possible to transmit a message from this House to the Senate I would hope the message would be that in the other place, under divine providence, wiser counsel should prevail. I for one am proud, along with millions of other Australians, to say the words 'God save the Queen'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -This Government has taken notice of and considered the consultations that the previous Government held throughout Australia with migrant communities and organisations. I have consulted with the States and I am satisfied that in the main they support the major provisions of this Bill. I have consulted with them almost since the Government took office over a year ago. I have taken this matter through two Commonwealth-State ministerial conferences. What is more, I am confident that the majority of the people of Autralia gave us a mandate for the major changes that are proposed in this Bill after they were quite clearly told at the last election what we were going to do. Therefore, I refute what the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), said and call on the other place to pass this Bill unanimously because that is what the majority of the migrants and, I believe, the majority of Australians want.

TALKER.NAME: Mr YOUNG
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that this House has a general debate covering this Bill and the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill 1984 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill is to give the Pork Promotion Committee control of its own funds. The change of name from the Pig Meat Promotion Committee to the Pork Promotion Committee is also provided for. The outline of the legislation states that the following changes are to be made:

SPEECH.PARA: to appoint the second producer member on the Committee as Deputy Chairman ( other producer member is Chairman).
to provide for Ministerial approval of deputies prior to their appointment by a member.
to provide for a quorum of three (member or deputy) at Committee meetings.

I am making this speech for the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), who is away from Parliament at the moment. He wanted certain definite points to be made during this debate.

These Bills continue the legislative policies of the Hawke Labor Government over the period of the 13 months it has occupied the treasury bench. Those policies indicate that as far as primary industry is concerned the Government is more interested in the shadow of administrative fine-tuning than in the substance of developing policies and fulfilling pre-election commitments. There has not been one substantive piece of legislation which has sought to translate its 'me too' pre-election promises into statute. One can understand that that is only to be expected. The Government has never shown any interest in primary industry. We all remember Senator Walsh's comments on millionaire farmers and the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen), that we would be better off without Australian wheat and sugar producers .

Of course, the Government has been very strong on rhetoric. It has been superb in extending sympathy and agreement with primary producer organisations which have come in with their legitimate concerns. The stock reply of the Government has been to blame the previous Government for all its inability to offer help and fulfil its promises. It cannot deliver and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is rapidly gaining a reputation as a man who always loses in the Ministry or in Cabinet and as one who has failed to translate that sympathy into reality. The only legislation he has brought in deals with administrative change or imposes additional charges, such as increased inspection charges on industries or applies them to a wider area of primary production than was the case under the Fraser-Anthony coalition.

Fortunately for Australian primary producers, the Minister has had to face the complete ignominy of having this legislation held up in the Senate. He is one of the few Labor Ministers who has had this fate befall him. It is interesting to note that following the comments made by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Darling Downs, in a recent House of Representatives debate on inspection charges and the failure of the Government to have in place practical policies and enthusiasm to charge for something that was unknown, two Bills were not proceeded with in the House of Representatives and four Bills in the Senate are not even to be debated this week. The Minister, in his enthusiasm to put further charges on Australian primary producers, in his second reading speech indicated that the passage of these Bills was urgent as the increased and new charges-

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. These Bills are not about export inspection charges. They refer to quite minor matters concerned with two Acts.
—I ask the honourable member for Murray to confine himself to the content of the Bills.

—I think the point of order raised by the Minister verifies the point I was making, namely, that the Government and the Minister have failed to do anything other than increase charges for farmers in the primary industry area. With respect to the Pig Meat Legislation Amendment Bill the Opposition supports the deletion of the promotion account and the payment of promotion moneys to the Committee. With the necessary safeguards provided by the Auditor-General it will allow for a more business-like arrangement than that which was possible through departmental procedures. It seems unnecessary for the Department of Primary Industry to be involved to the degree it was involved under the 1975 legislation when we are not here dealing with dollar for dollar government and industry money. We are dealing with industry money alone.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need for promotion. Pork promotion will be supported to the level of $1.75m this year. Of this amount $1.4m will be spent on promoting all cuts of pork and $250,000 will be spent on ham promotion. The people associated with the promotion deserve applause for their modern approach in convening a joint policy of advertisements in all capital city newspapers and 14 major provincial newspapers, 33 radio stations and in a 16 page colour recipe lift-out in the Women's Weekly. This follows the successful campaign which they launched in mid- 1983 and the previous success of the 'Quick and Easy' cooking theme they developed. The cooking theme will be further developed by a new series of television commercials. Ham has traditionally been used for snacks, salads or Christmas dinner. The tactic now will be to promote ham as an everyday family dinner at a cost of $250,000 through advertisements in the Australian Women's Weekly, Woman's Day, New Idea and Family Circle. An advisory committee comprising a nutritionist, a dietitian, a food scientist, a food technologist and home economist has been set up.

The pork promotion scene has been gratified by a massive swing in interest towards health, diet and nutrition and by the endorsement pork has from Weight Watchers. The pork industry is a major Australian agricultural industry and a significant industry in world terms. Presently there are about 330,000 sows producing about 4.2 million slaughtering pigs with a total carcass weight of about 240,000 tonnes of fresh pork, 50,000 tonnes of ham and bacon and 40,000 tonnes of can product a year. We readily appreciate the multiplier effect of such a large number of intensively housed animals to the secondary industry such as meat processors, feed millers and grain growers. As with the red meat industry there has been a reduction in prices to pig farmers this year compared with last year and for the pig industry in isolation there has been a significant reduction over the past few years.

Following discussions that the shadow Minister for Primary Industry has had with pig industry people from all over Australia he sees that the greatest difficulty faced by pig and pork producers is in the export area. Australia has many factors in its favour which could lead it to becoming a world leader in pork exports. Australia has big areas with ideal climate for intensive livestock production. Australia is an exporter of natural gas and coal which should provide a relatively cheap supply of energy and land costs for intensive production are low by world standards. This cheap land, dry climate and low population density makes effluent disposal in Australia easy compared with some of the enormous difficulties of some of our overseas competitors.

Due to the sound quarantine proposals of previous governments we are relatively free from livestock diseases. If we adopt adequate promotion techniques and spending on this industry there is an enormous market for pork meat in the general Asian sub-continent area. Japan is a major importer and Singapore could be developed. Australia should be a major supplier to these markets. There is no inherent reason why we cannot usurp the position of Canada which has been the major supplier of pork as it has many disadvantages compared with Australia. However, the lack of a plant variety rights scheme in Australia has discouraged private firms from developing better feed grain varieties and improving the yields of feed grains. Grower supported research funds through the wheat industry have been concentrated on wheat development. Therefore, pig producers have been inhibited in their export potential by this lack of development of a feed grain industry. We need also to overcome our bad reputation as a supplier to world markets because of our industrial relations record.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Handicapped Persons: Taxation of Special Vehicles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say if a vehicle, manufactured by British-Leyland in the United Kingdom, designed to allow a disabled person to enter and exit the vehicle by wheelchair without assistance, and to also drive that vehicle without assistance , is now available.
(2) Can he also say if any similar vehicle is now in production in Australia.

(3) Is this vehicle, manufactured by British-Leyland, and designed specifically to aid the disabled, currently subject to between 93 and 95 per cent sales tax and import duty by the Australian Bureau of Customs, when it is purchased by an Australian citizen and brought into this country.
(4) Is this level of taxation an undesirable impost on the severely handicapped person.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that a vehicle specifically designed for disabled persons is now available from British-Leyland in the United Kingdom, under the name of the Elswick Envoy.

(2) None of the local vehicle manufacturers produces a vehicle specifically designed for use by the handicapped. However a variety of locally produced vehicles are capable of being modified for this purpose and each of the local producers provides an advisory service to assist handicapped users in the design of modifications necessary for their individual purpose.

(3) For tariff purposes an Elswick Envoy would be classified as a passenger motor vehicle, and therefore be subject to a duty of 57 1/2 per cent. As imports of motor vehicles are subject to quota limits a prospective importer would also require access to quota in order to be able to import the vehicle.

As far as sales tax is concerned I am advised that the rate of tax applicable on importation would be the general rate of 20 per cent unless it is covered by an exemption provision in the sales tax law. The only provision which calls for comment is item 123 in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. Item 123 exempts goods designed and manufactured expressly for use by disabled persons provided that they are not of a kind ordinarily used by persons who are not suffering from disablement.

It is a question of fact for the Commissioner of Taxation to decide whether a particular item of goods is exempt under item 123 or excluded from exemption because it is in the nature of general-purpose goods ordinarily used by persons other than the disabled. The Commission is not aware of any instance where a road vehicle designed or modified to be used and operated by a disabled person has qualified for sales tax exemption under the item. On face value, such a road vehicle would be unlikely to qualify for exemption, because, although it may be specially designed in certain respects, it would still retain the basic character of a road vehicle for the transport of persons. The Commissioner would need to be supplied full details of specifications, etc. of the vehicle to enable a proper determination to be made. He will arrange for this to be done if such details are supplied.

I am advised that the sales tax position would be the same for similar vehicles produced in Australia as for the imported vehicle in question. There is, however , a limited exemption in item 42C, First Schedule, for goods to be used in the modification of a motor vehicle solely for the purposes of adapting it for driving by a person who is suffering from physical impairment. The exemption would apply to goods used in Australia to modify imported or locally produced standard vehicles. Exemption, of course, would not apply to goods which are used in the modification overseas of a motor vehicle and which form an intergral part of an imported vehicle.

Items 135 and 135A in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act contain limited sales tax exemptions for motor vehicles for use by disabled persons. Item 135 provides exemption for a motor vehicle for use in the transportation of an ex-serviceman who as a result of war service has lost a leg or both arms or receives a special Repatriation pension for blindness , tuberculosis or in respect of total and permanent incapacity. Item 135A provides exemption for a motor vehicle for use in the transportation to and from gainful employment of a person who has lost the use of a leg to such an extent that he is permanently unable to use public transport.
On the basis that the vehicle would not qualify for exemption, sales tax would be calculated at 20 per cent on the following value on importation into Australia-
(a) value for customs duty; plus
(b) customs duty; plus
(c) 20 per cent of the sum of (a) and (b)

(4) The Government of course is very conscious of the particular mobility problems that can face disabled people. Assistance to help the disabled in meeting those problems is provided through various avenues.

As noted above, provision exists for exemption of sales tax in certain instances. In 1981-82 the cost to revenue of sales tax exemptions on motor vehicles owned and used to convey persons with leg disabilities amounted to around $1.2m.

Furthermore, a special mobility allowance for severely disabled persons was introduced in the 1982-83 Budget. Persons who have not received sales tax relief on the purchase of a motor vehicle qualify for a non-taxable allowance of $10 a week. The cost of this allowance is estimated at $18.3m in a full year.

The possibility of providing special tariff concessions for imports of vehicles designed for any use by the disabled has also been considered. However examination has shown that this would not be feasible. If concessional entry was provided for these vehicles there would be a real risk that the concession would be used to import vehicles which would end up being marketed for the general user. To safeguard against this risk very specific criteria would need to be written into the tariff. This however would have the effect of negating the practical value of the concession to the genuinely disabled. Even if tariff criteria which avoided this problem could be devised the potential would still remain for vehicles imported under the concession to be subsequently converted for sale in the general market. While conversion would involve costs to the importer these need to be considered against the substantial duty savings which would be involved.

Abuse of any concession in these ways could have serious effects on production and employment in the local vehicle manufacturing industry. The possibility of side effects of this kind places obvious limits on the extent to which it is feasible to use tariff concessions as an instrument of social welfare policy. These limitations have been recognised by governments of all political persuasions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 17 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article on the rust-proofing industry in the September issue of Choice magazine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The treatment of motor vehicles either during manufacture or subsequently with a suitable and properly applied corrosion inhibition product can assist in preventing rust. It seems however, that at least some rust-proofing currently performed in Australia is below the desired standard. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to articles in the Age and the Australian on 30 November 1983, reporting that Mr Ranald MacDonald, a former director of David Syme and Co. Ltd, had discovered that up to 1964 the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation had vetted the appointment of Age newspaper reporters.
(2) Can the Attorney-General confirm whether, and to what extent, such vetting has been undertaken by ASIO in relation to the appointment of reporters in the print, radio and television media.
(3) Will the Attorney-General advise whether, and to what extent, ASIO is presently operating such a vetting procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I follow the practice of successive governments in that the activities of ASIO are neither confirmed nor denied. I can say that the great majority of allegations reported about ASIO's activities are without foundation. ASIO's functions are strictly confined under the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 to the collection and evaluation of intelligence relevant to security. It is concerned only with the activities prejudicial to national security.

It appears from the article in the Age of 30 November 1983 that many people associated with David Syme and Co. Ltd, and the Age newspaper regard Mr Ranald McDonald's claims about ASIO vetting of journalists as lacking foundation. Mr Keith Sinclair, editor of the Age from 1959 to 1966 was reported as describing Mr McDonald's claims about ASIO vetting of journalists as 'absolute nonsense'. Mr W. G. Bland, General Manager of the Age between 1964-1983 was reported as saying that he had no knowledge of any ASIO vetting of journalists. Mr Peter Alston, the personnel manager of the Age from 1961 to 1978 said that he was '' never aware'' of any ASIO involvement in the process of appointing journalists to the paper. The present editor of the Age, Mr Creighton Burns, said that to his knowledge, and certainly since he had become editor, the Age has not sought security checks on staff from ASIO or any other government instrumentality. Mr Burns stated that he had never been approached by ASIO in relation to staff appointments.

(3) In certain prescribed circumstances, ASIO is authorised by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 to provide Commonwealth agencies with security assessments in relation to individuals. The only circumstance in which a reporter would be the subject of such an assessment is where he or she is to have official access to national security classified information or a secure area and is formally submitted for assessment by a Commonwealth agency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that the Local Government Grants Commission has indicated that because of present budgetary circumstances and the need to expand job creation programs, the Government is concerned to concentrate funding in areas of maximum need; if so, will special grants be given to some areas at the expense of other areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The various State Grants Commissions are responsible for recommending to the State Governments on the allocation to local governing bodies, within their respective States, of Commonwealth local government revenue sharing funds.

Distribution guidelines are provided under section 6 of the Local Government ( Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 which allow some flexibility in grant allocations according to the relative revenue raising and expenditure disabilities of local authorities. The special needs of areas are taken into account to some degree under the Grants Commission's methodologies.

These basic general purpose grants may be supplemented on an area or functional basis for above average needs according to the policies of the Commonwealth or State Governments. A number of Commonwealth programs already exist for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that there is a potential anomaly in requiring the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to regulate the satellite program service or television networking but to make no such requirement for terrestrial networking.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. Although commercial television stations currently practise extensive networking by terrestrial means, in the sense of large-scale distribution of programs from one central source, cost considerations prevent this practice from developing to such a point that local control of the receiving stations is endangered. The Tribunal inquiry is concerned, at least in part, with the issue of whether satellite delivery of programs will increase the probability of such local control being lost.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cane Toad: Ecological Impact in Northern Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the introduced toad Bufo marinus (cane toad) has become established in the Northern Territory, and that the continuing expansion of the geographic range of this pest could have serious ecological impact in the N.T.

(2) Will he indicate what steps are being taken to prevent the toad from becoming established in the Territory in light of his attempts to enlarge the Kakadu National Park as a portion of Australia to be maintained for future generations.

(3) What steps is the Australian Government taking to investigate possible control of this pest in the light of documented evidence of the harmful effects of the toad upon native wildlife that succumb to its toxic secretions or competition.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Since 1980 the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory has been monitoring the distribution of cane toads in the Gulf of Carpentaria region . There is considerable concern regarding the environmental consequences of the westward movement of the cane toad to presently unaffected areas of the Territory.

(2) I am concerned that the cane toad may become established in Kakadu National Park. Preliminary discussions have been held between officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and Australian Quarantine Service research scientists on the possible control of cane toads using one of the exotic iridoviruses. The host specificity and target efficacy of these viruses require further research and evaluation.
(3) See (2) above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cane Toad: Effect on Native Fauna

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 28 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer given by his predecessor to my Question No. 152 ( Hansard, 27 April 1976, page 1650) concerning cane toads, has the Acting Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service approached State wildlife authorities to see if the cane toad problem warranted combined State- Commonwealth action; if so,what was the outcome of those discussions.
(2) What action was taken by the Federal and State Governments at the time on each of the 19 recommendations made in the report by Mr Michael Tyler of the University of Adelaide.

(3) In view of his predecessor's observation 8 years ago, that information about the cane toad is poorly documented and is one area that requires research, what action has been taken to research the effect of the toad on native fauna.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The spread of cane toads and their apparent adverse impact on native wildlife has been the subject of Commonwealth-State consideration and has been discussed in the forum of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers and associated Committees.

In 1977, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service funded a three year study of the biology of the cane toad and its effects on Australian wildlife. It was found that the sensitivity of native wildlife to cane toad venom varies with various lizards (goannas) and snakes being the most obviously affected.

(2) The report by Mr Michael Tyler of the University of Adelaide to which the then Minister referred, was prepared for the Vermin and Noxious Weeds Destruction Board of Victoria and the Western Australian Agricultural Protection Board. I am not aware what specific action those agencies have taken in relation to the recommendations contained in the report.
(3) See answer to (1).
