QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether in January 1983, the United States Department of Commerce, National Technical Information Service, submitted to the US Congress its justification of estimates for the fiscal year 1984; if so, did the report ( a) refer to an electro-magnetic gun (EMG) program being pursued in the US and (b ) note, on page 157, that the US has maintained close ties with related work pursued by the Government of Australia.
(2) What does the 'related work' referred to in the report involve.
(3) How closely does Australia work with the US on this program.
(4) What are the potential strategic applications of EMG technology.
(5) How far advanced is the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The report referred to by the honourable member is a compendium of descriptive summary sheets and was a supporting document for the US Department of Defense's Research, Development, Test and Evaluation (RDT&E) financial estimates for fiscal year 1984. Although the actual date of release is not specified it is most likely that the compendium was submitted to the US Congress in February 1983. The honourable member's copy was provided by the US Department of Commerce National Technical Information Service.
(1)(a) Yes.
(1)(b) Yes.
(2) The 'related work' carried out by Australia is concerned with research into the physics of electromagnetic launchers.

(3) Australia and the United States are involved in a joint collaborative program on electromagnetic launchers. This program is one of a number of programs carried out under the auspices of the Australia-US Memorandum of Understanding on co-operative research and development.

(4) Potential applications of electromagnetic launchers cover any situation where an ultra high velocity of projectile is required, such as for intercept of anti-ship missiles. While not of interest to Australia, they have also been proposed for strategic systems such as defence against ballistic missiles.

(5) US workers have demonstrated the feasibility of accelerating projectiles of 300 grammes mass to velocities of 4 kilometres per second. Velocities in excess of 30 kilometres per second are considered possible in the future. Scientists in the Department of Defence have designed, built and analysed the performance of small experimental electromagnetic launchers. They have made particular contributions to the overall understanding of the complex physics of these devices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a cash injection of $90m given to Australian National Line in June 1983 ; if so, was it (a) given to improve ANL's commercial efficiency, (b) conditional on ANL management to improve management efficiency and (c) conditional on sea-going unions to implement manning reductions and increase dead-ship productivity.
(2) Have the unions (a) reduced manning of ships in the 6 months up to December 1983 and (b) improved the productivity of ship usage in the same period.
(3) Did ANL give one month's notice of termination of the Darwin/East Coast service; if so, was this part of the improved management efficiency.
(4) Can Tasmanian shippers expect a similar period of notice of ANL if the Bass Strait service runs at a loss,

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government made a capital injection of $90m to the Australian Shipping Commission, trading as the Australian National Line (ANL) in June 1983. It comprised $30m cash and $60m conversion of outstanding Domestic Treasury loans to equity
(a) Yes;
(b) Yes;
(c) Seagoing unions agreed to certain improvements in manning levels and to examine other ways of improving efficiency.
(2) (a) Yes;
(b) Ship productivity has improved.

(3) ANL's decision to withdraw from the East Coast/ Darwin service and its formal notice of one month to shippers was made after extensive discussions, spanning over three years, between ANL, the Federal and Northern Territory Governments and shippers. In 1983-84 the Government increased the subsidy for the service by a third to $2m to allow more time for the Northern Territory Government to develop proposals for alternatives.

It was only after the Northern Territory Government did not come forward with any constructive proposals and also advised that no financial assistance would be forthcoming that the decision was taken by ANL that the service be terminated .
(4) The Government is not aware of any suggestion that ANL proposes to withdraw from the Bass Strait trades.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 1 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the average length of time taken by Customs officers to clear personal effects of public service officers returning from overseas.
(2) If there is any delay, what are the reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Customs inspections are normally carried out within two working days from the time the importer or importers' agent requests an appointment for the examination to be made. This period may be slightly extended during times of workload peaks or staff unavailability. Unless prohibited imports or the payment of duty is involved, the goods are released for delivery immediately the Customs examination is completed.

The examinations cannot be carried out until the goods have been delivered to the place of examination from the shipping company and the goods made available for inspection and all necessary documentation completed by the importer or the importers' agent, including the owners' personal Customs declaration.

These procedures apply to examinations of personal effects imported by public service officers returning from overseas, as well as importation by other private or commercial interests. In the case of returning public service officers appointments for inspections are made by the Department of Administrative Services who act as agent for the owner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: When will Mackay have its ABC-FM radio transmitter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No new VHF-FM radio services can be introduced into the Mackay area until surrounding television transmitters using particular VHF frequencies known as Band II (channels 3, 4 and 5) have been allocated to other VHF or UHF channels. Band II covers the internationally recognised portion of the spectrum used for VHF-FM radio services although past planning decisions in Australia gave shared usage to some television services.

The Government is anxious to clear the way for the development of FM radio. New services will be introduced as soon as the frequencies become available. Early attention will be given to those areas, most critically affected, including Mackay.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he bring up to date the information given by his predecessor in answer to Question No. 159 (1) (Hansard, 15 September 1983, page 958) in relation to (a ) which trials of dissidents Australian Embassy officials have attended, or attempted to attend, in the Soviet Union, (b) where these trials were held, (c) the date on which these trials were held, (d) in each case (i) the charges and ( ii) the sentences, (e) the reasons given for denial of access to Australian officials where applicable and (f) what representatives from other countries attended, or attempted to attend, these trials.
(2) Further to his answer to Question No. 159 (2), has the Government supported any subsequent initiatives to support the release of Dr Yuri Orlov or Mr Anatoli Shcharansky.
(3) How many Soviet citizens emigrated to Australia under the 'family migration ' category in 1983.
(4) How many persons emigrated to Australia from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in 1983.

(5) Further to his answer to Question No. 159 (4), will the Government support any move to establish, in the Parliament, a Standing Committee on Human Rights to report on serious violations of human rights in any country, including Australia, in accordance with paragraph 65 of the final chapter of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on Human Rights in the Soviet Union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Embassy officials have attempted to attend the following trials since September 1983:

(i)-(a) Begun, Josef; (b) Vladimir, RSFSR; (c) 12 October 1983; (d) (i) section 70 (1) of the RSFSR criminal code and (ii) seven years' imprisonment; (e) Vladimir was described as 'temporarily closed to foreigners'; (f) British, Dutch , United States and Canadian representatives were also refused permission to travel to Vladimir.

(ii)-(a) Medvedkova, Olga; (b) Moscow; (c) 16 and 23 March; (d) (i) Article 193 (2) of the RSFSR criminal code and (ii) thirty months suspended sentence; (e) ' no available places'; (f) United States, British and Canadian representatives also attempted unsuccessfully to attend.
(2) No representations have been made on behalf of Orlov and Shcharansky since Mr Jacobi's 1983 question.
(3) Under the 'family migration' category, 9 Soviet citizens and one family of 3 came to join relatives in Australia in 1983.
(4) The figures for December 1983 are not yet available, but it can be confirmed that the total number of persons emigrating from the USSR to Australia in the period January-November 1983 was 29.
(5) In response to the final point, I refer the honourable member to my answer to a similar question in September 1983.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Horticultural Products: Inclusion in Food Aid Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he include horticultural products, such as dried or canned fruit, in Australia's food aid program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The question of what commodities should be included in Australia's food aid program falls within the responsibilities of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. However, I am informed that modest quantities of horticultural products are included in the program from time to time as appropriate. While the bulk of Australia's food aid program is in the form of wheat, flour and rice, there is also a smaller non-grain component of the program under which a range of commodities such as milk powder, horticultural products and canned meat are provided according to the requirements of particular recipients.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Does he recall saying, in reference to my speech on the second reading of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983, that 'He asked whether the anti-dumping duty will be refunded on goods that are exported. Of course, it is' (Hansard, 1 March 1984, page 277); if so, does this mean that dumping duties on nitrogen fertiliser will be refunded when that fertiliser is used in the production of primary produce which is exported.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Dumping duties are not excluded from the payment of drawback.

The payment of drawback is however subject to certain eligibility criteria set out in the relevant legislation. These criteria would exclude from drawback goods which have been used in Australia to fulfil their intended home consumption purpose and would necessarily exclude nitrogen fertiliser used in the production of primary produce.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Mr Elias Freij, the Mayor of Bethlehem, a guest of the Australian Government; if so, is his visit being sponsored by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

(2) Is he able to say whether Mr Freij stated at a presss conference at the Canberra Press Club on Monday, 6 March 1984, in response to a question from an unidentified journalist concerning the agreement reached between Israel and Mr Gemayel, the President of the Lebanon, that Mr Gemayel has no authority in Lebanon and secondly that in Jordan there is a government, in Syria there is a government, and in Egypt there is a government but in Lebanon there is no government, there are only gangs and gangsters.

(3) If so, is he able to say whether this statement (a) gave offence to the Lebanese Ambassador, Mr Heneine and (b) reflected seriously upon a government to which Australia has given support and encouragement.
(4) Is he further able to say whether Mr Freij failed to apologise to the Lebanese Ambassador for his statements about the Lebanese Government.

(5) Did Mr Freij later, in concert with officers of the Minister's Department, issue a more detailed statement supporting Lebanese independence, calling for a cessation of hostilities and a withdrawal of non-Lebanese forces, but falling short of giving to the Lebanese Ambassador and the Lebanese the apology and retraction sought by the Lebanese Ambassador.

(6) Has he, or his Department, received a note of protest from the Lebanese Ambassador; if so, (a) does the note call for any action on the part of the Australian Government, disassociating itself from the statements of its guest about the Lebanese President and the Lebanese people and (b) what has been the Government's response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Elias Freij, Mayor of Bethlehem, visited Australia from 4-18 March 1984. He was invited by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the costs of his visit were met by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

(2) Mr Freij addressed the National Press Club on 6 March 1984. The Department of Foreign Affairs does not have a full text of his address. Mr Freij made comments similar to those referred to in the honourable member's question, although it is far from clear that there was any mention of President Gemayel.

(3) and (6) The Lebanese Ambassador called on the Department of Foreign Affairs on 7 March 1984 and delivered a note drawing the Department's attention to reported comments by Mr Freij which the Ambassador described as 'insulting to the President and Government of Lebanon'. He asked for 'public reparation'. The Lebanese Ambassador's request was considered, but it was felt that there was no requirement for the Department of Foreign Affairs to express a public view on the opinions of a private person. The Lebanese Ambassador was informed of this.

(4) and (5) I understand that Mr Freij called on the Lebanese Ambassador immediately after his address to the National Press Club. I further understand that as a result of this meeting Mr Freij issued the following statement clarifying his remarks:

'I strongly support the full independence of Lebanon. All countries should respect the integrity of the borders of Lebanon and its sovereignty. All non- Lebanese forces have no right to be in Lebanon and should withdraw without any conditions or concessions. All non-Lebanese forces which carry guns in Lebanon must be obedient to the Lebanese Government in this critical hour in the history of Lebanon.

I wish President Gemayel, his Government and our Lebanese people all the necessary courage to solve their problems and factional differences in a way which would preserve the unity and integrity of Lebanon and the independence of Lebanon.'
The statement was drawn up by Mr Freij. The Department of Foreign Affairs assisted Mr Freij in having the statement brought to the attention of the media.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 April 1984:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is available to indicate how many people listen to broadcasts of Parliament.

(2) Does this information indicate (a) ages, (b) sex, (c) socio-economic groupings, (d) residential regions of the listeners and (e) the different sizes of the audiences at different times of day; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice received from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A survey conducted by the ABC's audience research department in the month of August, 1983 in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Hobart is the most recent source of information and shows that on a four-city basis:
49.3 per cent of people aged 10 years and over have listened to a broadcast of Parliament at some time in their life;

In demographic terms, these people who have listened to Parliament, are more likely to be male than female and to be aged either 25-44 years or 45+ years. Information on socio-economic groups and residential groupings of listeners is not available.
47.5 per cent of those who listen to Parliament do so once or twice per year; 29.3 per cent listen several times per year; 15.6 per cent listen once a week; 7 .6 per cent listen most days.
Females are slightly more likely to listen to Parliament on an infrequent basis , than males.

57.8 per cent of those who have listened to a broadcast of Parliament at some time did so primarily because 'it just comes on'; 22 per cent listen because they 'follow Parliament'; 11.6 per cent listen specifically to 'Question Time'; and 18.3 per cent listen for a range of reasons;
Females are more likely to listen because 'it just comes on', while males are more likely to have listened because they 'follow Parliament';

For nearly two-thirds of those who listened (63.3 per cent), the time of listening tended to be variable; for 10 per cent it was in the morning; for 25.3 per cent it was in the afternoon; and for 14 per cent it was at night. Age and sex differences in these listening patterns were not in evidence.

2. It is not really possible to state how many people listen to Parliament. However, it is possible to show how many people listen to radio at times when Parliament and/or the normal Radio 1 program is being broadcast. Thus, the following figures relate to time-slots, which sometimes represent listening to Parliament and sometimes represent listening to the normal Radio 1 program. The two cannot be separated; eg Sydney/Melbourne: April-June 1983 Weeks 1, 3, 4, 5, 6 Parliament was broadcast. Weeks 2, 7, 8 normal 2BL/3LO program was broadcast.
Sydney Melbourne

While information relating to age, sex, residential centres and, as has been explained above, some degree of audience size is available, the ABC does not have information about socio-economic groupings.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Television and Radio Coverage of 1984 Olympic Games

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 November 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provide the same radio coverage of the 1984 Olympic Games and television and radio coverage of the 1986 Commonwealth Games to all Australians or will certain areas receive only a percentage of that coverage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Final details of the ABC Radio coverage of the 1984 Olympic Games have not yet been decided. Choice of events to be broadcast will be influenced by results, that is, the specific events including finals, in which Australians are competing. Because of Australian time zones, the great difference between Australian time and United States West Coast time and limits on broadcasting capacity using Radio 3, it will not be possible for the ABC to provide the same radio coverage to all Australians. These problems will to some extent be lessened in the State capital cities, Canberra and Newcastle where both ABC Radio 1 and Radio 2 operate.

It is also significant to note that on 12 March 1984, the ABC announced that Radio Station 2UE had acquired exclusive rights throughout Australia to the ABC' s coverage of the Los Angeles Olympics. Radio station 2UE is seeking to sell coverage to other Australian commercial radio stations.

The ABC has obtained exclusive radio and television rights for the Edinburgh Commonwealth Games in 1986 and it is anticipated that all Australians will be able to enjoy its coverage. However, details of coverage of this event have not yet been considered.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Assistance to Private Business by Department of Science and Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) financial, (b) technical and (c) other forms of assistance, are available from the Minister's Department, to private business.
(2) What (a) is the contact point and (b) requirements have to be met to qualify, for each form of assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A range of financial, technical and other forms of assistance is provided by the Department of Science and Technology to the private sector. This assistance is designed to promote the development, maintenance and utilization of scientific and technological capability to meet Australia's industrial, economic , international, social and cultural needs and its objectives include:
stimulating scientific research and technical development in industry, government and academic sectors;
facilitating the effective application of technology and the development of technologies having special significance for Australia's industrial growth;
faciliting invention and innovation.

In addition my Department provides support for basic research to promote the acquisition and advancement of knowledge. Although these schemes are not specifically designed to support industry, appropriately qualified individuals within the private sector may receive support from them.
Specific schemes and forms of assistance are:
innovation centres-provide private and corporate inventors with access to information, expertise, services and facilities.
workshops in innovation and entrepreneurship (enterprise workshops)-provide training for potential entrepreneurs.
assistance to inventors scheme-provides technical advice and/or financial assistance to Australian inventors.
information technology programs-provide technical assistance and advice to industry and the public on information technology.
multiplier agency and infrastructure development-provides support to various organisations which in turn provide assistance to industry.
manufacturing technology programs-provide technical support and some financial assistance to business.
Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme-provides financial assistance to industry in the fields of industrial research and development.
Australian research grants scheme-provides financial assistance for basic research.
marine science and technologies grants scheme-provides financial assistance to qualified researchers in the field of marine sciences and technologies.
national biotechnology program research grants scheme-provides financial assistance for research in biotechnology.
national research fellowships scheme-provides financial assistance to qualified researchers for basic research.
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation collaborative projects-provide technical inquiry service to business.
patent trade marks and designs-provides technical assistance to industry in areas of industrial property protection, patents, trade marks and designs.
National Materials Handling Bureau-provides technical assistance and advisory services to industry in areas of materials handling.
Management Investment Companies Licensing Board-allocates licences to companies to raise investment capital which attracts a tax concession.
Full details involve a considerable volume of material. I have provided the honourable member with documentation containing relevant information and points of contact separately.
The initial point of contact on these forms of assistance is the Central Office of my Department, Belconnen Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Institute for Health, Economics and Technology Assessment

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Health has provided funds of $13,900 to the Institute for Health Economics and Technology Assessment under the health services research grant scheme, to study the impact of health care technology assessment on health costs and private sector innovation in twelve nations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Uranium Industry: Industrial Safety Procedures

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does his Department recommend industrial safety proceedures to authorities responsible for enforcing these procedures in the Australian uranium industry.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the conclusion of the US Committee on Biological Effects of Ionizing Radiation (B.E.I.R. III, 1980, page 326) that the evidence is still insufficient to determine whether aggregates of radioactivity that remain localised in specific regions of the lungs give a greater or smaller risk of lung cancer per average lung dose than uniformly deposited radiation and that a small fraction of inhaled insoluble particles may remain in the bronchial epithelial layer for long periods.

(3) Is he able to say whether theoretical considerations following the work of Sir Macfarlane Burnet and others suggest that (a) there is no minimum dose of ionizing radiation capable of increasing cell mutation rates, (b) most cancers start from a single cell and (c) present guidelines to 'safe' levels of industrial exposure recommend toleration of total radiation doses to particular vulnerable tissue sites several orders of magnitude less than the recommended tolerable total body dose.

(4) Will he review existing guidelines for uranium mining and publish maximum and minimum estimates of increased malignant disease arising from uranium mining in Australia with (a) 40 hours' work without filtering of inspired air and (b) 40 hours' work with total efficient filtering of inspired air in (i) worst case conditions with deep cut dry mining in still air and (ii) best case conditions with efficient exhaust ventilation of the work site.

(5) Has he evidence that (a) miners and other workers in hot humid conditions prefer to dispense with respirators because the discomfort and impediment to breathing they create exceeds the discomfort of breathing slightly dusty unfiltered air and (b) employers and health authorities do not efficiently enforce use of respirators in mines.
(6) Has he information based on the use of alternatives to respirators such as air conditioned helmets or cabins for uranium miners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Formally, radiation safety procedures are recommended as guidelines to the Code of Practice on Radiation Protection in the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores (1980). The Australian Radiation Laboratory of my Department provides major input in the development of these guidelines which are published by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. In addition the Laboratory publishes, from time to time, handbooks of good practice. The State authorities make use of these codes, guidelines and handbooks in determining safety procedures to be followed in the uranium industry.

(2) Yes. The 'hot particle' thesis first advanced by Tamplin and Cochran has been rejected by a number of radiation experts (including the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council). There has been little serious discussion of this problem since about 1975.

(3) Australia's current radiation protection standards are based on the recommendations of the International Commission on Radiological Protection which assume that there is no threshold for radiation induced effects and that the effect of a radiation dose is in simple proportion to its size and is independent of the rate at which the dose is given (generally referred to as the linear hypothesis). They also take into account the varying sensitivity of different organs to ionising radiation.

There is a minority scientific opinion which holds that radiation is much more serious than is generally believed but there is also a minority scientific opinion which believes that radiation damage in man is greatly overestimated. The majority scientific opinion is that the linear hypothesis allows the upper limit of the radiation risk to be defined. Its use may lead to over-estimation of risk but is unlikely to under-estimate it.

(4) The Australian Radiation Laboratory has recently circulated widely a review paper on the present code of practice. The paper addresses many questions, including the need to re-examine exposure standards in the light of new information and improved understanding of radiation effects. These will be taken into account when the code of practice is revised.

Up to the present, monitoring of mine employees and of their working environment has demonstrated that exposure to ionising radiation, both external and internal, has in practice been very low and no significant increase in radiation induced malignancies is likely to result.
The following guidelines, which discuss aspects of the inhalation of radioactive materials, have been published to supplement the code of practice.
Background to radiation protection criteria embodied in the Radiation Protection Code
Personal respiratory protection
Radiation monitoring programs
Appointment, qualifications and responsibilities of ventilation officers
Radiation protection aspects of ventilation practice (in final stages of preparation).
The following handbooks have also been published.
Monitoring employee exposure to radon and its daughters in uranium mines
Radiation protection in the mining and milling of radioactive ores.

(5) In general the preferred regulatory practice is to ensure that working conditions do not require the use of respirators rather than to depend on respirators whose effectiveness is always difficult to control. Respirators are regarded as emergency aids to cover unforeseen circumstances.

(6) Individual filtered-air-flow helmets and mining equipment with air- conditioned driver's cabins have both been made available in Northern Territory mines. Air-conditioned cabins are in regular use by workers involved in mining operations.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What savings were planned by the introduction of the diesel fuel rebate scheme in terms of (a) type of saving and (b) value of saving.
(2) What was the increase of staff necessary to cope with the introduction of the scheme, and what is the annual cost of that staff in (a) salaries, (b) overtime and (c) travelling expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) There were two types of savings envisaged by the introduction of the diesel fuel rebate scheme. Firstly the additional revenue, which formed the greater part of anticipated savings received from diesel fuel purchasers who were no longer entitled to duty free fuel because of the limited eligible categories of uses. Secondly improved control under the rebate system has provided further savings by reducing the scope for abuse which existed under the old arrangements.
(2) The increase in staff necessary to cope with the introduction of the scheme was 100.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: STD Classification: Electoral Division of Flinders

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: When will he urgently review the STD telephone classification of residents of the electoral division of Flinders for calls to the Melbourne metropolitan area as promised in the Prime Minister's telegram of 1 March 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is assumed that the honourable member's question refers to the telegram sent by the Prime Minister to the honourable member for Flinders indicating that I would review telephone call charges from the Flinders electorate to the Melbourne metropolitan area.

Following representations to me from the honourable member for Flinders, such a review was completed by Telecom in June 1983. The report I received from Telecom indicated that it would not be appropriate, for a number of reasons, to vary call charges between the Mornington Peninsula and the metropolitan area.

The honourable member will be aware that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure is currently enquiring into Telecom's zonal charging policies. The Committee is to initially examine local call arrangements surrounding each of the capital cities and no doubt call charges from the Mornington Peninsula to Melbourne will be addressed as part of the study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 require Australian National (AN) to meet any loss it incurs over and above the Federal Government's yearly allocation.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the Tasmanian Government's recent decision to lift the need for permit fees for the movement of superphosphate in Tasmania; if so (a) was the decision based on an alleged heavy backlog of rail deliveries, (b) was there such a backlog and (c) how did this backlog come about.
(3) What was the consequent reduction of revenue for AN.
(4) Is this situation being rectified so that the Tasmanian region of AN can maintain its anticipated target for revenue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Under Section 56 of the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 the Commission is required to use commercial methods to fund any loss it incurs over and above its budget appropriation.

(2) (a) I am advised that the decision to ease permit fees for road cartage of superphosphate was made by the Tasmanian Government in the light of backlogs of unfilled orders at 8 March 1984 amounting to 6,000 tonnes for rail and 3,000 tonnes allocated to road. Easement of permit fees was applicable only to the 3, 000 tonnes backlog for road, and was subject to review at the end of March 1984. At 27 March 1984 the road component of the backlog was 2,500 tonnes and the permit-free period was extended to 14 April 1984, subject to further review at that date.
(b) See 2 (a) above.

(c) The unfilled rail orders were brought on by a seasonal rush and were accentuated by less than optimum wagon utilisation due to: (i) slow discharge of loaded wagons by some consignees, (ii) limitations in maximum gross train loads brought on by industrial bans on locomotive servicing.
(3) There is no anticipated reduction in revenue. No cancellations or reductions in loading for rail have been evident to date.
(4) The unfilled rail orders of 6,000 tonnes at 8 March 1984 have so far been reduced by 1,500 tonnes in addition to the normal loading commitment of 500 tonnes per day.

The situation is being rectified by (i) removal of locomotive servicing bans, allowing greater gross tonnage on trains, (ii) constant liaison with consignees to ensure prompt discharging of wagons, (iii) supply of wagons for weekend loading.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Children: Alleged Effects of Eating before Bedtime

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in Zdoroviec, the Soviet health magazine, as translated in the Sydney Sun of 16 March 1984; if so, does it (a) warn parents not to give children too much to eat before bed because it excites the sexual organs, (b) claim similar effects for coffee, chocolate and spices and (c) warn Soviet parents not to caress or kiss their children because it encourages stimulation of the erogenous zones and precocious development of sensuality.
(2) Has his attention also been drawn to similar views expressed by the Reverend Fred Nile, MLC, of New South Wales, and his adherents.
(3) Does his Department have any scientific evidence to support these views.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have seen an AFP-AAP-Reuter report of an article, stated to have appeared in Zdoroviec, saying much the same as quoted by the honourable member.
(2) I have not been able to locate any material of this nature.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department established a uniform royalty rate for licensing fees; if so, (a) what is the rate and (b) which licence categories have reached that level.
(2) Are increases, additional to those imposed by the last Budget, being considered in the number of licence categories and in licence fees for satellite earth stations.
(3) Do the present earth station licence fees include a 16 per cent royalty component.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From 1 September 1983, a royalty component was included in all radiocommunications licence fees. While it is not feasible to ascertain exact figures for each service, the royalty averages out at approximately 15 per cent.
(2) A review of all licence categories and fees is undertaken every year.
(3) See the reply to part (1) of this question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Steedman Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 6 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that under a number of recent non-labor administrations, no action was taken to encourage light-keepers in attendance on Commonwealth light- stations to associate with or to form a union or association in their own interests.
(2) Do light-keepers remain one section of the Australian work-force in which membership of a protective association is the exception rather than the rule.

(3) Recognising that it may be neither advisable nor practical to force such public servants into an appropriate organisation, is it possible to encourage such organisations and to supply relevant information.

(4) Do the report and transcript of evidence of the inquiry by the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee into light-stations indicate that (a) no light-keepers were called upon formally to present evidence to that Committee and (b) no association representing light-keepers was called before or made a submission to the Committee.

(5) Can he say whether (a) light-keepers were able to present their views and experiences in a formalised, inquiry-type situation when the Committee visited individual light-stations and (b) senior officers of his Department were present during these visits.

(6) Does he propose any action to ensure that adequate and independent consultations are held with light-keepers when matters affecting light-stations and their relationship with the community are under consideration; if so, what action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) I have no direct knowledge of what action may have been taken under previous administrations. However, both the Australian Public Service Association (Fourth Division Officers) and the Customs Officers' Association of Australia, Fourth Division, are authorised to offer membership to light-keepers and various other categories. My department co-operates with these associations in disseminating or displaying relevant information for their members. Beyond that applications for membership are at the discretion of individual light- keepers.
(2) Accurate statistics on membership of staff associations by light-keepers are not available. My department estimates that approximately one-third of light -keepers are union members.

(4) (a) and (b) The seeking of written submissions and the calling of organisations and persons to present oral evidence were matters for the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The Committee placed advertisements in the national Press advising of its Inquiry and inviting submissions from interested individuals and organisations. I understand that written submissions were made by two light-keepers and by the Australian Public Service Association (Fourth Division Officers) on behalf of light-keepers. Neither the light-keepers nor the Association was called before the Committee during its public hearings.

(5) (a) The Committee visited 10 of the 41 manned light-stations around Australia. During these visits the Committee held informal discussions with the light-keepers at these stations. I understand that the discussions were not conducted in a formalised inquiry type situation.
(b) Yes.
(6) My Department will continue to consult with light-keepers as appropriate on matters affecting their particular stations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 7 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he consider (a) extending the range of eligible relations under the family migration program to cover nieces and nephews and (b) a revision of the family reunion guidelines to enable Australian residents who have in the past acted in loco parentis to their nieces and nephews, to sponsor the entry of those relatives and have them assessed for entry as if they were the natural children of residents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Government's immigration policy contains generous concessions which allow for the migration of close family. The policy is based on the concept of the nuclear family (parents, children and siblings) which reflects the Australian norm. If the policy were to include nieces and nephews it would imply a commitment to the extended family concept and carry with it an obligation to include other relatives in eligible categories. Our capacity to absorb migrants would be severely tested if eligibility categories were to be widened as the honourable member suggests.

(b) Imigration policy allows for the acceptance of sponsorships for relatives where special circumstances exist. Each case is considered on its merits having regard to the nature of the circumstances and the needs of both the sponsor here and the relative overseas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Changes to Equal Opportunity Programs: Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What changes to existing equal opportunities programs have been made in the Minister's Department since the 1983 general election in regard to (a) aims, (b) assessment procedures, (c) methods of ensuring that the aims of the program have been met, (d) procedures for union involvement and/or consultation in the program, (e) the involvement of the Public Service Board Equal Opportunities Bureau and (f) the priority rating of the program within the Department.
(2) What is the cost of the Department's programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department's equal employment opportunity policy was determined after the general election in 1983. Committees have been set up in central and regional offices to implement that policy.
No formal arrangement was in place prior to the general election in 1983.
(2) Departmental initiatives are being undertaken through the respective equal employment opportunity committees. Costs incurred to date are restricted to internal publishing and advertising.
